Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2010 07:40AM dlb823 wrote: Houndmommy ~ I also had a mast & rads.  I also had multicentric disease (4 lesions in 2 quadrants), but of more concern was an unspecified margin on a bit of tissue that contained the tiny (1mm) 4th lesion, which was not known about prior to pathology, so never marked, and extracapsular extension in my 1 positive node.  I talked to 3 different rad oncs (2 @ UCLA @ different times & 1 local) before deciding to do rads.  I'm not sure if they ever gave me an actual reduction in recurrence risk number.  I just felt that I wanted to do everything possible to minimize the risk, and the uninked margin and extracapsular extension concerned me enough to feel that rads was the right decision.       Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 02:41PM - edited Jun 28, 2009 02:49PM by dlb823 Erica ~ I think the answer depends a lot on how well you know this woman.  Also, the fact that she may have refused chemo because she doesn't want to lose her hair (although you don't even know if that's actually true or the real reason) makes me think that she might be reluctant to talk to anyone about her dx.  One thing you might do is write her a card (or call, if you know her well enough) and say something like, "How nice that (daughter) was here visiting.  You know, DH saw her briefly on Saturday, and he couldn't help feeling she was more concerned about you than usual.  He couldn't put his finger on it, but I thought I'd call and see how you're doing, since I haven't seen you around as much recently.  It also occured to me that with your daughter not nearby, if you do need anything, I wanted to be sure you have my phone number."  An alternative idea (again depending on your relationship with her) might be to drop off something freshly baked (bread, cookies), or some fruit (if you have trees) or something from your garden, and include a note that you haven't seen her around as much recently, and hope everything is okay.  Ideally, she'll call to thank you for it.  If not, you have another reason to call her -- Did she get it (if you left it on her doorstep, for example), and is she okay?  If it was my neighbor, I think I'd maybe do something like that.  In other words, reach out, but very generally -- not mentioning bc until she does.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 09:25AM dlb823 wrote: teresainidaho ~  I think the best thing you can do is open their eyes to the fact that, as serious as her bc is, there is light at the end of the treatment tunnel, and with surgery and today's 3rd generation of chemo drugs, there is much hope she can recover and have a full life ahead of her.  There are many women on here who had a lot of positive nodes and are doing very well years later.  The other thing you can suggest is that they both talk to the psychologist or social worker where she's being treated.  Large hospitals and cancer centers normally have someone on staff to help patients and their families with the stress of a bc dx and tx.  Hopefully, someone like that can help them both, and that sort of counseling is usually included in your care, so no additional charge (at least where I've been treated). It sounds like her husband has a lot of growing up to do (no matter what his age), and this situation can end up giving them both that unexpected gift, or it may not.  In the mean time, please tell your friend about this website so that we can also offer her our support, including resources for financial assistance with her treatment if by any chance that's a concern (since you mentioned his comments about money).   Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 12:05PM dlb823 wrote: Christy, women sometimes have pain with a breast lump, but it's not the most common symptom, and it can be due to a number of B9 conditions, so is never a real indicator of a malignancy (breast cancer). Metastatic tumors refer to breast cancer (or any type of cancer) that has spread beyond it's original site -- for example, to the bone or the liver.  That type of cancer can be extremely painful, but the pain would be in your back, for example; not your breast. Dr. Google can be great for getting more information after you have an actual diagnosis on any health matter.  Until then, it's useless and unnecessarily frightening to try to self diagnosis. The vast majority of breast "spots" (something like 85% of spots they actually decide should be biopsied) turn out to be something other than breast cancer, so try not to worry too much at this point.  Hopefully, there's a totally B9 explanation for your pain and the spot they see.   (((Hugs)))  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2010 08:23AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Karen ~ Yes, your pathology means that you have two types of cancer cells.  In situ is a less invasive type of breast cancer that rarely travels beyond the breast.  Like invasive breast cancer, it can be either ductal (DCIS) or lobular (LCIS).  So you have both a lesion of invasive bc (the ILC), as well as some LCIS, and this is fairly common, especially for IDC and DCIS, because those make up a much higher percentage of bc overall.  Invasive lesions are often found within areas of in situ bc, and the fact that your BS didn't mention it isn't all that surprising, as it's the invasive part that is the more concerning of the two, especially since the in situ component seems to be the smaller part.  I think only your BS and an MRI can answer your question about an increased likelihood of more breast cancer in the same breast, and a radiation oncologist will be able to advise you on your radiation options, especially since the type of radiation you're hoping to have is one of the newer possibilities.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 12:04PM dlb823 wrote: Whenever you have any kind of test that requires a contrast dye, you should have to fill out a questionnaire that asks about allergies to foods, especially shellfish.  Some contrast dyes contain iodine or an iodine-like substance, and those who have had any type of allergic reaction, no matter how mild, to iodine or shellfish absolutely need to bring this to the attention of whoever is doing the test. Reactions to MRI dyes are extremely rare, but they can be life threatening.  But if you've never had an allergic reaction to shellfish, you're probably worrying needlessly.    Deanna
Posts.Title: Risks of MRI Scaredandworried Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 01:47PM dlb823 wrote: Maisie, I don't think anyone can offer an opinion re. IBC from a verbal description, nor do I know exactly how your medical system works in the UK.  But, in general, unless you've been given a specific diagnosis for your pain, then I think you need to continue to pursue getting one. As far as I know, the only way to diagnosis or rule out IBC is via a skin biopsy, sometimes referred to as a punch test.   But there are occasionally other forms of bc that do not show up on a mammogram either, such as some lobular bc, and especially if your breasts are dense, which is now considered a risk factor in itself.  So since your pain has not gone away in 8 mos., I would agree with you that further testing would be appropriate, maybe starting with an ultrasound. Try not to overly worry about the possibility of IBC, which is extremely rare.  But do request another appointment with a breast specialist to voice your concern about the ongoing pain and possibility that something may have been missed, and see if they can do some additional testing.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2009 03:06PM dlb823 wrote: wenmazb ~  Sorry you're having the problems you are, and good that you got the gloves, which should preserve your nails, especially.  I have two suggestions.  For anything that feels like neuropathy (numbness, nerve type tingling) in your hands or feet, the supplement B6 often helps.  I and many other women here have used it with success. But as far as the rash and that sort of thing -- I don't think that's "typical."  You need to show that to your onc.  Occasionally, women do have hand issues that will not get better with topical creams.  If you are one of those rare cases, you may not be able to tolerate more Taxotere, and your regimen may have to be switched.  This isn't meant to alarm you -- just give you a heads up.  You need to have your onc check your hands.  Peeling skin (which you didn't mention) is the more serious SE that suggests Taxotere intolerance, but the rash sounds a bit out of the ordinary and concerning enough that I wouldn't just put a cream on it because it could get much worse with future infusions. Also, if you haven't found it yet, there's a thread here called Anyone on just Taxotere & Cytoxin (if that's the combo you're on), that you might want to check out for tips and support.  And the thread for gals who started chemo in July (there's one for every month) would also be a great group to join if you haven't already.  Good luck, and let us know what happens!    Deanna

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 02:15PM - edited May 22, 2012 02:16PM by dlb823 If the surgeon is truly a breast (only) surgeon who specializes in diseases of the breast (vs. a general surgeon who includes breast surgery within their specialties) then IMO her opinion would trump that of a radiologist.  I say that because it's well known that radiology is open to interpretation -- in other words, two rads might look at the same image but come to different conclusions about it.   I agree with getting a second opinion, possibly at a major medical center, if you haven't already, where both a new radiologist and breast surgeon could look at your images.  Here's a list of NCI-designated cancer centers, where I would absolutely trust their opinion on whether or not a biopsy is warranted:  cancercenters.cancer.gov/cance...  Good luck!  Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2016 09:17PM dlb823 wrote: Loripotrubacz, I'm so sorry about your mother's situation. It sounds like she's been through a lot since her original Stage 2 diagnosis. As far as a prognosis, no one can really venture a guess about that, nor should they, as it will depend entirely on how well she responds to her chemo. I can tell you that it's not unusual to have metastasis in several or even many different areas, and have an almost miraculous turnaround. It all depends on how well she tolerates her chemo and how effective it turns out to be on her mets. As far as letting other things go, as you put it, the lung mets are probably the most life threatening if not treated. For the most part, the other areas affected are all bone, perhaps with the exception of brain, which could also be bone if it's actually her skull vs. her brain. I don't know for certain, but it sounds like the plan is to get the lung mets under control, then re-evaluate what's next. Has her oncologist given you any suggestions for increasing her caloric intake with a decreased appetite? Obviously, it's important to keep her strength up, so be sure he/she is aware of the situation, especially if something like an anti nausea med could be helpful. Let us know what other questions you might have. I'm glad you've found us. (((Hugs))), Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2013 09:35PM - edited Jan 3, 2013 09:36PM by dlb823 azrescue, I have a slightly different take on your situation because an MRI-guided biopsy can be very stressing and not something you should go through if you don't have to.  And I'm also not comfortable with the suggestion to biopsy your right breast just b'cuz you're already doing your left one.   I know you like the newer doctor you're seeing, but is she a breast (only) surgeon at a major medical center such as The Mayo or the U of A (since you appear to be in AZ)?  If she's not, then I would suggest taking your mammo, u/s & MRI results to a breast surgeon at one of those two places for a 2nd opinion on the biopsy recommendations.  I just think it would be prudent to get a second opinion before you take the next step, especially since that next step isn't just a simple, singular biopsy but an MRI-guided biopsy PLUS two additional biopsies.  And I would hope that a breast surgeon wouldn't leave it up to you to decide a best time frame, if they think a biopsy is necessary.   Just my take on your situation ~  (((Hugs))), and I'm glad you've found BCO.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 11:12AM dlb823 wrote: Irishred ~  In situ is not what you have.  Your pathology says "invasive," which means it is not "in situ," or "in place" although they may find a bit of in situ later, as it sometimes co-exists with other types of bc.  Your bc is ductal, which is the most common type.  (Lobular is the other type.)  Also, bc is explained in terms of a grade (1, 2 or 3) and a stage (which you will find out later).  High grade is usually a 3, which means the bc has been there long enough to change from normal-looking cells to cells that are not growing in normal patterns.  The grade simply means to what extent the cells have changed from normal to abnormal.  It sounds like yours are Grade 3, which means the bc has been growing for awhile and is more aggressive than a Grade 1 would be -- but still no cause for alarm.  Many women are Stage 3 and, with proper treatment, are just fine. Did they give you any idea of the size of the lesion?  That will be an important factor in determining your treatment options. So sorry that you're joining the club that none of us ever wanted to join, but we're here for you ~  Deanna
Posts.Title: Got the results Irishred Irishred

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 09:34AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:15AM by dlb823 sandra's_daughter, whether or not you switch medical teams in the end, you absolutely need a second opinion at this point.  In addition to way too many questions, the fact that your Mom has lost faith in her doctors is not a good thing, as they need to be able to have absolute credibility with her to instill confidence and trust in their abilities to get her through this. Emory sounds like the place to be.  It's an NCI-designated Cancer Center, which means they see far more breast cancer than any local general surgeon, and will be extremely detail-minded evaluating her situation and the possible need for an axillary node dissection at this point.  NCI-designated status also means they are totally up on the latest research (these are the institutions doing the research) and state-of-the art treatment protocols.  http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html Any reputable doctor will not mind a patient wanting a second opinion; in fact, the good ones encourage it because when it comes to breast cancer, no one doctor knows it all, and it's in their best interest as well.  A doctor who scoffs at a second opinion would raise a huge red flag in my mind, so don't be afraid to ask for a referral.  Your Mom is employing these people, and she has every right to have doctors she trusts and to ask for second opinions when things are not clear. I actually went through something similar to your Mom -- started with a highly-esteemed local surgeon with impeccable credentials.  However, for whatever reason, there were inconsistencies in my pathology, so I went to an NCI-designated cancer center (UCLA) to figure it out.  My bio page tells more, but it was absolutely the best thing I could have done. I hope you'll stay with us and keep us updated on her situation.  Good luck!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 01:03PM dlb823 wrote: So sorry about your Mom's bc diagnosis.  Hopefully, it will turn out to be very early stage with an excellent long term prognosis after treatment. In the mean time, let me answer your questions.  First, you're absolutely right about an MRI being a pretty standard test done after a bc dx to rule out anything else going on in either breast. Perhaps she just didn't mention it to you.  A CT scan is more optional and may not be recommended unless there is reason to believe her bc has been there awhile, or she's having any symptoms that raise a concern. The gene test is most likely a test for the BRCA1 and BRCA 2 mutations.  When there is a genetic factor, more aggressive tx is recommended. And not knowing one's stage (which is based on the actual size of the lesion and any possible lymph node involvement) until after surgery is the way it works.  They can tell her an initial grade (1, 2 or 3, which corresponds to aggressivness) for the area that was biopsied, but until they remove the entire lesion, that might change if other areas of it are different from the biopsy. Hope this helps, and good luck to your Mom!  And be sure to tell her about BCO.  There's a whole world of suppport here for you both!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 01:29PM dlb823 wrote: Fearless, I'm not sure why the lump you feel isn't showing up on MRI, but I would strongly suggest that you seek a 2nd opinion at an NCI-designated cancer center.  These are among the leading medical facilities in the country.  If one is within an easy drive for you, I would suggest trying to get a second opinion with a breast surgeon/expert there.  The benefit of going to a place like this is that they see far more women than either general surgeons or ob/gyns (both of whom deal with all sorts of conditions) or even breast surgeons at smaller facilities.  So where a local doc may have seen only one rare case, for example, the breast experts at a major NCI-designated facility probably will have seen a few more, as well as seen more younger women with bc, and hopefully be able to pinpoint what's going on for you. Hopefully, neither you nor NJDevChick has bc, but you both certainly need the peace of mind I think you will get from going to one of these places.   http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html Good luck!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 09:07AM dlb823 wrote: Erica ~  You are definitely doing the right thing by going to a comprehensive breast clinic.  Two suggestions I have are to call today and explain that you have a 4 hour R/T drive, and ask if you need to see a breast surgeon, would it be at the same appointment.  That will give them a heads up to possibly schedule your app't. to allow for a BS to see you, if that isn't already part of their initial routine, which it might be.  The other suggestion I have is to be sure to take someone with you (spouse, other family member, good friend).  The fact is, when we get in those appointments, we're often not totally present due to the stress of it all, and having someone with you to focus on exactly what's being said and even ask obvious questions that may not occur to us because we're not focusing is a huge help. As far as what to ask, just make a list of the things that are on your mind.  I think they will be thorough and guide you through what needs to be covered, but some questions that would be on my mind are  (1) Could the original biopsy have missed something?  (2) Are there any additional tests I should have?  (3)  How can anyone be positive it's not a malignancy, and if it absolutely isn't, what the heck is it, and does it still need to come out?  Basically the same things you're asking...   Please let us know how the app't goes....  Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 08:05AM dlb823 wrote: I'm totally with Beesie in questioning the recommendation for a bi-lateral mastectomy at this point.  Did you have an MRI of both breasts prior to your surgery?  If so, and if the non-affected breast is clear, I do not understand the suggestion for the bi-lateral, unless that's your own thinking on the situation.  If it's from your surgeon, then I would also be curious to know what sorts of reconstruction option(s) have been mentioned to you.  In addition to future peace of mind, which is something only you can assess, I think sometimes women are encouraged to do a bi-lateral mx to ensure symmetry with implants.  However, there are other types of natural reconstruction, such as Diep flap, that may not be done by the plastic surgeons in your immediate area, but which can  achieve excellent symmetry in the case of a unilateral mx.  As you're thinking about your options, I would be sure to read up on the various reconstruction techniques, and be sure you are not being given limited choices.  With a mastectomy, in most cases you lose your nipple and normal nipple sensations.  That's something you need to weigh when you are considering a bi-lateral.    Do you have a copy of your pathology report?  The exact wording in regard to margins and DCIS may give some clue as to the extent of the problem, and if re-excision is a viable choice.  And, by the way, depending on breast size, sometimes a 3rd excision is not totally out of the ordinary to get clear margins.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2015 12:46PM dlb823 wrote: I'm so sorry about your sister's dx. I think sometimes the issue with not wanting tx can be a misconception about what it actually involves -- for example, fearing doctors will "cut off your breasts," when a lumpectomy might be just as do-able. Or if a mastectomy, if necessary, explaining that it's removing diseased breast tissue -- not cutting off anything. Same for chemo. So many people think of someone they knew who went through horrible chemo txs years ago, before there were meds to combat nausea, etc., and maybe a much harsher chemo that was done for a different type of cancer entirely. Or if something like losing her hair is a secret fear, she needs to know there are cold caps available now. Can you at least encourage her to see a top notch medical team (preferably at an NCI-designated cancer center) who can assure her that her bc is treatable and will also paint a realistic picture of what they recommend, so that she truly understands what it is she thinks she wants to reject? Hopefully, you can get her past what is probably still some shock and denial. Unless she has pre-existing health issues, 60 today is considered young in terms of being able to fight early stage bc, including breast reconstruction, if wanted. Assuming you're in the US, here's a list of NCI cancer centers: http://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-role/cancer-cen... Good luck to you both! She's fortunate to have you helping her, and maybe just a bit more time to digest her situation and options will soften her current stance on no tx. ((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 03:59PM - edited Jan 24, 2009 03:59PM by dlb823 Hi, Ellen ~  A few thoughts came to mind when I read your post.  Are you sleeping well?  If you're not getting good, deep sleep, it could be catching up with you.  Also, have you had a CBC recently?  I guess what I'm thinking is, the tiredness may not be related to the RT at all, and maybe some basic blood work would be in order, in case you've become mildly anemic or some such thing.  My other thought is, how is everything else in your life going?  Are you very worried about your bc or other things, because exhaustion can also be a sign of depression.  It's true that it takes many months to regain our previous energy levels, but if you're still totally draggin' and not feeling any improvement, I'd definitely report it to your onc or primary doc and see if they can pinpoint a cause.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2015 08:33AM dlb823 wrote: I learned so much from and was so encouraged by last night's episode. For one, I guess I tend to think of pharmaceutical companies as focused only on their bottom lines -- gouging us and our insurance companies with exhoribant prices, hiding bad trial results, and hawking their products in uber expensive TV ads. But some of the interviews in last night's segment made me believe that their research PhD scientists are as dedicated as medical research folks are to finding answers, and I found that reassuring. All in all I got the impression that there have been a lot more discoveries, a lot more knowledge and a lot more happening than I realized, and understanding now the distinction between immunology (the newest generation of research/treatment) and the more general class of "targeted therapies," really left me feeling quite hopeful.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2015 09:25AM dlb823 wrote: Last night's episode helped me better understand the uniqueness of cancer compared to other diseases, and how far we've come in unraveling a lot of its mystery. I have a new awareness and respect for the brilliant PhD scientists who made the big breakthroughs to get us this far, and pray there are more like them out there who will continue to make much-needed advances. So far, The Emperor of All Maladies has not been at all what I expected, which I guess was more of an expose on why cancer hasn't been cured, and why it's such big business. Maybe that's still coming??? As an aside, it also reaffirmed my very strong belief and commitment in getting chemicals (one of 3 proven causes of some cancers) out of our lives. While we are far from preventing or curing breast cancer, thank G*d we aren't dealing with it in the era of radical mastectomies and bone marrow transplants! WoW, was that ever an eye-opener!

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 07:07PM dlb823 wrote: slcst12 ~ I think it's pretty important to pin down exactly what your surgeon means when he says "the rest" of the nodes.  Under no circumstances should you consent to him taking them all.  If you Google axillary breast nodes, you'll find charts showing the 3 levels of nodes.  IF you have a positive sentinel node, agree to taking 1 or 2 levels at the most.  Taking "the rest" of them, if that means all of them, is old school thinking and opens you up to a huge risk of lymphedema.  I've just skimmed the posts above so don't know if this was covered, but the reason you sometimes see 0/15 or 1/24, for example, is a surgeon doesn't remove them 1 at a time.  They remove a little pad of tissue where they're clustered, so they're never sure how many they're getting until final pathology.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 08:58PM dlb823 wrote: meg, I'm surprised they've scheduled you for an MRI so quickly without mentioning getting insurance approval for it, which can sometimes take a few days.  Many insurance companies balk at paying for an MRI if you do not already have a breast cancer diagnosis.  You may want to double-check with the facility to be sure your insurance company has pre-approved this procedure.  It's not something you'll want to fight with them about later or pay for out of pocket. Other than that, I'm wondering if the radiologists' overly serious attitude prior to an MRI or biopsy might have been because of your age, and the desire to impress upon you the need for follow through?  Otherwise, no matter what your age, her approach sounds a bit unusual, since no one can tell for sure what you're dealing with prior to a biopsy.   Good luck... sorry you're going through this... and please keep us posted.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 09:54PM dlb823 wrote: Sassy ~ Two thoughts come to mind in reading your post.  First, are you getting your testing done at a comprehensive breast center?  Most of the larger hospitals with dedicated breast centers (UCLA, MSK, JH, etc.) have high-risk programs -- which it sounds like you would fit into -- and are very diligent about doing everything necessary to give you peace of mind about your situation.  Getting your routine mammo, etc., at a local facility may not be enough with your strong family history.  I didn't know about these programs until I ended up at UCLA for a second opinion on my bc.  Had I known about their high risk program sooner, I believe they would have caught my bc earlier. Also, as far as the MRI goes, I think you'll find this current active thread very interesting: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/47/topic/727995?page=2#idx_49   It seems as though not covering MRIs or at least initially declining to pay for them is par for many insurance companies, which is outrageous.  But savvy and determined women are figuring out how to fight back and get them covered.  I've just learned that often it can be just a matter of semantics when the request for pre-approval or coverage is made.

Regarding what you should be asking her doctor, are you planning to go to appointments with her?  Otherwise, doctors don't normally share medical information with family members, so you probably won't be able to get any information that way.  The best thing to do is to let your Mom know that you want to support her in whatever she needs, whether that's doing on-line research or accompanying her to her appointments (if that's possible), or just listening to her, and let her set the parameters for what she's comfortable sharing with you and what she needs. Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 11:54PM - edited May 13, 2009 12:33AM by dlb823 I think it's very individual, as are genetics.  For some, stress may not be a factor.  For others, the way they handle stress dumps excess hormones into their systems, or leaves their immune systems depleted and unable to defend against other assaults, like chemical pollutants.    It's kind of like smoking and lung cancer.  Some people smoke their entire lives and never develop it, while others do.  The docs @ UCLA may have changed their thinking on this by now too, but last year, shortly after I was dx'd, the PA there pointedly asked me if there had been a major stress in my life 10 years ago.  Before I could answer, she simply stated, "If there was, I hope it isn't any longer," which made me think that they think/thought (depending on the latest research, I guess) that stress can factor in, at least for some of us. But what this whole question makes me wonder ... if there is a connection, then isn't getting a bc dx and going through tx (a pretty major stress, if you ask me!) itself a psychological event that would impact our future health?        Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2010 09:07PM dlb823 wrote: Polyana, are you drinking lots of water?  You absolutely must do that to flush the chemo out of your system. For the mouth sores, try Biotene mouthwash.  For your next infusion, if you suck on ice chips during the infusion, it will prevent the chemo from damaging the lining of your mouth.  The same is true for your nails -- ice them during your infusion to prevent damage. Since you have mouth sores, any type of fruit or fruit drink will probably irritate them.  Milkshakes and soft, bland foods would be more tolerable. I would report any pain that doesn't go away within a reasonable time to your oncologist.  There's no way anyone can guess at what that's from. Hopefully, this will get your thread started and others will be along to answer your questions on herbs and such.  Hang in there!   Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 10:08AM - edited Apr 13, 2011 10:23AM by dlb823 bettydaviseyez ~ I would suggest trying to learn all you can about bc and your personal bc stats (where you fit into the general picture) before choosing a medical team.  I have always been and still am into natural healing, but one thing that jumped out at me about "alternatives only" treatment when I was trying to decide what to do myself, is that those who offer only alternative protocols often lump all cancers together, and I just think they're so much more complicated than that.   Better known and highly regarded treatment facilities that offers CAM in addition to conventional treatment are the Treatment Centers of America.  I know there's one in Phoenix; there may be one in CA, too, if that's where you're located.  There are also many integrative oncologists who are trained in both CAM & conventional med, so they will use CAM when it's appropriate, but they also understand when conventional txs might be your best bet.  Just some thoughts....   Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2010 06:46AM dlb823 wrote: beau, be sure to tell your oncologist about all of your previoius drug reactions.  If he or she minimizes them in anyway, or if you don't feel you're being taken seriously, I'd suggest having a second opinion appointment with another oncologist.  You just want to be sure that your oncologist really hears your concerns and addresses them to your satisfaction. I don't think any of us or our oncs knows exactly how we'll react to any chemo.  My previous drug reactions were not as bad as yours, but I rarely took any drugs because I absolutely hated the way they made me feel.  Or, at worst, I'd get a rash.  I considered myself overly sensitive to drugs, and, for the most part, used homeopathic stuff when I needed something.  And I did pretty well with TC.  My worst problem turned out to be some latent muscle weakness that seemed pretty bad for several weeks after chemo ended (which I hadn't anticipated), but no problems during my infusions, and nothing within the next few days beyond the typical fatigue and occasional nausea, etc. Best of luck with your treatment.  And be sure to check out both the monthly chemo threads here (e.g. Starting chemo August 2010 or September 2010) and also the TC thread (Anyone on just Taxotere & Cytoxan?).  They'll both be wonderful support for you!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 01:51PM dlb823 wrote: monroe ~ Sorry you're in need of a followup appt. to check out an area of concern, but I'm glad they're taking a closer look and not sending you off to wait due to your age.   At this point, the odds are totally in your favor that it's not bc.  In fact, 80% of biopsies for suspiscious lumps turn out to be B9, and so far they haven't even suggested a biopsy.  So definitely no cause or indication for worry at the moment.  Women get breast lumps all the time.  However, on the outside chance that you do have something going on, 5mm is tiny, so the ideal time to catch it. Having a family history of bc would be more concerning, but surprisingly, the vast majority of women who are diagnosed have no family history.  And while pain can exist, most of us did not have it when we were diagnosed. Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2012 12:36PM - edited Sep 9, 2012 12:37PM by dlb823 kane, I'm so sorry you're going through what you are.  I'm not a doctor, so won't second guess your onc's recommendations.  But I know that when some women are allergic to Taxotere, it's not to the Taxane itself that's causing it, but the additional things in Taxotere. One solution can be Abraxane, which is basically Taxotere without added ingredients.  It's considerably more expensive than Taxotere (like 3x as expensive), so insurance companies normally only okay it in cases like yours (severe allergy to Taxotere, etc.). The other thing I want to ask is if your onc is truly an expert in TNBC?  I know there's plenty of information available to oncs, but if I was in your situation, I think I would want someone who is really on the front lines -- like someone who is either doing TNBC research, or at least affiliated with a medical institution that is.  I just personally feel that there's both a lag time in getting the newest info' disseminated to oncs, as well as a lack of expertise if an onc doesn't deal with TNBC on a regular basis.  And since you've run into such a serious issue and question about what to do, I would want to be sure you're dealing with a top TNBC expert who has run into this before and is drawing on firsthand experience and knowledge.  If that's who you're with, great!  If not, I think a 2nd or 3rd opinion is in order -- just to be sure you're going down the right path and not wasting time or risking continuing allergic reactions.     (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: May 10, 2015 08:27PM - edited May 10, 2015 08:31PM by dlb823 windingshores, up until recently, the research showed that there was no difference in outcome for those who waited 6, 9 and 12 weeks following their last surgery to start chemo. However, very recent research concluded that there is a difference in outcome based on subsets. In other words, the more advanced your dx is, the more important it is to start chemo as soon as possible. Since there was some doubt about whether or not you even needed chemo, it sounds like you may fall into the less advanced subset. If I can find a link to that research for you, I'll stop back and give you a link. (((Hugs))), Deanna Here you go... http://www.ascopost.com/issues/march-15,-2014/sidebar-impact-of-delayed-initiation-of-adjuvant-chemotherapy-for-breast-cancer-varies-by-tumor-subtype.aspx

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 12:55PM dlb823 wrote: Gma, I have truncal LE that involves mostly my left (mx) side, and my breast, back and upper arm to a lesser degree.  The #1 thing that helps me is wearing only sports bras (no more wires) with wide band side compression.  Also, not getting overheated (no hot baths, hot tubs, overheated exercising) is important, as any of those things can set off a painful flair, as can stressing my upper left side with weights, which I do, but very carefully.  Self massage also helps a lot when it happens, but it's definitely better to prevent it.  I've also noticed that my most recent flares have been getting worse (I'm 4 years post mx), and I'm concerned that if they continue to worsen or become more frequent, the LE could eventually involve my lower arm.  So keeping it under control is a high priority.  At their worst, my flares literally feel like someone is stabbing me in the side with broken glass.     It's good that you're aware of the problem and hopefully can keep it to a minimum.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 09:34PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Brian ~  Sorry about your wife's dx, but I think it's great that you're doing some research for her.  Based on my own experience, I would strongly recommend checking out an NCI-designated hospital.  When I was dx'd, I started out with a well-respected surgeon at a fine local hospital with a sizeable cancer center.  My sister who is in cancer research and is also a bc survivor kept telling me that I would be better off at an NCI-designated hospital because they see far more bc than most local hospitals and surgeons -- even ones with "Breast Center" on the building.  Well, long story short -- she was right.  After a lumpectomy and resulting pathology that had some things in it that just didn't add up, I decided to go to UCLA for a second opinion.  They discovered additional lesions in the same breast (missed by the first surgeon), and I ended up needing a mastectomy.  They also advised a totally different chemo regimen than had been suggested by the well-respected local oncologist. Some women do not like the larger teaching universities and prefer to get treatment locally, especially if there is a breast center at their local hospital.  That was my preference in the beginning, too.  However, I found I got more thorough screening and also had better reconstruction options at the larger facility than I'd had locally. Here's a list of NCI-designated cancer centers if you're interested: http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html  Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 11:23AM dlb823 wrote: I heard something interesting on XM "Doctor Radio" yesterday, that I thought might be worth passing along.  They were saying that our bodies cannot absorb more than 2,000 IU's at a time, and that if you take more than that, you need to break it into 2,000 IU doses.  I know I've seen comments here on BCO from women taking extremely high doses (as high as 50,000/day), and still not being able to get their levels into the desireable range, so I thought I'd just pass this along.  They were also saying that sunscreens are a major culprit because even in sunny CA & FL it's possible to be deficient in D.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2012 07:06PM dlb823 wrote: (((neugirl))) ~ As rough as it is, what you're going through is totally normal and something we each need to work through for ourselves.  As the other ladies have said, you have extremely favorable stats, but I know that doesn't make it any easier right now.  But I just wanted to tell you that your observation is correct -- most women leave BCO around the time they finish up their tx, probably as a way of putting it behind them, which I'm sure you will too when you're ready.  I was very fortunate when I was dx'd to have a number of relatives, friends and acquaintances who are 10+ year survivors, but there were still some rough days when I asked the same questions you're asking now. If you haven't already, you might want to check out this website:  cancer.lifemath.net/  And keep in mind that all the survival stats you see today are based on txs that were given 5, 10 and more years ago, so not even up-to-date in terms of the improved outcomes now that we have with Oncotype-DX testing, Herceptin for Her2+ bc, and more targeted chemos.    (((Hugs)))  Deanna
Posts.Title: Diagnosis very hard to handle neugirl Appetite4life

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 10:34PM dlb823 wrote: The steroids they give as pre-treatment definitely increases your appetite, and the food aversions may have you craving bland, childhood favorites.  Mine was grilled cheese.  Also, it's imperative that you drink a lot of water, to flush out the chemo, and the steroids will cause your body to retain some of it.  I gained about 7 pounds, as did some other gals in my August 08 chemo group.  But once I started walking and exercising again, they came off.  Just remember -- like the chemo, any weight change is temporary, and not that big a deal, unless you are already extremely thin and concerned about possibly losing too much.  Once you're done with chemo and go back to eating normally, your weight should self-adjust within a few weeks. Here's hoping for a LOW LOW LOW Oncotype score for you!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2016 09:22PM dlb823 wrote: I'm so sorry about your diagnosis, Antonietta, but glad you've found us! What treatment are you on, and what specific questions do you have? The first few months are especially hard -- just trying to wrap your head around a Stage IV diagnosis. But the vast majority of us get on top of things with the great meds available these days and soon realize that life goes on -- even with advanced breast cancer. In addition to the suggestions above, I would say, be sure you're on the best treatment plan by at least checking in with a major medical center (if you're not already being treated at one) for a second opinion. Centers like the ones in a list I'll link here see the most metastatic breast cancer and actually have better survival stats than smaller, local facilities. It's always a good idea to check in with the one closest to you, just to be sure you're on the right treatment path. http://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-role/cancer-cen... I'm also going to give you a couple of links to other thread here I think you'd enjoy. Tips For Fighting The Dark Clouds https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topics/... LIfe Does Not End With A Stage IV Diagnosis (Really) https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topics/... Let us know how else we can help you! (((Hugs))) Deanna

Hopefully others with young children will be along to weigh in on your concerns.  (((Hugs)))  Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2013 08:17PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Tony ~ I'm so sorry about your Mom's diagnosis, but it sounds like she and you are on the right track as far as finding a top notch medical team, and I know she's very grateful to have your hands-on support. I live near Palm Springs, and I chose UCLA for most of my care after a rocky start with local docs who have excellent reputations in general. So, personally, I would choose the NCI-designated facility, City of Hope. Also, I have known two local women through BCO who used City of Hope, and both were thrilled with their care, including reconstruction. Other than that, I just personally believe that NCI-designated hospitals are uniquely thorough when it comes to treating bc -- partly because they see more of it than even larger regional hospitals, and partly because they're the docs who are involved in research, so are truly up on the leading edge treatment options. As far as scans, unless her medical team suspects a problem, a scan will only expose her to unnecessary radiation. And I'm going to venture an educated guess that pain in the calf and/or knees is probably arthritis, as it's not a usual site for bc to show up. Perhaps a simple x-ray would show typical age-related deterioration and allay her fears and yours. Let us know how else we can help you and your Mom. (((Hugs))) to you both! Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 10:42PM dlb823 wrote: Karen ~  When we are first diagnosed, all we want to do is get rid of the bc.  But not all doctors have the same degree of experience or expertise with breast cancer, and this is one situation where you want all the expertise you can get, to be sure you get wise counsel and adequate treatment without being overtreated, as well as having access to state of the art reconstruction if you decide on a mast or a bi-lateral mast.  I was very much like you, in that I could schedule what I thought was excellent treatment quickly locally with doctors who seemed to know what they were talking about.  But when my first surgery didn't get all the bc, I was very glad that I ended up at UCLA for a second opinion because they found some things that had been overlooked by my local surgeon, and they also offered advanced reconstruction options.  (I had a Diep)  I would strongly encourage you to take the time to have the second opinion at Scripps.  They're top notch and will give you excellent guidance. You can always take the information you get there back to your doctor(s) in Idaho and have your surgery there if you decide that's best.  Taking another week or two at this point in your diagnosis really isn't delaying your treatment -- it's giving you time to understand your options and think them through without being rushed, as well as getting a valuable second opinion.     Deanna

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 08:21PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, MED ~  I just read your first post to try to get a better understanding of your situation, and what struck me as slightly odd is that your tumor was Grade 1 and small (less than a cm) -- but had already gone to a lymph node.  The Grade 1 may be a big reason why your OncotypeDX came back relatively low.  But for an unaggressive bc, it was aggressive enough to travel to a node.  I think if I was in your position, I would get a second and maybe even a third opinion -- just to be sure that nothing is missed, and that whatever decision you make regarding chemo is one that will give you peace of mind.   As Marin pointed out, not all docs think alike on any given situation, and the fact that you have a lack of complete comfort with the current recommendation is all the more reason for a 2nd opinion.  Please keep us posted on your situation ~   Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 09:09PM dlb823 wrote: gonnabstrong ~  I think it's natural for the diagnosing surgeon to assume that he/she will do your surgery.  But all you need to do is tell your surgeon that you would like to get a second opinion before proceeding with surgery.  No further explanation is necessary.  Ask for copies of all of your tests (the actual films, etc., which the facility that did them will put on a CD for you), written test reports, and reports for any procedures you've had.  It's your right to have copies, which you should have in your files anyway. A reputable surgeon will not be the least bit offended by your wanting a second opinion, and many will encourage you to do that.  If a surgeon balks at this proposal or says anything to make you feel uncomfortable, I think that's a huge red flag, and that they are afraid you will go elsewhere when you start making comparisons.  A good surgeon will not feel threatened that you want a second opinion, so it will be interesting to see how your current surgeon reacts. From my personal experience with a second opinion, I am very keen on the NCI-designated cancer centers.  If you are anywhere near one, you might want to consider getting your second opinion there: http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html Good luck, and let us know how your second opinion appointment goes ~   Deanna
Posts.Title: How to handle the Doctor Situation gonnabstrong dlb823

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 12:33PM dlb823 wrote: gonnabstrong ~  Absolutely find a breast surgeon -- one who dedicates 100% of his/her time to conditions and surgeries of the breast.  General surgeons have to keep up on research and the latest techniques for many other surgeries -- appendix, melanoma, gall bladder.  There's just no way they can be as experienced when it comes to the subtle techniques and differences between bc patients.  Also, breast surgeons at comprehensive cancer facilities normally have plastic surgeons, oncologists and rad oncs on staff.  Depending upon which of these you may need, it's great when they're all part of a team that works together on only bc and is in constant communication re. their patients.    Deanna
Posts.Title: How to handle the Doctor Situation gonnabstrong dlb823

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 09:34AM dlb823 wrote: Shirlene, there are many other skin conditions that can cause rashes and itching.  Have you seen a dermatologist yet?  That might be your first step, to see if it resolves quickly with a topical RX. The symptoms you're describing can also be associated with a rare but aggressive form of breast cancer called Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC).  I'm almost reluctant to tell you this because I don't want you to Google it and start panicking, because it is pretty rare and not easy to self-diagnosis.  However, because it's rare, some primary doctors and OB/GYNs have been known not to recognize its earliest symptoms, which delays diagnosis.  So what I would suggest you do is make an appointment with a Breast Surgeon/Expert (someone who deals only in matters of the breast) and ask specifically about IBC, which can be ruled out with a skin biopsy. If you need to know where to find a qualified breast surgeon, an NCI-designated cancer center is always a wise choice if there's one near you.  Here's a list: http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html Hope this helps!  Good luck, and be sure to let us know what you find out.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 10:09AM dlb823 wrote: Mom, can you tell us more about your biopsy?  Was it done at a major facility?  How big a lesion are we talking about?  Was it given a bi-rads rating prior to the biopsy?   Another thing you might consider doing, since it looks like you lost your Mom to bc, is see if you qualify for a High Risk Program at one of the major university hospitals like those listed here: cancercenters.cancer.gov/cance...  They will review your records and offer any additional screening they think is appropriate, which should ease your mind.  Then, if they determine you actually are at higher risk than most women for any reason, they will watch you more closely while also teaching you lifestyle modifications that can cut your risk. I know you would probably prefer to forget about it altogether, but if you're going to continue to worry, you might as well base it on the most accurate risk assessment information possible from the top experts in bc.   Just a thought ...    Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 01:13PM dlb823 wrote: Anxiousmama ~  You definitely want to get those tests done first, as the information they disclose will impact treatment decisions, including surgery.  I know, once you're diagnosed, you just want the bc out ASAP.  But you have to realize that it's taken quite a few years to grow large enough to where it could be seen on imaging, so it's not going to change that much in another 4 or 6 weeks, even though we may feel like it is.  Best to get a full picture of what they're dealing with before having surgery.  That didn't happen to me.  It all worked out for the best, but it meant a second surgery, which is the last thing you want to do if you can avoid it.   Sorry you've found yourself here, but I hope the information and support you get will make this journey easier for you, as it has for all of us  ~   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2011 01:14PM - edited Jun 27, 2011 01:36PM by dlb823 whitty ~ Not sure how I missed the Her2+ on your dx line (nor did you mention Herceptin), but I just wanted to pop back and agree with everything Lago's told you.  Sorry I didn't realize you're Her2+, but as Lago said, Her2+ bc is nothing to mess around with.  The need for Herceptin should absolutely trump every other thing running through your head.   If you haven't seen it, there's a made for TV movie called Living Proof, with Harry Connick, Jr. playing Dr. Dennis Slamon, the creator of Herceptin.  I was doing chemo when it came out, and I cried all the way through it.  But it so clearly drives home how deadly Her2+ bc was pre-Herceptin, and what a miracle drug it is for those with Her2+ bc.  It you can get ahold of the film (maybe on Youtube?), I highly recommend it.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2011 10:58AM dlb823 wrote: ccjj, I had a really similar situation -- 1 positive node (it had been declared clear in the OR, but path found it was positive with extracapsular extension), and an "unspecified" 1mm margin on a tiny piece of trimmed tissue that hadn't been inked (my BS took it at the last moment just to smooth an area for my PS), and a tiny 1mm ILC lesion that hadn't shown up on MRI turned up in it.  (One more reason I am sooooo keen on NCI-designated cancer centers, b'cuz I feel my BSs experience and instinct to trim that bit of tissue was HUGE!)   Anyway, I was so against RT, I consulted with 2 different rad oncs and even made one of them get a 3rd opinion from a renown expert at his institution.  They all thought RT would benefit me for the two reasons outlined above, although my local onc didn't think it was necessary.  His rationale was that if I had a local recurrence, we could deal with it.  But his just thinking there was a possibility that could happen didn't give me peace of mind, nor did I want to go through any of what I'd just been through again.  My final decision, after finding a local rad onc I really liked who was able to calm a lot of my specific concerns (i.e. lymphedema and heart & lung damage) was to go ahead and do rads. And I'm very glad I did.  I feel I had a couple of oddities about my path that just made it the prudent thing to do, and I don't regret my decision for one moment.  But I think it's a decision we each have to make based on those individual path issues, and not be persuaded too much by what anyone else with similar stats may have done, although it's good to hear why they made their decision.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2011 12:14PM dlb823 wrote: whitty, did you have the Oncotype-DX test?   Although it's hard for any of us to weigh in on whether or not you're doing the right thing by doing chemo, my first impression is that with a 3cm tumor that was Grade 3 (aggresive) -- and without knowing anything else about you or your diagnosis -- chemo sounds like an entirely wise and appropriate decision, and the one I would have made from my very holistic/natural point of view. And what I and many others have done is to use all sorts of complementary protocols to support our bodies during chemo and help them rebuild following it. As far as chemo causing secondary cancers, for the most part, that risk pertains to Adriamycin, which you're not getting, and which is something like a 1-2% risk.  It also pertains to Tamoxifen, but, as far as I know, not to the chemo regimen you're on. Yes, chemo is potent and there can be unpleasant side effects.  But a recurrence of bc, especially a distant recurrence in an organ, is far more concerning to most of us. Dr. Bryznski's approx. 25% success rate seems to be with patients for whom traditional treatment offered no hope.  Unfortunately (and I may be wrong here), I don't believe there are stats re. his treatment for early stage breast cancer, although his treatment certainly sounds viable.  And I don't believe it would be covered by any medical insurance, so cost would be a big concern for most of us.  Two things that helped me come around to doing chemo (which I was very against at first) were the number of healthy, happy survivors who came forward to tell me they'd gone through bc, often 10 or more years ago, and had chemo (which, by the way, is much improved since then); and also the question... How would I feel if it ever came back and I hadn't done chemo? I agree there's a huge, self-perpetuating cancer industry out there, and no doubt some people are probably over treated.  That's one reason it's extremely important to find doctors you trust who will let you be involved in decisions about your treatment.  But the bottom line is, early stage bc is largely "cureable" (or possible to put into NED, hopefully forever) with appropriate conventional medicine, and the data for doing strictly alternatives just isn't as strong, IMO.  Hope these random thoughts are some help to you ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 02:05PM dlb823 wrote: in_cognito ~  I'm so sorry that you're joining the club that none of us ever wanted to be in, but I'm glad you found BCO.  We've all been where you are -- newly diagnosed, terrified, and on a roller-coaster of emotions -- and we all remember what a scary place it was.  It honestly gets better once you know the full picture, have a game plan in place, and start treatment.  Please let us know if there's anything we can do to help you until you get more information.  If you haven't already planned to, be sure to take someone with you to those appts. next week.  You'll find once a doctor says "breast cancer," our minds just can't stay in the present and focus.  Having someone with you to ask questions and remember what's said can be extremely helpful.  And we'll be here when you need us.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 10:37AM dlb823 wrote: timerdog, I don't like the way your BF is acting or treating you either, but so far (and it's really hard to understand a relationship from just a few paragraphs), I'm not sure he's beyond all hope.  It's true that the annoyances you've described sound like they're based on deep insecurities.  But I'm wondering if you and he could honestly talk about some of these things, if he might realize how unhelpful and self-centered his comments are.  It sounds like it's about money and influence (like the personal doctor story) to him, but I doubt if he realizes how his comments are coming across to others.  If you truly have strong feelings for him, I would think maybe a heart-to-heart conversation and getting all of this out in the open would help you know if this relationship is worth salvaging, or if he's truly as shallow, self-centered and uncommited as some of his comments are.  And I would absolutely include your financial worries.  If he's so selfish that can't commit to helping you now, while at the same time dropping $2K on entertainment, I would RUN the other way and thank heaven you found out BEFORE you moved in with or married him.  But he may not be aware of your fears about not being able to work or other financial concerns. If you can possibly clear the air and get on a more authentic track with him, then I wanted to suggest a book that might help.  It's called the Breast Cancer Husband, by Marc Silver.  Here's a link:  http://www.breastcancerhusband.com/   It's written from a guy's point of view, and although I didn't read it, I've only heard rave reviews from those who have.  Most of us find out that a crisis like this tends to bring out what's already there in people.  But unless your gut is already telling you otherwise, I would cut him a bit of slack for not knowing how to act right now, and at least let him know how the incidents you've shared here are making you feel, then let him adjust if he wants to.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 10:49PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, smend13 ~  You know, it's really impossible to compare lumps with one another.  We're all so individual.  Two women might have lumps that feel similar, yet they could be caused by very different things.  The only way to diagnosis a lump is to have it biopsied.  And, if it eases your mind, 80% of breast biopsies turn out to be benign.  So try not to get way ahead of yourself and panic at this point.  Your lumps could be several things other than bc.  Just be determined, as you are, to find out what they are. The way you were treated by the radiologist in November sounds totally inappropriate, and I'm glad to hear that you're being sent to a breast surgeon this time for evaluation.  If you are not happy with that doctor, get a second opinion.  Do not let any doctor bully you if you feel you have not been thoroughly checked out, or if you don't totally understand why they are calling something benign.  Please let us know what happens when you see the surgeon ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 10:41AM dlb823 wrote: Schie, do you start just Taxotere on Thursday?  AC+T is a fairly common chemo protocol, but I'm not familiar with AC+TC (both Taxotere and Cytoxin) following AC.  I'm asking b'cuz there's probably a lengthy thread within the Chemotherapy Forum for those who are on AC+T, discussing it. I had TC (no A), and one of the most important things about Taxotere is that you need to ice your fingernails either before & after or during the infusion, to prevent nail damage.  Some chemo facilities supply ice mitts made by the makers of Taxotere.  If yours does not (mine didn't), ask ahead if they can provide ice packs.  If not, take ice or even a bag of frozen veggies (like peas) with you to hold against your nails to keep them cold and cut down on the drug circulating to them.   PM me if you have questions or need more info, but this will save you from damage to your nail beds. Good luck!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 04:18PM dlb823 wrote: drewmom, I don't quite understand the need for an MRI with Birads 2 & 3, but I think you're fortunate that you managed to get one.  From what you've described, it doesn't sound like anything unusual is going on, but having a baseline MRI for future comparisons sounds like a very good thing. As far as worrying about the results, I know it's hard not to, but the bottom line is, IF there is anything concerning there (which is doesn't sound like there is), it's far better to find out as early as possible than to wait and give it time to grow and become more difficult to treat.  Not knowing is never a positive, and, believe me, some of the saddest stories amongst us here on BCO involve missed opportunities for early detection.  So just try to keep busy until you get the results.  Did they tell you when they'd have those?    Deanna  (and I'm praying for totally B9 results for you)

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 08:30PM dlb823 wrote: bcricket, so glad you were able to pick up a copy of your pathology report.  6mm is a very small area of infiltrating (invasive) ductal (the most common type) bc -- like less than 1/4 of an inch, I believe.  So that's very good news!  The other scores have to do with aggressiveness, and it sounds like yours is low grade or Grade 1 -- the least aggressive grade, which is more good news!  And hopefully your MRI will also have good news for you!  Please keep us posted!   Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 10:42PM dlb823 wrote: Duff, IBC is very rare.  However, because it's rare, it's frequently misdiagnosed, which wastes valuable time in getting the proper diagnosis and treatment.  For that reason, I agree with Patti that you need to seek out a breast specialist to rule it out.  Unfortunately, many PCPs and OB/GYNs rarely (if ever) see it.  For your own peace of mind, a breast surgeon/specialist is the type of doctor you need to see.  If your doctor wants to treat it with an antibiotic or cream, you might try that -- but if it doesn't work within a few days, insist on the referral.  The only way to rule IBC in or out is a skin biopsy, sometimes referred to as a punch test. Hopefully, there's another, totally benign, explanation for the symptoms you're describing.  But trust your gut to push for an answer that makes sense to you.  And let us know what happens.  I'll be hoping whatever it is isn't bc!!!    (((Hugs)))  Deanna

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 08:33PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Reddawn ~  I'm really sorry about your diagnosis.  If you can get a copy of your pathology report prior to your next meeting with your surgeon, that would be helpful, as you would have a much better understanding of what you're dealing with  -- small tumor, large tumor, more than one lesion, what kind of bc (there are different kinds) -- all of which will factor into his recommendation and your decision about surgery.  We can help you decipher it, if needed. I'm glad that you're having an MRI.  That's done to find out of there's anything going on besides what they already know about. Be sure to take someone with you to your appointments.  You may not need someone there for the MRI, but definitely to any appt. where your diagnosis and recommended treatment will be discussed.  It's totally normal to kind of zone out from the stress of it all, and having someone with you will ensure that someone will hear everything and be able to fill in the gaps for you later.   (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2014 11:55AM dlb823 wrote: pugs, I'm also sorry to welcome you, but know you'll find great support and information here. I'm also highly in favor of second opinions -- just b'cuz I've learned that not all oncologists have the same experience or think alike, so it's really good to get treatment recommendations from more than one -- just so that you can compare what you're being told and hopefully pick the one who seems the most experienced situations like yours. I'm also curious if they've suggested a biopsy.  Our lungs accumulate all sorts of artifacts over the years, especially if you've ever had pneumonia or other respiratory infection, and stories of suspected lung mets that turn out to be something benign are not uncommon.  Learning you're Stage IV is a huge shock, but with the expertise of a positive, experienced breast cancer oncologist and some luck, you might be surprised at how well you can adjust to living with Stage IV -- and hopefully for a very long time.    (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2014 12:18PM dlb823 wrote: Sarah, as concerning and scary as a Bi-Rads 5 designation can be, there is absolutely no way short of a biopsy to tell if what the radiologist thinks could be a potentially malignant lesion, is in fact breast cancer. Keep in mind that Bi-Rads ratings can be somewhat subjective, so that's the first bit of hope -- that this particular radiologist is being overly cautious. Then, I believe even a Bi-Rads 5 rating has about a 5% chance of turning out not to be something other than bc. http://breastcancer.about.com/od/diagnosis/a/birad... I also may be reaching here a bit, but "irregularly marginated" doesn't sound quite as concerning to me as "spiculated," (in other words, appearing like a spider), which to me has always been the most concerning wording, since that's how mine was initially described. Let's just hope and pray that you're in that 5% margin! I've actually seen quite of those turn up here. (((Hugs))), and I'll be thinking about you tomorrow. Please keep us posted. Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 04:18PM dlb823 wrote: Sorry if I missed it above, but did you mention if your Mom had a lumpectomy or a mastectomy?  Also, do you have a copy of her pathology report?  If so, what's the Ki-67 proliferation factor?  That's one of the prognosticators they relied on prior to the Oncotype-DX -- not that it's a perfect one, but something under 20% is better re. recurrence risk than something a lot higher. I think one of the questions a lot of us ask ourselves about chemo -- especially if it's left up to us -- is, if I don't do chemo and it ever comes back, how would I feel?  Would I kick myself for not having done more? The other random thought I have for you is, there are a wide range of chemos.  CMF, for example, is sometimes referred to as a lighter chemo, and might be something to ask her onc about.  Sorry you're going through this.  Waiting to find out if you or someone you love needs chemo or not has got to be one of the worst times ever.   (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 09:21PM dlb823 wrote: jabal, if I was in your situation, I would want an MRI.  And some BSs or oncs do order additional screening prior to tx, but it probably depends on each patient's situation. I had a PetScan, for example, prior to starting chemo, because, as my onc said, if bc had shown up elsewhere, the game plan would have changed.  But my bc turned out to be more complex than originally believed, and there was a delay in figuring that out, having my second surgery, and starting chemo.  So a scan was probably a reasonable recommendation.  OTOH, if you have a Grade 1 bc, for example, the radiation from a scan might outweigh the very small potential that it would show anything concerning.  But MRIs don't use radiation, so I would at least ask  about having one for the added peace of mind, especially since you had a positive node with a very small lesion and a Grade 1 bc.   As far as the hormone issue, I would start by having your estrogen levels tested, to see where you are.  I hesitate to recommend my regimen to others because I do a lot of stuff with diet, supplements and exercise that may or may appeal to or work for someone else.  I also had chemo, which you did not, and I'm under the impression that the Oncotype-DX score assumes a woman will do Tamox or an A/I.  One thing you might consider doing is at least trying an A/I.  Some women do surprisingly well with them, and you could be one of them.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2017 05:45PM dlb823 wrote: Gina, I would strongly recommend a second opinion at an NCI-designated cancer center. These are the places that see the most breast (and other) cancer(s), so will have the most experience with women who fall into a similar subset as your Mom. And I could be totally wrong, but I strongly suspect they will recommend TC x 4 over a regimen containing Adriamycin, even for a very youthful 60 year old, due to some of the risks that rightfully concern your Mom. https://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-role/cancer-ce... The recommendation for Tamoxifen vs. an A/I doesn't sound quite right to me either, and as Elalne pointed out above, an A/I can actually be more powerful than chemo, so is a very important component to get right in her total treatment. Absolutely time for a second opinion, which hopefully will also dispel much of the fear and sadness your Mom is dealing with, when she hears from docs whose recommendations she trusts more than perhaps what she's heard so far. (((Hugs))) to you both. Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 09:43PM dlb823 wrote: ML, I did the survey, and I was actually pleased to be asked if I thought prevention is an important message, because I think it is.  Of course preventive measures will never fully protect us from a disease that has so much genetics involved anymore than annual mammograms will prevent us from getting bc.  So it's important that the benefits are not overstated.  But why not take advantage of every proven cancer fighting strategy in the hopes they will help prevent a future cancer dx?    Here's a recent article on the topic:  http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/09... And here are some more suggestions:  http://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-10654/11-ways-to-k... If only I'd truly understood the risks of HRT years ago, I might not be here now.     Deanna

Posts.Content: May 5, 2015 03:49PM dlb823 wrote: starbright, I'm glad to hear you're thinking of going for a second opinion because there probably are several viable options to approach what may or may not be going on, and there isn't necessarily a "right" or "best" one -- just hopefully a "better" one b'cuz it's based on the most first-hand experience with patients in situations similar to yours. For what it's worth, my UCLA onc recently told me that in spite of somewhat higher TMs (and like you, mine have always been spot on), she would not look at changing my current tx unless they doubled because, according to her, some fluctuation is normal. Without that input, I'm pretty sure my local onc may have wanted to change my current tx. If I was in your situation, I would proceed with caution. Take your time gathering as much input as you can. See at least one more onc -- maybe more. Get opinions from two rad oncs if you possibly can, because the more information you glean from talking to each of them, the more you will be able to make an informed choice. Personally, I would keep rads available for a situation where your future mobility could be impacted and/or you have pain that isn't well-managed with meds. And I'm not sure I'd switch meds just yet either based on a minimal rise in TMs and pain you describe as minimal to none. But that's my way of looking at it, and may not be right for you. That's why I think talking to more than one onc may help you figure out the best course of tx for you.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2013 11:26AM - edited Feb 3, 2013 11:28AM by dlb823 jabal, I also have very sensitive skin, and I used Emu Oil and continue to sing its praises.  I actually started with 100% aloe vera gel, as recommended by my rad onc, then moved on to something she had free samples of in her office.  Then one day in the rads changing area I was talking to another bc patient who was using and loved Emu Oil, and I found out that b'cuz she was extremely fair skinned (I'm olive), our rad onc had started her on the Emu Oil.  So I switched to that, and neither of us had any problems. I can add that the first bottle of Emu Oil I bought, which was the least expensive one on the shelf at my natural foods market, actually felt a bit gritty, which I didn't like.  So I bought a more expensive brand at an organic farmer's market that was "ultra refined," and it was much nicer. I still use it today as an occasional vaginal lubricant, and it works great for that, too.      Deanna PS ~ I just applied it immediately after my 7:00 a.m. tx, and then again in the evening.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 01:05PM dlb823 wrote: One thing I try to do now when I have conflicting feelings about things like this, is ask myself if my negativity is coming from my heart or my head -- and you can feel the difference if you pay attention.  If the negative reaction is in my head, then it's probably more inconvenience than anything.  Example:  Your first thought is about making beds and the meal prep.  Solution:  Tell them ahead of time, you are not up to making beds, extra laundry or cooking.  If they want to come, they'll need to pitch in and do this for themselves and for you.  But if that "oh, no" feeling is coming from your heart (and it's quite obvious when it is), well that's the time to say, "No, I'm sorry.  As much as I want to see you, it just isn't going to work for me right now," -- and know you'll have no regrets about your choice.  In fact, you will probably feel happy and empowered that you have put yourself first when this is what your heart was telling you.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2017 09:24PM dlb823 wrote: Gina, icing fingernails and toenails is to protect them from what can be negative effects of chemo, including lifting and even nail loss. Like hair, nails are fast growing cells and prone to chemo damage. Something as simple as a bag or two of frozen peas works great, and doesn't melt the way ice does. Just hold them on nails to cut down on chemo circulating where it isn't needed anyway. And so happy to hear your positive news about a more accommodating onc! Hope all goes smoothly! If you haven't yet, you or your Mom may want to join the BCO thread for those starting chemo this month. It's helpful to compare notes on SEs, etc, and feel supported by others dealing with the same initial fears and concerns.

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 06:48PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Justina ~ I haven't read the sticky notes for chemo in a long time, but I can tell you a couple of things from experience.  First, the fear of chemo is far worse than the actual experience.  Most of us did just fine with it, and you will, too! Sucking on ice chips will help protect the lining of your mouth from mouth sores.  Another really good product to have on-hand is Biotene Mouthwash, which you can get at most drugstores, Target, etc.  While you're picking that up, if you're going to be getting Neulasta to keep up your white blood cell count, many of us used Claritin (the allergy med) to alleviate some bone pain the Neulasta can cause.  If you search Claritin (box to upper right), you'll find threads about it. The other thing I would highly recommend is icing your nails to prevent nail damage from Taxotere.  Some infusion centers actually have ice mitts made by Taxotere's manufacturer, so be sure to ask if yours does.  If it doesn't, ask if they can provide ice.  If not, just bring your own or even a bag of well frozen veggies (like peas), which is what I did.  (They don't liquify and run all over like ice does.)  Holding this on your nails (both fingers & toes) to keep them cold during your infusion will really help prevent nail damage.  I haven't kept up with it, but there's a thread here on Penguin Cold Caps, which some women use to prevent hair loss.  They weren't as popular when I did TC in 2008, but something you might want to check into. One other thing I did that helped me overcome a lot of my fear of chemo was a guided imagery CD (download) by BellaRuth Naperstek.  You can find out about it here:  www.healthjourneys.com Hope this helps, and feel free to PM me if you have other questions.   (((Hugs)))  Deanna
