Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 09:24AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, LilHobbit... Yes, definitely consult another doctor who will check it out more thoroughly.  The obgyn you saw could be 100% right.  But if he is, it's a lucky guess, probably based on the incorrect assumption that you're too young to have bc -- although the odds are certainly in your favor that it's not bc at your age.  But there are many young women on these boards, including a 26-year old in our August 08 chemo group.  So, age alone is not a reason to rule out a more in-depth look.  It concerns me that the doc you saw didn't feel what you feel yet still dismissed you.  I would see your PCP and ask for a referral to a breast center for a mammogram.  There is absolutely no reason to be alarmed.  Most lumps are not bc.  Many can be ruled out via mammogram and/or ultrasound, and of those that look suspicious enough to  biopsy, 80% turn out to be benign.  But for your own peace of mind, do follow up on what you know is there. And please let us know how you do.   Deanna
Posts.Title: Found Lump & not happy with Dr's Answer LilHobbit LilHobbit

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 02:16PM dlb823 wrote: By asking questions here and deciding on a game plan, you are taking control, and that should give you comfort.  Your insurance should be the only factor to consider in whether or not you go through your PCP or make an appointment directly.  Some insurance coverage requires a doctor's referral to a specialist vs. self referral.  If you won't know which kind you have, you can call the 800 number on your insurance card and ask them if you need a referral for a breast exam. As far as waiting, 2 weeks shouldn't make a difference.  However, what's important is your peace of mind.  It sounds like an appointment now would greatly ease the stress you're going through, and if your insurance will cover it, why wait?  It's totally normal for women to find lumps and get them checked out.   What you're doing is perfectly within reason, and there's no sense in waiting or going through your PCP if you don't have to.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 04:59PM dlb823 wrote: lynda ~ So sorry about your diagnosis, but I'm glad you've found us, and hope we can make things a little easier for you. With your history, I think it's really important that you go to a comprehensive cancer center like the NCI-designated ones listed here:   http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html   Because of the number of breast cancer patients they treat, they will have experience with situations like yours, as well as a true team approach, including specialists in addition to breast surgeons and oncologists with whom those doctors can consult re. how your previous kidney & pancreas conditions could influence necessary treatment decisions.  They'll all be under the same roof, and will all have on-line access to your file, which will be important with your past history.  We're all scared -- terrified -- when we're first diagnoised.  But finding a medical team in whom you have 100% confidence is your first step, and will make a world of difference, and should be your immediate focus.  Please keep us posted, and let us know how else we can help you ~  (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2011 10:04AM dlb823 wrote: slinky, just a suggestion... maybe write a complaint letter (to get it off your chest and in writing while everything is still very fresh in your mind), but don't mail it until you find a new OB/GYN and have had at least one app't. with him/her.  Unfortunately, word of any serious complaint or suggestion of a legal action will travel fast within medical circles where you live, and I've heard of docs more or less blackballing patients, especially if they think you could be a trouble-maker.  I would write the letter -- set it aside for a bit -- take care of finding another doc -- then, when a little time has passed, decide to whom you really need to send your letter.  In the mean time, you might be able to figure out if this is the doc's first real problem like this, or if there have been others, and also how much of this was really the fault of his employee for not listening to you and accurately relaying your situation to him.  But for your own ability to use any area doctor you want to in the future, I'd proceed slowly with any formal complaint, just to be sure you have the perspective of a bit of time, as well as access to local docs in the future.  JMO....    Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 02:02PM dlb823 wrote: slinky ~ I wasn't going to weigh in on your seeing this doctor again, as I feel that's your decision.  However, after reading your most recent posts about how much you're dreading seeing him, I totally agree with Leah that it might be best to sever your ties with him before seeing him again. Not only is it probably best for your emotional health, but just going back to him, no matter whether it's for convenience or to confront him, kind of takes away from any future complaint you plan to make about his incompetence.  In other words, you went back to him (as he'll no doubt inform everyone), how bad could he have been? I know it's probably hard to think straight after all you've been through, but maybe you could call your health insurance provider, tell them you've had a serious disappointment with this doctor, and ask what your options are re. switching.  Another thing you may find is that another surgeon may not want to take you because the money making part of the procedure is already done, and at this point they'd just be doing the followup.  So maybe make a few calls and see what you find out before deciding either way.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2015 10:09AM - edited Jul 23, 2015 10:10AM by dlb823 A member who is not Stage IV and was reluctant to post here sent me this PM with permission to share it here. Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 08:43PM dlb823 wrote: Kadia, most of the time, our doctors prefer that we start chemo just as soon as our surgical wounds are healed, but there is a study that demonstrated no change in outcome for those who start chemo up to 12 weeks post-surgery.  However, that 12 week window is only intended for medical reasons, not social ones.  (I found this out when I had to wait 10 weeks post-mx w/Diep recon for an open wound to heal, and then asked my onc if I could wait another week so that I could attend a niece's wedding across the country.  The answer was a resounding, "No!") Hopefully, you won't need chemo.  But if you do, it sounds like waiting until mid-June would really be outside the bounds of what your onc would be comfortable letting you do.  Here's a link to the research I mentioned:  http://www.jco.ascopubs.org/content/24/30/4888.abstract There's another active thread right now entitled, "Safe To Delay Chemo?," that you might also want to check out.    Sorry if chemo throws a glitch into your plans, but if it turns out that it's recommended, then I think you'll need to make it the priority.  (((Hugs))), and let's hope maybe you'll come up with a surprisingly low Oncotype-DX score afterall.     Deanna

Posts.Content: May 24, 2011 09:15AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Sagita ~ I had very much the same thing happen (explained on my bio page), so I know how blindsiding and surreal it can be.  I kept thinking I must have been in an auto accident on my way to my BS's office, and I was unconscious and it was all a bad dream from which I would eventually awaken.  It actually took me several weeks to agree to a mast and to decide on immediate reconstruction, but I guess the good news is that your primary tumor is out, so you do have a bit of time (depending on your move) to think things through.  In the end, I decided that as difficult as the situation was, there was a silver lining because it made me go to a different facility (UCLA) for a second opinion (before agreeing to a mast), where I found doctors I absolutely adored and a far more advanced form of reconstruction (DIEP) than I previously knew anything about.  In fact, one of the top reconstruction teams in the country (NOLA), where they specialize in the type of reconstruction I had, isn't too far from you. I'm so sorry this is happening to you.  One of the things that helped me the most was Googling photos of breast reconstruction and realizing that it can look pretty natural.  Feel free to PM me (private message -- click on anyone's avatar to find that link) if you want to talk off the boards.   (((Hugs))), and you WILL get through this!     Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2014 08:41AM - edited Sep 18, 2014 08:45AM by dlb823 Oh, I know... I am too... especially about my re-dx.  Like you, I did so many things right... annual mammos, athletic, ate extremely healthy, etc.  But I have gone through some extremely stressful times... plus the HRT for early menopause... and then of course there are genetics.  But then I ask myself, if I'd smoked or been significantly overweight, would I have gotten bc or something else sooner?  Who knows?  And I certainly think that being fit has helped me bounce back from the tx I've been through -- especially the fractures and hip replacement that came with my re-dx.  But I absolutely get your point of view, and am certainly not trying to refute anything you've said!   I also don't think we can ever blame ourselves and I don't necessarily equate a prevention message with blame -- unless someone intentionally flaunts anti-healthy behavior.     I just want a more current Pinktober message -- one that isn't stuck on pink ribbons and early detection solving everything, because clearly they don't either.    (((Hugs)))   Deanna
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Survey MusicLover MusicLover

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2014 07:43AM dlb823 wrote: Sandy, your story has been on my mind since I read it last night.  I'm sorry about your birth mother's early passing.  It must have been quite a shock to find out she died from MBC.  But I still wonder if genetics is the 100% explanation as to why you or I or anyone develops a disease where genetics are clearly involved.  The best example I can give you to illustrate my thought process is my DH.  My MIL is extremely diabetic, as are others in her family.  My otherwise healthy DH fought high blood sugar issues for several years (borderline diabetic), until our naturopathic doctor sternly advised him that at 6' and 205 lbs, (certainly not obese and he went to the gym), he was too heavy.  So he lost 30 lbs., and voila -- no more blood sugar issue -- in spite of that very strong familial predisposition. Like you, I always ate healthy, went to the gym, etc. -- even more so after my first dx -- and I still had a metastatic recurrence.  Plus I have a sister and two cousins who are bc survivors, one with mets.  So I totally get why genetics at times seems to be the overriding factor for us, and perhaps it is.  I guess I just still want to believe that -- if we could only pinpoint environmental factors that possibly exacerbate our genetic predisposition, perhaps it could make a difference for some of us.  And since there are so many variations of bc, I guess I have a hard time wrapping my head around a one size fits all vaccine or cure, although there have been some phenomenal research breakthroughs this year that hopefully will lead to far more effective treatments and hopefully someday the eradication of this disease.       Deanna

Posts.Content: May 19, 2015 05:01AM dlb823 wrote: Terri, as everyone else has said, it really takes awhile to wrap your head around a Stage IV dx, and it sounds like what you're going through is perfectly normal. It just takes awhile for the reality to overtake the fear. And the reality is -- while it still remains life threatening -- many oncs now treat mbc as a chronic condition and expect to keep us alive for many years, in which time we all hope and pray there will be more advancements and better txs. And if you go to the Research Forum here, I think you will feel more hopeful when you see how many discoveries (mostly in the areas of genomics and immunotherapy) that have been termed "possible game changers" have been made in recent months. All very hopeful stuff! As others have probably said above, be sure you have an optimistic oncologist who is in the chronic condition camp, and be sure you have been thoroughly evaluated, and that any pain issues have been addressed, because it's impossible to feel optimistic or even think clearly when you are in pain. And not all pain meds work the same for each of us. It can be a very individual trial & error process. I limped around in increasing pain with a fractured femur and fractured pelvis that went undetected for almost 3 mos, and absolutely believed my life was over and I was going downhill fast. But what a difference repairing those made! Don't let something like that happen to you. Other than that, hopefully whatever med(s) you're now on will start to work within the next few weeks, you'll be feeling better, and you'll feel much less pessimistic. (((Hugs))), and hang in there! The first few months can be overwhelming, but I would be very surprised if you don't feel significantly more even-keeled soon. And also remember -- the mind-body connection is a very powerful thing! Focusing on our situations, in my experience, absolutely makes us feel much worse. Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 02:42PM dlb823 wrote: Pat ~  Due to a variety of extenuating circumstances, I didn't start RT until almost 13 weeks from my last chemo.  Although that wasn't the way it was planned, that's the way it worked out, and my docs @ one of the major medical facilities said that there is no agreed on time frame, and that better late than not at all.  To tell you the truth, I never doubted that the txs were working, and I think I felt better having waited because my last chemo tx had been extremely hard on me and it took me a long time to get my energy back.  That said, I would never encourage someone to play the waiting game -- just not to worry if it works out that way due to medical delays.  Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2010 03:16AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Barbara ~ I don't think anyone else has mentioned this yet, but there are a couple of lengthy threads here entitled Oncotype-DX Rollcall and New Oncotype-DX Rollcall.  In each, women have reported their Oncotype score and their decision re. chemo.  While each of us is unique, these threads may help you get a feel for what other women with a similar score decided.  The threads in the Chemotherapy section (click on Forum Index, above).  I'll bump them up for you so that you can find them easily. You might also want to take a look at a website called www.lifemath.net.   There's a section in it for breast cancer, where you can put in various treatment combinations to see what difference in outcome they might make. The last time I looked at it, Taxotere + Cytoxan was not specifically listed because it's rather new, but you can put in "Third Generation Chemo Regimen" (which it what it is) to get a general idea. Hope both of these suggestions help.  And don't feel pressured into making a decision.  Take your time and be sure you're doing what you are most comfortable with going forward.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2016 04:17PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Barbe. So sorry to see you here. Arimidex or one of the other 2 A/I's (Aromasin or Femara) are used after active tx for early stage bc in post menopausal women to hopefully prevent a recurrence, in which case 5 years is normally the recommended time. But these drugs are so powerful, once someone has mets, they can actually halt its progression -- as long as it keeps working. If your met or mets should disappear while on Arimidex, they would keep you on it to hopefully keep it at bay, since your bc has now shown everyone it knows how to travel. Hope this helps... (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 11:42AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Deen ~  I had a DIEP in May.  I was really afraid I wouldn't have enough tummy tissue, but my PS kept assuring me I had just enough, and he was right.  I'm 5' 4" and 125 lbs.  When lying down, my tummy was very flat, but when standing, you could sort of grab enough to make a breast mound -- if you know what I mean.  And that was the only "test" my very experienced PS did.  Then, I was so concerned about possibly losing weight before the surgery, I actually ate a piece of cheesecake every day for two or three weeks, just to be sure I kept every ounce of fat I had.  So, you might actually consider eating a bit more and gaining a couple of pounds if you don't think you'll pass the tummy grab test.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 08:17AM - edited Sep 8, 2011 08:20AM by dlb823 cg, I just reread your original post, partly because I was concerned that I might have been a bit too opinionated when I answered your question last night about not rushing into surgery, especially a mast.  And I was actually kind of shocked to realize that you don't even have your biopsy results back yet and probably won't until tomorrow.  And your surgeon has already scheduled surgery for Monday?!!  Trust me, this is not usual, and I don't see how she can line up a plastic surgeon (no less give you enough information that you could even make an informed decision about recon) unless neither one of them has anything on their schedules.   How long will she be gone?  Other than a couple of types of very aggressive (fast growing) bc's, most have been growing for 8 or 10 years by the time they're large enough to be imaged on mammo or u/s.  So even though our instinct is to want them out immediately once they're discovered, in most cases taking a little time to educate yourself and not be rushed into a decision is not going to exaccerbate the situation.     If I was in your situation, I would also be interested in knowing exactly how many bc surgeries (lumpectomies and mastectomies) this surgeon does per year.       Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2012 11:30PM dlb823 wrote: Zennurse, depending on what the u/s does or doesn't show, with the symptoms you're describing, you might also want to ask for a skin biopsy ("punch test"), just to rule out a particular, uncommon type of bc that can manifest with some of the skin irregularities you've mentioned.   Being called back sooner for your u/s and additional mammo views isn't a reason to panic.  But with more than one thing going on, getting thorough screening is probably wise, so don't hesitate to ask for a punch test if you still have the skin related issues.   Good luck, and please let us know what you find out.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2016 08:54AM dlb823 wrote: What's crazy about the different terminology used for metastatic recurrences (and Stephanie is correct, although "Stage IV" is commonly used, even by oncologists and here) is that it seems to have prevented us from getting a true handle on how many women are actually living with mbc. In other words, those dx'd out of the gate as Stage IV are counted, but as far as I know and often hear lamented, there is no reporting nor accurate stats when it comes to patients who recur as metastatic. This is so wrong, because it only aids in the lack of seriousness about our numbers and the need for research. Sorry if this is off tangent, but felt it needed to be mentioned. I wish someone would take on the task of figuring out how many truly are living with mbc, in the hopes that we can continue to shed light on the need for mbc research over pink awareness.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2013 09:48PM dlb823 wrote: An article in Medscape critiquing the research noted: "The unmeasured variables include the use of adjuvant systemic therapy, she explained. "Advances in systemic therapy are credited for a large part of the reduction in mortality from breast cancer we've seen in the past 2 decades." The absence of data on systemic therapy was especially concerning to another expert. "We know that systemic therapy has a large influence on overall and disease-specific survival,' said Maurice van der Sangen, MD, a radiation oncologist from Carina Hospital in Eindhoven, the Netherlands, who has studied breast cancer recurrence." And "...more women in the mastectomy group than in the BCT group were treated before 1999 (59% vs 48%), when systemic therapy was used only in the case of node-positive disease, said Dr. van der Sangen."               In other words, this study totally ignores chemo as a factor in outcomes.    Deanna

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 06:11PM dlb823 wrote: I did TC x 4.  Back when I did it (2008), the research showing it was superior to several others  was brand new, and many oncs were RX'ing AC or AC+T for almost everyone, or if they were doing TC, sometimes they were randomly doing it x6.  Now, TC x 4 is very commonly used.   This is one reason I am so keen on at least getting an opinion at an NCI-designated facility -- b'cuz they're sometimes up on recent research that others aren't.  Sometimes it takes awhile for new research and recommendations to filter down to everyone, and for oncs to get comfortable with changing.    Deanna

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 08:49PM dlb823 wrote: asmd ~ This is the study that led to the change in thinking re. AC: http://journals.lww.com/oncology-times/Fulltext/2008/02100/TC_Superior_to_AC_in_Early_Breast_Cancer.4.aspx And here's a comment by Steve Jones, considered the father of Adriamycin, that was often quoted.  I couldn't find his entire commentary just now, but this short piece from MORE Magazine contains the gist of it:  http://www.more.com/health/breast-cancer/new-breast-cancer-breakthroughs This is not to say you wouldn't be better off with AC.  I'm not a doctor -- just sharing what I was told and why I made the decision I did.  I haven't read or heard about whatever research has influenced Dana Farber's current opinion, but you're absolutely right about them being top-notch.  Taxotere does cause neuropathy, but it seems like there's a wide range in what women experience.  I found the supplement B6 very helpful for that, but neuropathy and fatigue were both issues for me.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2014 10:05AM dlb823 wrote: Absolutely get a second opinion! Is this your first bc dx? If so, and if you're Her2+, that would explain the recommendation for chemo (with Herceptin, I assume). But without a shadow of a doubt, I'd head for the Mayo. Not all workups are the same, not all radiologists are equally as skilled at reading scans, and not all docs think alike. And once you have a bc dx, radiologists are sometimes IMO quick to jump to a mets conclusion. Tumor markers for breast cancer are normally checked with a blood test called the CA27-29. Unfortunately, it is not always accurate for everyone, but also hard to tell if it's elevated if it's your very first one, as there's nothing to compare it to. (i.e. if normal for you is 10 and this one was 30, that's within the normal range, but could be elevated for you.) Are you going to the Mayo? Normally when you go to a comprehensive cancer center such as the Mayo for a second opinion, you have the option of being treated there, or taking the information they give you back to a local medical team. Sometimes they can even recommend top docs in your area, such af those who were former residents at the Mayo, etc. The 2 hr. trip will be well worth it to have a second medical team evaluate your situation. Praying that you're not dealing with mets, but know that whatever it is, you will get through it! Glad you've found BCO. (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2010 08:29PM dlb823 wrote: daisybeth  ~  Better to make a mountain out of a molehill than to find out later there was a problem that you let go too long because you were afraid you might be overreacting.  80% of biopsies (and you're not even to that point yet) turn out to be benign.  So the odds are totally in your favor that it's not bc.  However, some of us will draw the bc card, and when we do, it's always better to catch it as early as possible.  As you may know, the itching in particular can be a symptom of one of the more aggressive types of bc, so I would say it would be prudent to get it checked out.  And your oncologist is not the best one to diagnosis a breast condition. A breast/surgeon specialist is the type of doctor you need to figure out what's going on.  Good luck, and please let us know what happens...   Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2015 09:56AM dlb823 wrote: Blaine, I think many of us can relate to what you're going through. A few months ago our ND suspected my hubby had a serious heart issue (based on a complex blood test NDs do) and sent him to a cardiologist. Hundreds of dollars later (since he had never met a penny of his deductible or out-of-pocket), the cardiologist (who he didn't like and who brought out the worst, argumentative, non-compliant patient in him) cleared him, and a follow up blood test with the ND showed the original concern no longer existed. But in the meantime, my rock of a hubby was in a horrible mood for weeks, afraid he was a heart attack waiting to happen. So in some ways, I can relate to what you're going through, although our son is much older than yours, so I wasn't dealing with that huge concern. I'm relaying the story because my hubby's problem turned out to be nothing in spite of a very concerning blood test that made him believe he was in danger of an imminent heart attack, and I'm hoping things will turn out the same for you, and that whatever is causing the low counts is nothing serious and things will get back on an even keel very soon! Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 02:17PM dlb823 wrote: Emerald, what sometimes gives doctors a significant clue to whether or not a lesion is malignant is something referred to as being spiculated, which means the lesion has little tenacles or looks a bit like a spider.  That was something I was told prior to both of my biopsies (initial one and one for something much smaller seen on MRI) -- that they strongly suspected bc because the lesions were spiculated.     Good luck, and be sure to let us know when you're having the actual biopsy.  Hopefully whoever gave you the 85% odds is mistaken, and the biopsy will absolutely come back B9.  Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 01:58PM dlb823 wrote: Don't feel bad; I think that happens to a lot of us!  That's one reason why BCO can be so very helpful --  connecting those who have already been through a dx and tx and can suggest what questions to ask, with others just starting the journey.  And nobody learns it all at once.  I've personally gone back to my own biopsy and surgical reports dozens of times because I've learned something new or because something clicked that hadn't earlier, and I wanted to see if it applied to me.   So two things that every newly-dx'd woman should do are (1) be sure to take someone with you to appts, so that they can be your eyes and ears when you start to zone out from shock or information overload; and (2) ask for copies of every medical test and report.  That way you can go back and look at them as questions arise.  Congrats on being done with chemo!  Hopefully, you're beginning to see the light at the end of the tunnel.   (((Hugs))),   Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2011 09:01PM dlb823 wrote: Gosh, I'm not a doctor, but I can tell you that there's a HUGE emotional component to being dx'd with bc, and surgery as serious and irreversible as a mast. IMO should not be scheduled within a few days of a dx to fit into a doctor's vacation plans.  Most of us need a couple of weeks to think through what we really want to do -- partly b'cuz we're literally in so much shock that we may not be thinking half as clearly as we think we are, and we will very possibly change our minds several times before coming to a decision we know is right for us. Has this doctor said anything to you about reconstruction?  Sometimes (depending on your individual situation) doing that at the same time as a mast. is the best choice.  So traveling to a larger comprehensive cancer center in Seattle might give you that option, which I suspect you don't have in Juneau. The first thing I would do tomorrow is get a copy of your pathology report and let us know any additional details.  Have you had an MRI?  That's something most of us have to ensure there's nothing else going on in either breast beyond what they already know about.  If there isn't anything else of concern, a lumpectomy could remove the 2 cm bc and you could think about doing a mast. later.  But I would be really hesitant to go forward without an MRI. Just some thoughts...   Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2012 11:45AM - edited Aug 8, 2012 11:46AM by dlb823 I was treated locally (Palm Springs/Palm Desert area) and also UCLA, and in both settings, a psychologist or oncology social worker were very prominent from the very beginning, right through rads.  So it's kind of surprising to hear that no one has filled that need for you. In what part of CA do you live?  I know UCLA has wonderful support groups run by their psychologists that are open to non-UCLA patients on an availability basis.  Here's a link to some of their info:  http://www.simmsmanncenter.ucla.edu/groups/groups.asp It's not only helpful to have someone to talk to at various stages in our tx, it's also important that you find someone with a real understanding of bc and bc tx.  As a UCLA psychologist said to me, this is not the time to be explaining to someone what bc terminology means.  You need someone who knows more than you do about the disease, your tx, and the healing process, which probably means making an appointment with someone at one of the larger institutions -- UCLA, USC, Cedars, Stanford, UCSF, etc., depending on where you live.  I do hope you can find someone to give you the support you need and are seeking!   (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 08:59AM dlb823 wrote: Jenny, my heart goes out to you.  I don't know where you live, but I would strongly suggest that you find a new medical team.  NCI-designated hospitals are the ones on the cutting edge of research.  They are also usually extremely thorough in their workups, as well as dealing with the most breast cancer patients, so will likely have experience with your pre-existing condition(s).  If there is one within even a few hours of you, I would strongly suggest getting an appointment ASAP.   http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html If the nearest one is more than a couple of hours away, I would still go and find out what they recommend.  You can always take the information back to more local docs (although probably not the ones you have now), and often the docs @ these top facilities will work directly with local docs.   I pray that you will find a highly competent and positive medical team going forward.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 01:28PM dlb823 wrote: My advice from personal experience is DO NOT tell anyone who enjoys being the bearer of big news.  No matter how well-intentioned some people are, the information they spread can quickly become distorted -- like that childhood game where you repeat a message by whispering down a line and by the time it gets to the other end, it hardly bears any resemblence to the original message.  So be sure anyone important hears it directly from you.    Also, I think it's really best to wait until you have a treatment plan in place, or at least know exactly what treatment you will need, recovery time, etc., to prevent people from filling in the blanks themselves and possibly giving others misinformation about your situation.    Deanna
Posts.Title: Who and when to tell? wyldblumusic Frapp

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 09:23PM - edited Apr 2, 2010 09:35PM by dlb823 ac295206 ~ Your situation is very typical.  Birads is a way they describe what they've seen.  4 means it's suspicious enough to want to do a biopsy to rule out a malignancy, but it's by no means the most worrisome rating: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BI-RADS Ultrasound guided biopsies are probably the most common type.  The radiologist will use ultrasound to image the spot they want to check and use a needle-like piece of equipment to get a small tissue sample.  It's not painful, but the procedure can cause some bruising. Needing a biopsy is unnerving, but the good news is that 80% of breast biopsies turn out to be benign, and I certainly hope that yours will be in that category!    Deanna

Posts.Content: May 11, 2010 10:10PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, paxton ~  I did 4 rounds of Taxotere & Cytoxan in August-October of 2008, and many of us on the TC thread here used ice to save our nails because it prevents the chemo from getting to our nailbeds.  For that, you can use either an ice pack or a package of frozen veggies, which is what I did, because it's maleable and seemed less messy after it had  melted.  And it was never questioned by any of our oncs or onc nurses, although my onc wasn't convinced it really did anything, but I thought so.  But I would question if getting your hands and feet cold enough to prevent neuropathy might interfer with the drugs circulating properly.  What does help with neuropathy though is the vitamin supplement B6.  And I'm sure you've been told or will be told that you need to drink massive amounts of water to wash out the chemo.  Hopefully, that will also help prevent it from settling in those extremeties too long.  Good luck with your chemo!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2010 04:31PM - edited Feb 22, 2010 04:45PM by dlb823 Nancy ~  Interesting post.  It sounds like you're very fortunate to have 3 extremely capable oncologists from which to choose, and it doesn't sound like any of them would be a bad or lesser choice.   From experience, the one thing I would caution you about is choosing an onc who isn't nearby or on staff at a local hospital, unless he can assure you of what to do in an emergency.  I had to consider that when I was deciding whether to have chemo @ UCLA (where I had my surgery, but a 3 hr. drive) or locally.  I ended up with UCLA's encouragement finding a local onc who would follow the protocol UCLA recommended.  Your #1 onc isn't 3 hrs. away, but I'm not sure 40 miles may not put you in the same situation in the unlikely scenario of having a problem, needing care quickly, and showing up at an ER where no one has your records or knows your history.  I would also very much want to know which chemo each of your prospective oncs would recommend for you and why.  Like you, I talked to 3 oncs prior to starting chemo, and they each had totally different recommendations, which was a huge surprise to me, but had everything to do with my final choice.  In other words, I totally ruled out Onc #1 (local) when Onc #2 (UCLA) told me that #1's protocol was wrong for me.  I ended up with #3 (also local), but only after he expressed genuine interest in UCLA's recommendations (which differed from his, as well) and agreed to work with my onc there. The other thing I might throw out to you that many of us don't realize initially, is that the relationship with your onc will be on-going for up to 5 years after your actual treatment ends, and he/she will probably want to see you at least twice a year to start.  So you may want to keep that in mind. Hopefully, someone from the Atlanta area will weigh in and be able to give you some firsthand input to help tip your decision.  And best of luck with whomever you choose!    Deanna  PS ~ Hi, Meg!  Looks like we were posting at the same time!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 03:10PM dlb823 wrote: enthused ~  It sounds like your Mom's surgeon has, at best, a communication problem.  But, that said, things can and do change with a bc diagnosis, as new information is learned based on the various tests that are done.  Unfortunately, they often don't tell you that upfront.  They frequently tell you their best guess at your situation.  Then, when a more complex picture emerges based on unexpected results from a pathology report -- like an unexpected positive lymph node -- you are both blindsided because their assumptions were incorrect, and they had never bothered to forewarn you that nothing was definite until the final pathology was in.  Many women get second, third and even fourth opinions, especially if they just don't have a comfort level with their original doctor(s), or if they get conflicting opinions from the first two.  Your Mom is literally putting her future health in this doctor's hands.  Encourage her to take the time to find someone she likes and feels comfortable with -- someone who will explain everything so that her situation and any options she has are totally clear. Good luck to you both, and please let us know what she decides to do ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 09:21AM dlb823 wrote: Debbie, active chemo suppresses the body's ability to heal and fight infections, so surgery would not be scheduled while you're on chemo and still have infusions scheduled.  Likewise, chemo doesn't start until you're healed from surgery because it would suppress healing and open the door to infection. I'm not absolutely sure, but I think surgery can be scheduled relatively soon after all chemo infusions are completed.  I'm not sure of the most ideal wait time, but I remember it was shorter than you might think.      Deanna

Posts.Title: And it keeps getting worse... Michele_T lhasamom

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 10:16AM - edited Feb 14, 2011 10:17AM by dlb823 series ~ I'm very sorry about your Mom's bc diagnosis.   Unfortunately, certain types of breast cancer, especially ILC (lobular) often do not show up on mammograms or ultrasound -- only MRIs.  X-rays are not normally used to detect breast cancer.  Also, in most cases, breast cancer takes years to grow.  So I suspect that her breast cancer probably was there 4 months ago and just not seen by whatever type of test was done. Many of us have a PetScan early in our diagnosis, to see if things have gone any further.  The fact that it may not be in her lymph nodes is great news.  If it isn't in multiple nodes, she would only be at Stage II, which is considered an early diagnosis and very treatable. The prognosis for Stage IV varies a lot, but yes, you are correct that it cannot be totally cured,  But many women who are Stage IV become NED (no evidence of disease) and many maintain that status for a very long time. Is your Mom scheduled to have surgery?       Deanna
Posts.Title: About probability series flash

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 09:46AM dlb823 wrote: I also had a sentinel node that was initially called clear in the OR, but turned out not to be.  My BS and other bc experts I was able to query, all felt strongly that I needed more nodes taken, so I did that.  In retrospect, since I had more than a micromet in the SN, other than staging, I'm not sure what difference taking 15 or 16 additional nodes would have made in terms of my tx, since I ended up having chemo anyway.  In your friend's case, it could make a difference, because I believe they are now offering Onco-Type DX testing to women with 1 positive node.  When I was dx'd, they were not doing that yet.  Also, finding out that my additional nodes were all negative was actually a huge emotional boost, since prior to that I'd had several unpleasant pathology surprises. You didn't indicate if your friend's surgeon is a breast surgeon or a general surgeon.  If the latter, I would suggest maybe getting a second opinion from a breast surgeon who might be able to explain the need for taking more nodes.  In my case, I absolutely trusted my new BS @ UCLA, who assured me she would take only a good "pad" of nodes (not all of them).  I also had extracapsular extension in my SN, so that was another reason checking additional nodes seemed to make sense at the time.    Deanna

Posts.Content: May 12, 2012 02:12PM - edited May 12, 2012 02:13PM by dlb823 Kay, something that helped re-frame my thought processes re. all sorts of fears I had about surgery (mx+Diep recon) was a guided imagery CD one of my SILs gave me called Successful Surgery by BellaRuth Naperstek.  You can find it at www.healthjourneys.com. I realize your concerns and fears are different than what mine were, but that CD is really great at helping to turn any negative thoughts to more positive ones, and they say it also helps to speed recovery.  You can listen to a snippet of it at that website and there's an immediate download option.  A friend of mine is having surgery for an aeortic aneurysm on Monday -- a very scary procedure -- and he reports that listening to it has helped with his anxiety.  Just thought I'd tell you about in case you don't know about it.  I'll be thinking of you ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 10:32PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:16AM by dlb823 mary ~ A mammogram normally will not show the axillary nodes.  Since your insurance is expiring, and since you and your gyno both felt something in that area, can she possibly set up an ultrasound at the same time as your mammo?  I believe that would be a very normal request (to have both tests on the same day) from what you've told us, and something your insurance company should cover. As far as your insurance expiring, are you planning to do COBRA or get other insurance after the first of the year?  If you are planning to get new insurance, you may want to think about waiting until January for those tests.  Whatever you do, you do not want to find something (and of course we hope & pray you won't) -- but you don't want to find something that would be considered pre-existing and prevent you from getting other coverage.  Just maybe something to consider.... and good luck whatever you do.    Deanna
Posts.Title: Mammogram Question about axillary nodes marymeyer4 leaf

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 05:06PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, kennessee ~ I wasn't familiar with hypoechoic, but found this definition by a doctor for you: "A hypoechoic lesion is a finding on ultrasound studies that refers to any structure which bounces back sound waves poorly, so that the image generated appears dark on the monitor screen. Structures which have less density, and contain more water, air or fat may appear as hypoechoic... a hypoecoic lesion could be either a cyst or a benign tumour or a malignant tumour." As far as the size of what are being called "masses," a mm is tiny.  18mm (the longest side given) is slightly less than 3/4 of an inch. Hope this helps a little ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2015 10:52AM dlb823 wrote: Akevia, the first pain med I was RX'd for my bone mets was simply 600 mg. of Ibuprophen. You can accomplish the same high dose with 3 OTC 200 mg. Ibuprophen. Also you might want to try a heating pad on the painful area(s), if you haven't already. If those don't help enough, ask your onc for something stronger. Codeine #3, which is acetomenophin with codeine, worked great for me when I need it, but everyone is different, so don't give up if whatever you try first doesn't relieve the pain. Ask for and keep trying things until you find something that works for you. So sorry you're going through this -- especially the worrying. Praying you don't have mets! Keep us posted on your tests. (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2010 09:47PM - edited Aug 18, 2010 09:48PM by dlb823 daughterinlaw ~ I agree with hrf, and also agree with you that it seems odd that a doctor suspecting breast cancer wouldn't arrange a biopsy sooner than 2 weeks out.  On the other hand, depending on where your MIL lives, perhaps it was hard to get an appointment any sooner with summer vacation schedules.  It may help to know that by the time a lump can be felt or seen on a mammogram, it's usually been there several years.  So the worse thing about the wait is the emotional stress, especially in view of her doctor venturing the opinion he has. If your MIL wants to investigate the possibility of a quicker biopsy, and if she's close enough to get to any of the NCI-designated facilities on this list, any of them would be a wonderful place to get a thorough evaluation, possibly sooner than July 30. http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html I'm glad you've found BCO, and hope you'll stay in touch and let us know the outcome of her situation.  By the way, 80% of breast biopsies turn out to be B9, so, at the moment, the odds are still in her favor.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 12:45AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, ccare ~ Sorry you had such a bad experience with that radiologist or rad tech or whatever he was.  I agree with those who said you should report that kind of insensitive behavior.  But, more importantly, I wanted to comment on something else you said: "I have EVERY risk factor."  That in itself is reason to get yourself to a full fledged breast center that offers a program to monitor high risk women.  I, too, had several risk factors (although I never considered myself high risk because I was so health conscious), but I didn't even know about high risk programs until I was dx'd and ended up at UCLA, where they have one.  Had I known about this sort of program pre-dx, I could have been monitored more closely and they probably would have caught my bc months sooner.  If I were in your situation, I don't think I would be comfortable with the diagnostic work you just had (based on the know-it-all attitude of that radiologist), and would definitely go somewhere else for a 2nd opinion.  If there's an NCI Cancer Center in your area, that would be a great place to go for a second opinion, as well as seeing if they recommend that you be in a high risk program, which just means they evaluate you especially carefully because of your known risk factors, and monitor you more closely than women who are not as high risk.  Here is a link to the NCI Cancer Centers: http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/cancer-centers-names.html Good luck, and please keep us posted on your situation ~   Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2014 04:16PM dlb823 wrote: CKC ~ I just wanted to add that what you're going through -- feeling your bc has already spread -- is very normal. I think most, if not all, of us have that fear when first dx'd. But beyond that, I agree with SpecialK, especially since there may be a genetic component to your bc. And that's something that should also be addressed, if it hasn't already -- the possible need for genetic counseling, to see if you carry a BRCA 1 or BRCA 2 mutation, since your Mother must have been quite young when she was dx'd. I also want to add -- if your doctor isn't receptive to doing a PET or CT Scan for any reason, I would consider at least getting a second opinion. For now, I don't see any red flags, so to speak, about your tx plan. But I would certainly ask for a PET or CT Scan, if only for the peace of mind it will give you going forward. So sorry about your dx. Sending you hugs & prayers for good results from your upcoming MRI and with chemo! Please keep us posted on what you find out. Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2014 10:11AM dlb823 wrote: CKC, it's very common for things to change, especially when you're first dx'd, as more information becomes available from biopsies and other tests. I don't think it's as much "smoke & mirrors" as it is just a fluid, changing situation -- like finding something on an MRI or in bloodwork that changes their assumed course. This is also a difficult week to get things scheduled due to the holidays and many docs taking off. But, that said, I personally think when things start to get the least bit confusing or complicated, that's the time to head to an NCI-designated cancer center, where they will have all the necessary breast cancer specialists under one roof (or on one campus), and the most experience. Here's a list of them should you decide to look beyond your local docs, which is what it sounds like you may be dealing with right now. http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map... Hope this helps. And keep in mind, what you're going through is one of the worst times. It gets much easier once you have a complete dx and a treatment plan in place. (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 11:34AM - edited May 31, 2012 11:35AM by dlb823 I totally agree that if it were a life or death situation, I, too, would want blood and not be overly picky about its source!  OTOH, so many people who need blood transfusions are very ill and probably already have compromised immune systems.   But I understand how some may not object to bc survivors donating blood, especially if someone's already been through tx and hopefully is clear of any bc cells. I guess for me it comes down to wanting to reduce even potential risk where we can, and I've heard too many stories of women being dx'd with metastatic bc years after their initial dx & tx.     guineamom, to answer your question about being BRCA+, I don't think you can give a genetic mutation to someone else via a blood transfusion.  But perhaps someone with a biology background can offer a scientific explanation.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2016 12:27PM dlb823 wrote: Indenial, I'm another one who really dragged my heels on starting Xgeva, which had been recommended for me for more than a year while I underwent some dental stuff -- a couple of extractions, and then trying to save a slightly loose tooth. My UCLA onc finally sent me to an Xgeva expert @ UCLA. She did a pretty extensive workup including a jaw CT, extracted the questionable tooth, and eventually cleared me for Xgeva, which greatly eased my mind re. the risk of ONJ. So I've been on it for 5 mos. now (about to get #6), and I absolutely love it. No issues, except greatly reduced bone pain and I can stand up much straighter than I'd been able to for many months. My UCLA onc recently recommended doing only 6 monthly injections before going to every 3 mos. (because of a possible increased risk of ONJ for those of us on Ibrance, which tends to lower counts), and I was actually disappointed! Clearly, I'm a huge fan now. I consider it one of my miracle drugs, along with Ibrance. My only advice is to get any teeth issues well checked out prior to starting it.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2015 12:37PM dlb823 wrote: Betsy, to answer your question about how long to wait to see if the pain regimen you're on helps, I would say not very long. There's absolutely no way you can feel the least bit optimistic, no less think straight, when you are in pain. I wouldn't give it more than a couple of days before asking for something different. And I don't think it's necessarily strength that's a factor. Some pain meds just work better for some of us than others. Ask for a different regimen if you are not getting your pain down to a manageable level. Patches + something for breakthrough pain may not be adequate, especially when we're advised not to let the pain get ahead of us so that we're chasing it. I'm just thinking you might need something more systemic than patches that you take on a regular schedule as your base pain med. Many (((hugs))) and prayers that you will be doing well for your son's wedding and far beyond. Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2012 11:07AM dlb823 wrote: Malignancies look white on mammograms.  When you have very dense breast tissue, there's a lot of solid white, so it's next to impossible to pick out an irregularity.   If you have any concerning symptom(s) -- a lump, pain, dimpling, shape changes, discharge, etc. -- by all means ask for additional screening to determine what's causing it.  Also, not to alarm you, but dense breast tissue has, in itself, now been termed a risk factor.  My best advice is to be sure you're being monitored at the type of facility that has a breast surgeon/specialist who will know when additional screening is prudent.  Dense breast tissue is now being noted on mammo reports so that we will be more pro-active if the situation calls for it -- like feeling a lump that isn't showing up on a mammo, in which case an ultrasound and maybe even an MRI should be requested.    Good luck ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2015 01:47PM dlb823 wrote: Deannie, I'm so sorry about your Mother. Of course you're a mess worrying about her and concerned that you might not be getting adequate attention on your own breast health concerns. Since there is quite a bit of cancer in your family, including breast cancer, can you possibly get a referral to a breast surgeon/specialist, who will not only listen to you, but will probably take your concerns much more seriously than your gyn did. A breast specialist can also refer you to a genetics counselor, if they feel it's appropriate, as well as give you practical lifestyle advice (especially IF it turns out that you have a higher risk than some for bc) that might be helpful in avoiding a future dx. (And I say that knowing there are no assurances, but certainly factors that have been shown to impact our risk.) That's what I would suggest -- an appointment with a breast specialist (surgeon) who will order whatever testing is truly necessary and hopefully be able to put your mind at ease going forward. Hugs, Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2015 02:55PM dlb823 wrote: MammaD, there's some controversy regarding what constitutes a "safe" margin, but 4mm is defintely on the high side of safe. From experience, my onc did not think I needed rads with a mx. However, I talked to 4 different rad oncs, and they all felt I absolutely did, even with an mx -- partly because of a positive node with extracapsular extension, and also due to an unspecified margin on a bit of uninked tissue my BS trimmed that surprised us all by hiding a 1 mm lesion. Each situation is individual. If I was in your situation, I would consult with one or more rad oncs, until you're comfortable deciding either way. It's not up to a BS to make that kind of judgment call. (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 03:45PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Glenda ~ I had multicentric ILC, and I had a unilateral mast, even though I have a sister who was in that unfortunate 20%, and had a recurrence in her other breast 8 years after her first bc.  But even knowing that risk, my surgeons @ UCLA did not recommend a bi-lateral for me (after a clean MRI), and encouraged me to only deal with the affected breast.  One thing that mattered to me was retaining nipple sensation on at least one side.  Not sure if you can possibly do a nipple-sparing mast on your good side, or if the nerves are as affected with that type of mast, but it may be something you'll want to consider and ask questions about, especially if you end up leaning towards a bi-lateral.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 02:28PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Lisa ~  I've just started rads, but had a similar situation.  I live near Palm Desert, but am being  tx'd @ UCLA, which is 150 miles away, through much freeway gridlock.  So, although I talked at length with the rad oncs @ UCLA, I really had to find someone closer to home. First, the rad onc plans your tx, and, as you suggested, the rad techs are the ones who set up and administer the txs.  Is there any way you can find out more about this new rad onc, like where he did his residency, and how highly was he thought of there?   I was fortunate enough to find a local rad onc who was UCLA trained.  All the docs @ UCLA remembered her and spoke very highly of her, which greatly eased my mind, especially after I met her.  As an alternative, can you find out where the doc who was originally recommended has gone?   And if neither of those ideas work, can you call Stanford and get another recommendation?   One more suggestion... if you like this new doc and would consider using him, I wonder if you could have Stanford look at his rad plan, since that's where you've been treated and you trust their counsel.   I'm not sure if he and Stanford will agree to that, but if they would, I think it should ease your mind.  And lastly, if none of those ideas appeal or work out, then I guess you should just bite the bullet on the drive, and just be grateful we don't live in the NE and have to deal with ice and snow storms.   Deanna
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2014 08:23PM dlb823 wrote: I'm so sorry about your BFF's diagnosis.  I can't answer your question about the wait, but perhaps the end of January is when the trial starts and her docs felt it would be worth waiting to get into it.  Also, many major medical centers virtually shutdown over the holidays so that all docs are off at the same time, and that can make scheduling anything difficult in December and pushed into January.   As far as how you can help, I think the most important thing is to let her share her feelings and just be a really good listener.  Beyond that, any needs will depend on her personal situation, how close you live to her, and how much other support she has.  I would just reassure her that you're available to do anything she needs, whether that's transportation or meals or whatever will allow her to focus on her treatment without worrying about the logistics.  The other thing you can do is tell her about this website.  She will find tons of support here in both the Stage IV and Triple Negative forums. And since we and our bc's all totally unique, no one can give you or her a prognosis.  A lot will depend on how she responds to treatment, but many women with mets do well for a very long time.   (((Hugs))) to you both ~   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2015 08:56PM dlb823 wrote: stvmom, well I think it's good that you're having an excisional biopsy. Until I read that part of your post, I was going to say that you needed to pursue this until you not only ruled out bc (as it appears has been done), but have also found the explanation for your pain. Hopefully the excisional biopsy will accomplish that. Had your BS not suggested the excisional biopsy, I was going to suggest perhaps asking for an MRI -- on the slim possibility there could be something small hiding behind that area that's been biopsied -- something tiny but painful. Also, just so you know, Birads ratings are somewhat subjective, and even a Birads 4, as you may know, leaves things pretty wide open re. the possibility of it being benign. So I wouldn't worry too much about that rating, if that was part of your question. Good luck on Monday! (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 02:30PM dlb823 wrote: gfrey ~ My eyelashes grew back and fell out 3 times, up until 6 or 7 months after I was done with chemo.  It was so annoying! As far as your other symptoms, have you seen your primary doctor lately for a checkup and some blood work?  Chemo and rads can really mess up our WBC (immune system) & RBC (energy), as well as other things.  I had unexpectedly high readings on my homocysteine levels and cholesterol, for example -- things I'd never had before chemo/rads.  The feeling you're describing that you get upon standing sounds like it could be blood sugar related -- either too high or too low. If you're on Tamoxifen or an A/I, they could also be factors.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2012 01:02PM dlb823 wrote: Bono, I'm so sorry that you find yourself needing a biopsy, but it's good that you made an appointment and are in the process of getting things checked out.  As you may know, 85% of biopsies turn out to be B9, and from what you've told us so far, there's no reason to believe that yours will be anything different.  Did you happen to get a copy of the u/s report?  Radiologists normally give lumps that need further investigation what's called a Bi-Rads Rating, and that might tell you a bit more re. degree of suspicion, if you can find that number (i.e. Bi-Rads 3, 4 or 5). So sorry you're going through this, but please let us know the outcome.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2009 02:37PM dlb823 wrote: someoneinaz ~   As leaf said, it's highly unlikely a bc lesion would get smaller, but it is impossible to diagnose what it is from a description.  My best suggestion is that she make an appointment with a breast surgeon, as they are the specialists best equipped to examine, recommend appropriate tests (like a mammogram) if they feel it's warranted, and diagnose conditions of the breast.  I don't think her first doc's reaction was necessarily over the top if she came to him with a complaint about a lump and if the only test he did didn't identify it.  It sounds like he's making the appropriate referral or recommendation, even though his demeanor on the phone may have been surprising to you.  Who knows -- maybe the last woman who didn't follow his advice actually had bc, or maybe someone he didn't thoroughly evaluate ended up with a bc dx.  I wouldn't read "suspected problem" into his intensity re. your wife -- just frustration that she didn't follow through with the recommended mammogram.  But his recommendation to have a breast surgeon (not another OB/GYN) check her lump sounds most logical to me.  Good luck, and please keep us posted ~  Deanna
Posts.Title: Cyst or not, comes and goes someoneinaz kibbles

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 08:13AM dlb823 wrote: I had the same misconception about surgeons.  And the apparent "logic" of it might apply in other situations -- a bad knee, for example.  For that, a surgeon could resolve it with surgery, but if the person is 100 lbs. overweight and gets no exercise, there are obviously lifestyle changes that should be addressed short of surgery.  But in the case of a  lump, based on the experience of feeling thousands of them, a breast surgeon should immediately know if a workup is warrented.  It's a simple matter of visualizing it using the right modality (mammo, more skilled u/s, MRI), and if it appears suspicious, biopsying it, most likely with a needle, so that a pathologist can identify the cells.  Breast surgeons have no reason to do surgery on women unless their pathology indicates a problem.  Your wife just doesn't grasp the role of a breast surgeon, which includes the initial breast exam to rule out things that aren't concerning.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 02:31PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Mercury ~ I think your question is a very logical one, and it will be interesting to see what JH recommends.  Personally, I'm not familiar with using Arimidex (which is what I think you mean) as a neoadjuvant drug, but maybe that's something very new, and would save the chemo for use later, rather than possibly weakening your Mom before surgery.  So it might be an excellent suggestion.  An aromatese inhibitor like Arimidex is frequently used first when surgery isn't adviseable (such as for metastatic bc), and drug therapy is the best option.  In that sitution, I believe it's used first because it's the least harsh option (a hormonal approach), and if it does the job, you've reserved chemo for later use. Just my guess, but I'm glad that JH will be your next stop because I think the input you get from those who have extensive experience with cases similar to your Mother's (and I can only assume an institution like JH has treated a lot of women over 70) will be valuable.  Good luck to her, and please keep us posted ~   Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 09:06AM - edited Feb 7, 2011 10:42AM by dlb823 It's interesting how our bodies often tell us what they need.  Shortly after I was dx'd, I started craving grapefruit, which I rarely ate.  The craving was so pronounced that I did a bit of reading on grapefruit, and was fascinated to learn that it's highly estrogenic, which made total sense in view of the fact that I'd had to get off the HRT I'd been on for many years, cold turkey. After I finished my tx, I met with an integrative specialist to talk about diet & supplements going forward, and that was one of the foods I asked her about.  She advised avoiding grapefruit juice, but didn't see a problem with an occasional piece of grapefruit.  So I still eat it (like once or twice a month) and don't feel like it's a problem, especially in view of the recent research re. the anti-cancer benefit of citrus fruit pectins. But these are decisions we each have to weigh in terms of what else we're doing or not doing.  It's what feels right to you (after knowing the facts) that's important.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 09:34PM dlb823 wrote: Karen ~  Although I know you won't see this now until after your surgery, I just wanted to tell you that I have been following this thread, and am praying for the very best outcome for you.  Like you, I'd always lived a natural lifestyle, and like you, I was totally against chemo -- until at some point, I finally grasped the important difference between non-invasive and invasive bc, and the fact that the first time around fighting it is truly the best shot any of us get at it; and if you don't get it all initially and comes back, it's a whole different ballgame.  And, unfortunately, although there are many holistic approaches, none of them can give us anything more than annecdotal evidence that they work -- and even then, they're just very general, which scarred me. As the other women who are concerned about you have said, you absolutely need to find an oncologist you like and trust, ideally one who will honor your beliefs in natural healing, and who will help you use complementary medicine appropriately.  They're out there.  You'll just have to hunt for one that's a good match for you.  Thinking of you & wishing you a smooth recovery from your surgery ~ Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2013 06:47PM dlb823 wrote: Patti, many women get only 4. In fact, I'm not sure there are yet stats to show if 6 is a superior regimen, although some oncs recommend it, especially to younger women or those with more aggressive stats. But, as far as I know, there may not be research to back up TCx6, which is probably why your insurance company will not automatically approve it -- although that doesn't mean it may not be in your best interest based on your individual stats. I don't know. My two best suggestions would be (1) Ask your onc to show you the research that supports his/her recommendation of TCx6. And perhaps more importantly, (2) get a second opinion, if you haven't already, at an NCI-designated cancer center where they will have the most experience with TNBC, as well as oncs who probably have a special interest in TNBC research, so will be totally up on the very latest information. www.cancer.gov/researchandfund... Hope this helps, and let us know what happens... (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 03:06PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Lisa ~  I think another thing to remember is that there are women who have few to no SE's, and, if that's the case, may not ever log onto a site like this, looking for reasurance.  So, as wonderful and supportive as all of the women here are, we may tend to be the ones who are more communicative about our SE's.  Also, remember that not every woman gets every SE, or even a significant percentage of them.  And certainly not all together, which is the impression you may get when reading through a thread.  Of the 5 or 6 over the counter preps I purchased going into chemo, I used Biotene mouthwash (it's wonderful), a generic version of Clartin (for Neulasta pain), and maybe 1 more (can't recall).  But  I never needed 1 of the 2 antinausea drugs or the antidiarrhea drug my onc gave me to have on hand.  I got sick to my stomach twice that I recall, and both times it was clearly because I'd eaten something that that didn't agree with me.  Had I not eaten things with raw onion (fish tacos the first time; a Greek Salad another), it  would not have happened at all.  Hope this helps to ease your mind ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2014 02:30PM - edited Apr 7, 2014 09:23AM by dlb823 Shelley, I was dx'd in Jan of this year w/bone mets to ribs, pelvis and a few other places, and I had absolutely no idea I had anything going on until I became extremely sick in mid-December with chest congestion and severe rib pain that Urgent Care docs initially dx'd as bronchitis, a severe viral infection, pleurisy, and rib inflammation.  I'd had no pain in my ribs or anywhere else even the week before I got so sick, and I had x-rays twice looking for maybe a broken rib that never saw any mets.  It finally took a visit to my onc -- because I was so sick and not able to shake whatever was going on (totally out of character for me) -- that showed a significant spike in my CA27-29, as well as my liver enzymes.  A CTScan finally saw the lesions. Between January and now, I had also been limping around with what I called "mobility issues," as I waited for MRI's scheduled @ UCLA (my ins. co. has 2x denied a PETScan) to pin down the extent of my bone mets.  Long story short, after several weeks of increasing leg pain that I and my docs thought might be coming from a disc, I ended up in the ER on 3/23 with truly excruciating leg pain, and was shocked to find out I had a fractured femur and a fracture in my pelvis that necessitated pinning my leg and a total hip replacement on 3/25.  Still waiting on the pathology report, but the MRI I had in the ER suggests significant bone mets in my pelvis -- which never really hurt that much. I'm sharing all of this b'cuz I think it illustrates what Roses-Toses wrote above -- that bone mets can feel like a lot of other issues, and may not even hurt where you're having the actual problem.   I also had a great DexaScan a few months ago that showed a significant increase in bone mass, which I find so hard to reconcile with this new dx. I hope and pray that neither you nor Roses-Toses nor Kathec nor anyone else is dealing with a recurrence, but thought my very recent experience might shed some light.  The bottom line is,  if you are experiencing persistent pain over several weeks, don't worry if it doesn't sound like someone else's pain or experience.  We're all different, and we know better than anyone else when something isn't right with our bodies.      (((Hugs)))  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 03:39PM dlb823 wrote: seaofhope ~  My first reaction to how quickly you were given any information is similar to the other women here -- that it's very out of the ordinary.  And perhaps that's one reason why you feel even more out of touch with what's happening -- because everything is moving even faster than it did for most of us, and we all felt very much like you described it -- in too much shock to cry.  A bc diagnosis is a lot to comprehend, even when delivered in smaller steps, and there's only so much of this kind of surreal news our minds let us absorb at once. I'm also hoping that by "advanced," your radiologist meant simply that it has gone into one lymph node, which is merely more advanced than if it had not.  While it would be better if it wasn't in a node, many women with bc in 1 or more nodes get treatment and are absolutely fine.  So, if that's the case, it very well may not be "advanced" in the dreadful way you're thinking.  It just means that you will probably need to have chemo, as I did and many of us here have.  "Advanced" is a very odd and unnecessarily scary choice of words when you haven't had surgery yet.  There is also a newer approach were women do chemo before surgery (neoadjuvant chemo), and in many cases this will totally eliminate any bc in your nodes.  So you have every reason to be hopeful at this point.   I'm so sorry that you're going through this, but I'm glad you found this website.  We're here for you ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 12:47PM dlb823 wrote: Maureens, it sounds to me from this post and your other one that so far you have an opinion that you have breast cancer, not a confirmed diagnosis. In order to get the most views and feedback, you should go to the forum you're already in here -- Just Diagnosed -- but rather than post in the middle of an on-going thread, look for the icon that says something like New Topic or Start A New Topic (don't have the screen open to be sure). Click on that and start your own thread.  That way, far more people will find it and be able to give you specific input for your situation. We know very little about your situation so far, but a GP telling you you have bc from mammo & u/s images is not a definitive diagnosis.  If he thinks you have bc, you need to have a biopsy.  If I was you, I would ask immediately for a referral to a breast surgeon, and let that kind of expert take it from here.  Your GP's diagnosis and advice sound way too premature for my comfort level. But please start a new thread for a lot more input.   (((Hugs))) & welcome (although I wish you didn't have a reason to be here!)   Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2010 02:49PM dlb823 wrote: SS095 ~ You're doing exactly the right thing -- getting it checked out at a breast care center at a major medical facility.  Absolutely no need to stress or panic over it.  Chances are, it's something benign.  But you need a more thorough evaluation from someone whose specialty is breast (only) care, and the peace of mind that comes with knowing exactly what that lump you're feeling is.  Be sure to get copies of your most recent mammo films on a CD to take with you.  That will avoid them having to order any more mammo views than might be absolutely necessary. Another good thing about going to the type of facility you are is that they will probably have a genetics counselor on staff to talk to you about your family history, and decide if BRCA testing might be appropriate for you.  If they consider you high risk for any reason, they will set up more frequent monitoring, as well as teach you lifestyle modifications that can reduce your future risk. Good luck, and let us know how that app't. goes ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2012 01:46AM - edited Jul 8, 2012 01:47AM by dlb823 Hi, Karen ~ I get a lot of truncal and upper arm swelling, especially when it's hot.  And yes, I think it's due to losing so many nodes. I try to get my walking in as early as possible -- like before 8:00 a.m. in the summer.  In addition to trying not to get too overheated (which is almost impossible at this time of year), what's helped me the most is always wearing a sports bra with really good side compression, and doing regular self massage.  I walk anyhere from 3 to 6 miles most days, but in the summer I limit my outdoor walks to about 2 miles, then walk some on a treadmill at the gym.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 01:17PM dlb823 wrote: sandrav, I can empathize!  I live near Palm Springs, where it hit 107 over the weekend.  I'm not in chemo now, but when I did it in 2008, it was during August, September & October -- all very hot months here.  The best advice I can give you is to forget about trying to maintain a normal activity schedule.  If you can get one major thing done each day -- rather than the list we women usually have -- that's enough.  And if it's something out of the house, do it as early as you can, so that you're not outdoors when the sun is at its hottest. I know living where it gets excessively hot (which I'm assuming you do) does have some added concerns.  But at least we don't have to brave ice storms to get to our appts, and being bald -- at least around the house -- may turn out to be a blessing if your hubby ups the thermostat too often.     (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 03:23PM - edited Mar 23, 2011 10:09PM by dlb823 Debbsie, I'm so sorry about your diagnosis, but I'm glad you've found BCO.  And yes, the waiting at the beginning -- when you know treatment is necessary, but you don't get have a handle on what it will be -- is absolutely one of the worst times.  We've all been there, so can empathize with you. Lumpectomies are typically done for smaller lesions, and, if done by a qualified breast surgeon, I haven't heard of it leaving anyone lopsisided.  And statistics show that there's no difference in outcome for a mastectomy vs. a lumpectomy + radiation -- as long as you're a candidate for the latter.  It's a good idea to start asking for copies of all your reports for any tests you have.  That way, you can research the information if you feel like it, or come here and ask questions.  Also, from here on out, be sure to take someone with you to your doctor app'ts.  We all seem to experience a weird zoning out when it hits us that we're there discussing the fact that we have bc, so good to have someone along to listen and take notes, etc.  Let us know how it goes on Friday.  (((Hugs)))     Deanna edited to fix a bunch of typos

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 12:32AM dlb823 wrote: flowergirl, either type of surgeon can do that procedure.  In fact, it's often done by a radiologist. However, if it turns out that you should need surgery (and of course we hope it doesn't!), then you may want to be in the hands of a breast surgeon from the get-go.  General surgeons do all sorts of surgeries, so IMO are rarely as experienced as breast surgeons when it comes to bc. So if a radiologist isn't going to do your biopsy, then you might want to ask your primary doc if he/she can refer you to a breast surgeon, rather than a general surgeon.  Of course many women have fine experiences with general surgeons.  But I would personally always opt for the most experienced doctor in any situation, and for a breast concern, that's obviously a breast surgeon.  Good luck!   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 12:39PM dlb823 wrote: Anxiousmama ~ I'm glad you shared this story, and I think there's more to it than just venting.  I know from personal experience that not all MRI places do an equally good job, and I would encourage you to get ahold of the report from this place when it's available, and read it for yourself.   Unfortunately, I didn't do that when I had a very poor MRI that called blurry areas "obscured," and even mixed up in the report which breast they were supposed to be looking at.  Long story short, they missed two ILC lesions that a later MRI @ UCLA found.  In my case, I believe it all worked out for the best, as I ended up @ UCLA where I got exceptional care.  But I also had a lumpectomy initially with a local surgeon who left those 2 spots she didn't know about!  So, do not look the other way about the type of care & attention you got today, and be sure their MRI is scrutinized extra carefully.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2013 12:40AM dlb823 wrote: Chatty, I'm so sorry about your Mom's symptoms. Did any of these things begin, or did she have any similar problems during chemo? I agree with you that Taxol seems suspiscious, but it also seems like your Mom would have had some reaction to the Taxol when it was given or shortly after each infusion -- not starting several weeks later, after radiation, although I don't know for sure. Have you contacted a true ALS specialist? I'm under the impression there is no definitive test for ALS, but I would think a specialist who deals with the symptoms all the time might be able to weigh in with a more compelling opinion than docs who probably don't see it as often, and may be deferring to it for lack of any research pointing to the chemo drugs. There's an on-line FDA form for reporting suspected drug reactions. Your Mom's post chemo SEs may not be unique, in which case the SEs need to be reported. http://www.fda.gov/safety/medwatch/howtoreport/ucm053074.htm I'm also under the impression that The Army Of Women has started a self-reported SE database that will hopefully fill in some major gaps in pharmaceutical company reporting. You might want to contact them and see if they can give you any additional information that could be helpful in figuring out what's going on. Praying that it's something chemo induced, and that it will resolve in time. (((Hugs))) to you and your Mom. Deanna
