Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 05:09PM - edited Jan 31, 2009 05:43PM by dlb823 Well, I gave you the short version... There were other treatment recommendations (oncology, in particular) with which UCLA did not agree.  Perhaps all community hospitals -- in spite of the Comprehensive Breast Center sign on the building -- are not as good as others.  You have one in your area that is exceptional, but many newly-dx'd women may not be able to discern the differences.  I also found noticeably more concern for my emotional well-being at the larger facility, which sounds very different from what you've experienced.  They never pushed me into anything, but always took the approach that each treatment option is your decision, and you have to decide and be totally comfortable with what you're doing.  So, maybe we've each had the best of their particular type of facility. (edit) I just wanted to add... The surgeon I used wasn't actually a general surgeon, although a couple of those names had been given to me by the breast center.  The surgeon I used is connected to the breast center and known as a breast cancer surgeon; but I found out later that she also does other cancer surgeries, such as melanomas.  When I said general surgeon, I was trying to differentiate between those who do only bc sugery, and those who do anything else, but general surgeon really wasn't the correct term.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 04:28PM dlb823 wrote: cat08 ~  I posted about how happy I am with my care @ UCLA on the other thread you have going, but wanted to comment on the suggestion to choose a large community hospital, etc.  That's what I did for my lumpectomy, and I ended up having a mast. at UCLA three months later.  The bottom line was, my wonderful (and I still love her) local general surgeon (part of a comprehensive breast center at a prominent community hospital) did the lumpectomy in spite of a poor MRI, because she was convinced she knew what she'd find.  Well, thank God, the pathology clued us all into the fact that things were not as clear and straight-forward as she'd assumed, because UCLA found two additional lesions.  On the plus side for the local comprehensive breast center, their excellent radiologist found my initial tumor.  It's also a very beautiful facility and very convenient.  I've even had my chemo and my RT there -- but only with significant input from UCLA as to both plans.  From my personal experience (and that's all any of us can really go by), a breast surgeon is far more experienced in breast cancer complexities than most general surgeons; and university teaching hospitals, especially those that are NCI-designated, offer the most cutting edge options, like my Diep flap reconstruction, which I would not have been able to do locally.  Just another opinion, although I also opted for the local breast center initially, so totally understand that point of view for many women.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 01:13AM dlb823 wrote: nwest, I think the percentage might be higher than 5%, but I also had ILC, IDC (side by side lesions), plus 2 smaller ILC and 1 small tubular (which is a rare form of IDC).  I also had some in situ bc thrown in.  In spite of all that, my breast surgeon & plastic surgeon (I had Diep recon) at UCLA encouraged me to do a unilateral mast.  They assured me that my chance of having anything happen in the other breast was only slightly higher than the general population, and they didn't see the need for a bi-lateral.  I'm satisfied with my decision and glad I have nipple sensation on one side.  But I certainly understand and support anyone who is more comfortable with a bi-lateral, to minimize future worries.  It's just such a personal decision, and one you should take whatever time you need to make.       I'm so sorry about your diagnosis and the two unsuccessful lumpectomies.  I'm curious, did you have an MRI prior to your surgeries?       Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 10:43AM - edited Feb 23, 2010 10:46AM by dlb823 Hi, Patti ~ Those are favorable stats.  er+pr+ indicates that your bc is receptive to estrogen & progesterone.  There will be a percentage attached to each one, and the % of estrogen basically tells to what degree your bc is being fueled by estrogen, so to what degree hormonal therapy will benefit you.  Her2- is less aggressive than Her2+ bc.  Prior to Herceptin, Her2+ had a fairly poor prognosis, but Herceptin has leveled the playing field.  Still, bc with your er/pr & Her2 status are considered the most responsive to chemo.   Basic aggressiveness is determined by something called a Grade of 1, 2, or 3, with 1 being the least aggressive and 3 the most.  Hope this helps ~     Deanna  Oops!!!!  Sorry, gals -- I grabbed this question from Active Topics and didn't realize it was in the Stage IV section until I went back to bookmark it!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2015 03:40PM - edited Sep 11, 2015 03:41PM by dlb823 I'm so sorry about your dx, but absolutely see all 3 docs that have been recommended. You will be surprised at how each one will add something to your knowledge bank that will help you understand your dx and make any necessary decisions, no matter whom you eventually choose. Like anything else, experience goes a long way, and barring personality issues, I would probably opt for a surgeon who specializes only in breast cancer vs. a general oncological surgeon who probably does far fewer bc surgeries each year. To add to your resources, here's a list of NCI-designated cancer centers where you will find breast (only) surgeons. If there's one within a reasonable distance of where you live, you might want to add it to your list of possibilities. http://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-role/cancer-cen... I've also had good luck finding local docs who either were residents or interned at one or more of these major cancer centers, because they have a very detailed and well thought out way of approaching things. Oh, and be sure to take someone with you to your appointments who can carefully observe and may pick up on things you might miss, because spacing out is a totally normal reaction when a surgeon starts talking about bc surgery and we realize the patient they're talking about is us. Hugs, and good luck ~ Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 05:30PM dlb823 wrote: BcMom, another thing your daughter can do is look into the high risk programs some comprehensive cancer centers now offer.  They will do a thorough risk evaluation, and, if she is determined to be more at risk than the general population, they will monitor her more closely, to catch anything suspiscious ASAP.  These programs also make women aware of the scientifically proven lifestyle modifications (exercise, diet, supplements, etc.) that can help reduce risk.  Being pro-active and knowing you're in the best of hands before any specific concern arises should also go a long way to give her peace of mind.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2014 03:24PM dlb823 wrote: Gubbyann, are you icing your nails during your chemo infusions?  That's really important, to prevent the chemo from circulating to your nailbeds, where it's doubtful you need it.   You can use ice packs or something as handy as a package of frozen peas or corn will work.  You can also use wig tape, which is very delicate to remove, to hold your nails on and try to prevent them from lifting.   So sorry this has happened to you, but icing is the best prevention I know of, and hopefully starting it now -- as long as your onc doesn't object -- will cut down on any additional damage.   (((Hugs)))  Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 12:27AM dlb823 wrote: Lovelyface ~ Yes, you're going through what a lot of us have been through.  A lot of times -- and especially depending on the size of your bc and the size of your breast -- a surgeon can get everything by going back a 2nd time and sometimes even a 3rd for a wider margin.  But at some point, continuing to go that route may not yield acceptable cosmetic results, so a mastectomy with reconstruction becomes a better choice.  I fought for weeks to keep my breast.  In the end, I gave into the mastectomy and was glad I did based on additional bc that was found in my final pathology.  But if your surgeon is willing to try to re-do your lumpectomy and save your breast, let's just hope and pray that she will be able to do that.   In the mean time, one of the things that helped me to accept my surgeon's recommendation for a mast. was looking at photos of DIEP reconstruction (what my BS & PS suggested for me), and how wonderful and natural the results are.  Not that I'd ever recommend it if you can avoid it, but when I realized I wouldn't be entirely losing a breast -- just replacing diseased breast tissue with healthy tummy tissue -- that helped me to move forward.   Good luck, and I will pray that your 2nd surgery for wider margins will be successful ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2012 04:03AM dlb823 wrote: Sorry about what you're going through, Ruthie.  I also had TC x 4 without a port.  I have very tiny veins in my one "good arm", so know how painful those extra sticks can be, especially if they hit a juncture (not sure if that's the technical name) in your hand, which I've had happen.  Here's what I've learned to protect myself as much as possible is... (1) For blood draws, have them use a butterfly needle in the back of your hand, but just watch and be sure they don't try to go too close to where two veins come together. It should be relatively painless.  (2) for procedures requiring larger needles, see if they can get it into the back of your wrist.  That's not a preferred location, but it works for me.  (3)  Be well hydrated anytime you know you'll need a needle stick. Drink a quart of water before your appointment.  (4) Ask them to use a heating pad to make your veins pop.  Most oncology offices have little ones they stick in a microwave for a few seconds.    If a nurse or tech can't get a vein on the 1st or possibly 2nd attempt, I insist that they call someone else who's better at it.  It's amazing to me how many lab techs and even some nurses just don't have good needle techniques.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 04:03PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Bonita ~  You are so newly dx'd, and that is the hardest place to be.  Once you and your doctors have a complete picture of your situation and you have a game plan in place for treatment, it gets easier.  The reality does take a while to sink in, but that's fine, because there is usually much to figure out in the beginning, so no time for a meltdown just yet.  I remember asking an RN before my mastectomy if feeling detached was normal, and she assured me it was.  A bc dx is huge for our minds to process -- all those questions & images you mentioned bouncing around in our heads -- so we go into a numb or dreamlike or detached mode, until we're in a stronger place and can deal with it differently. It's wonderful that you have a support team.  Don't hesitate to lean on them.  So often we women aren't very good at letting others take care of us, but this is the time to relax and let them do that.  You might also consider talking to a social work or psychologist who deals with bc (most breast centers have them on staff) about your children having already lost a parent.  That sounds like something a professional would have a lot of insight about and possible coping skills to give you all.  And usually those chats about how we're doing emotionally are included as part of our treatment.  Thinking of you ~ Deanna

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 01:17AM dlb823 wrote: makingway ~  I've just read the easily accessible links you provided  (Sorry, but I'm not on Medscape, and didn't feel like taking the time to register tonight.)  Anyway, after reading several articles, I was beginning to think you might be onto something very cutting edge, so to speak (absolutely no pun intended).  Then I came up with a recent retrospective-type study, and the conclusion is a bit different than the others, which, as you've pointed out, show little or no difference in outcome between SNB alone and SNB+ALND. http://www.oncologystat.com/journals/journal_scans/ On that website, search: Comparison of Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy Alone and Completion Axillary Lymph Node Dissection for Node-Positive Breast Cancer  (If I put the full link in, it's so long, it enlarges the page format here.) Anyway, it's an April 2009 study, and what concerns me is this conclusion, which reads in part: "...a trend for worse outcomes was observed in women with macroscopic nodal metastases who underwent SLNB alone. This was true for both recurrence rate... and survival rate... No differences in outcomes were observed among women with microscopic nodal metastases." So, personally, I think I would still question not doing the ALND IF your sentinel node tests macro positive, which, of course, we're all hoping it doesn't.  Another interesting thing I read is that there is no difference in outcome if you have the ALND at the same time as the SNB or later.  So, perhaps that's an angle you could use to bargain with your surgeon -- that you would consider doing the ALND in a separate procedure later, depending on the outcome of the SNB -- but that you would need time to re-evaluate it when you actually know the outcome of the SNB.  Just some additional food for thought ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2016 11:55AM dlb823 wrote: Lisa, I totally agree that you need to talk to a psychologist who specializes in oncology or an oncology social worker. I recall reading your comments in the past about anticipated progression, and if that kind of thinking is coming from your onc (which I suspect it is), then you absolutely need to find one who does not think so negatively, no less share those kinds of thoughts with their patients, because the truth is, no one can predict the course of this disease, and by projecting what will happen in the future, whoever has told you that is not acknowledging the potential of our arsenal of drugs, like the Faslodex that has rendered your mets inactive -- which is wonderful!!! I choose to look at it more as aiming for long term survival, by depending on research advances to continue to give us newer and better txs. Yes, there is always that sound track in the back of our minds about waiting for the other shoe to drop. But the busier you stay doing what you love, the dimmer and less frequent that voice can be. So please do whatever you need to do -- starting with finding a therapist you really like (and you may need to try more than one) to help you with some coping strategies, as well as some meds to get you back on track. You are also welcome to PM me any time if I can help more. (((Hugs))) and hang in there! This is tough -- especially at first. But you've hit a homerun with your "inactive" status, and there's no reason at this point to think that won't continue for many years. Deanna PS ~ I also think your onc is confusing you and/or not adequately explaining your test results. An MRI will show slightly different things than a CT or bone scan will. So if you have two "new" spots, they're probably not new, but just previously unseen, either by a different form of scanning or by a previous radiologist. The important thing to focus on is that they're INACTiVE!!!
Posts.Title: How do I accept my stage 4 prognosis? lisajo6 Iwillwinthisbattle

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 12:43AM dlb823 wrote: Irishred ~ I had multicentric ILC with 1 pos. node.  I was dx'd 2/08 and had a lumpectomy that didn't get it all.  After a second opinion, changing surgeons, another MRI, and an MRI-guided biopsy at a major university teaching hospital, I ended up with a unilateral mastectomy + Diep flap reconstruction.  That was May.  Then I had a bit of necrosis that had to be debrided, so couldn't start chemo until it healed, which was 10 weeks post-surgery.  Chemo (which I also fought) was not as bad as I'd envisioned, but I caught a very bad cold towards the end of it, and I didn't bounce back as quickly after it as I thought I would.  In retrospect, next to learning that I needed a mast, that was one of the hardest times -- those months after chemo when I still felt like crap and wondered if I would ever feel 100% again.  Then I couldn't decide about doing rads and procrastinated December, getting opinions from several rad oncs.  By the time I decided I would do them, my rad onc wanted me to wait until January 1.  Rads were not bad at all for me, and I finished up the first part of February 09.  So -- a full year of treatment due to the way things worked out -- and I still have a Stage 2 Diep surgery (cosmetic adjustments) ahead. There were definitely times I felt like I was living a nightmare.  There were times when I wondered if I'd ever feel well and energetic again.  And there were times when I got sick of being so engrossed with bc, and so focused on how I felt.  But I have to tell you, everything I did was so worth it.  I am back to walking 4 to 5 miles a day, taking extra good care of myself with nutrition & supplements, and feel that I've done and am doing everything I can to be sure it doesn't come back.  If it does, we'll then I have to believe it's in God's hands and at least I've done everything I can and won't be replaying those decisions and wondering if I should have done more. Yes, there will be days or weeks when you'll feel like crap, but the day will come when it will all be behind you.  I think your onc's timetable is just about right, and I believe it's a process well worth moving through -- especially since you have 2 positive nodes. When I was first dx'd, a bc-survivor friend of mine sent me a wonderful little piece that I read often, and I want to share it with you.    "Courage doesn't always roar. Sometimes courage is the quiet voice at the end of the day saying, 'I will try again tomorrow.' "  (Maryanne Hershey)     I wish you the courage you need to move ahead and give yourself the best chance and best odds for the future ~        Deanna

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 06:20PM dlb823 wrote: makingway ~  What I don't understand about your last post is, IF there were cancer cells in your lymph nodes at one time causing them to be swollen... and they're not swollen now... what happened to those cells?  Are you suggesting your lymph nodes disposed of them somehow, even though you still have bc in your breast?  Lymph nodes get swollen from all sorts of infectious causes, so I'm wondering if the fact that yours were noticeably swollen at some time had to do with something else going on in your body, and nothing to do with bc. As pro-natural healing as I am, I would so like for you to be right about not needing diseased nodes removed.  But I can't help believing that really skilled and dedicated breast surgeons would not take out nodes needlessly, and that there would be more research to dis-prove the need for ALND if even a handful of them were in line with the belief that it's not necessary, or even harmful re. fighting our bc. Just some thoughts I wanted to share with you, as I really do care about your outcome, and want to be sure that we've played devil's advocate with you as much as needed, if all it serves to do is reinforce your beliefs, which could well be right.  I just don't know.  But I wholeheartedly support your right to choose what surgery you do or don't have, and I don't believe a surgeon should be able to dictate that you have to have a surgery if you don't want it. Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 05:11PM dlb823 wrote: EVSF, with some types of bc, neoadjuvant chemo is preferable, partly for the reason you're bringing up -- the tumor's response can be seen.  But if the tumor has been surgically removed prior to chemo, there's nothing to observe.  And since most women wait several weeks after surgery to start chemo, that would give abnormally high tumor markers, if they ever existed, a chance to return to normal. Was your chemo given pre- or post-surgery?       I'm sorry about your Mother's diagnosis, but trust she's on a good path to complete recovery. Perhaps your Mother would also like to know about BCO?  There are groups here for women going through chemo which offer tremendous support.  Click on Forum Index above, and scroll down to the Chemotherapy section, which might be the section you've posted in -- I can't tell on this page.  Anyway, look for the February 2012 chemo group.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 09:08PM dlb823 wrote: Bettina ~ If you'll be getting Taxotere, find out if your onc's office has ice mitts or ice available.  Mine did not do either, but after finding out that ice cuts down on the Taxotere circulating to your fingers & toes (where you don't need it) and prevents nail damage, I started bringing my own.  Since I live out in the desert, where ice would melt very quickly, I found it handy to stick in a bag of frozen vegetables (peas, etc.) at the last minute, so that I could keep my fingers & toes cold during the taxotere infusion.  And it didn't make a big mess as the veggies thawed. I also used a guided imagery CD for chemo, so had that on my MP3 player.    afighter ~  Yes, definitely your own clothes.  No need for a hospital gown.   Deanna

Here's hoping the u/s guided biopsy is B9 (both spots), and when they re-do the MRI in a few months, there will be nothing there -- which will mean one or both of those WERE the spots they had originally seen and were concerned about!     Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 01:13AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Janey ~ Sorry you haven't had any responses yet to your question.  I haven't had experience with what you're asking about, but I thought I'd stop and at least bump your thread for you, hoping others who are familiar with your problem will still see it. In the mean time, I think it's really important to have your diagnosis and the recommended treatment confirmed by a breast surgeon/specialist.  Do you know if you've seen that kind of doctor yet -- someone who only deals with breast issues 24/7?  That's really the best type of doctor to confirm what you've been told, and to be sure you're getting a thorough diagnosis and the proper treatment recommendation. As far as smoking goes -- yes, it can absolutely complicate any surgical procedure because it constricts  blood flow, which impairs healing.  Can you possibly stop smoking?  I don't know off-hand the stats re. how long it takes to reverse whatever damage smoking has done to your blood vessels, but I think it would give you a better chance of having a successful duct procedure, if that's what's needed, as well as improve the outcome of any future surgery. Hope this helps some.  I'm glad you've found BCO, and I hope you'll get more input soon.   (((Hugs)))  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 05:50PM dlb823 wrote: Carol ~  Just wanted to add -- I had a somewhat similar situation to yours -- had a lumpectomy and thought I was "home free" (except for rads), only to find out 4 days later I needed a mast.  It's very hard to believe it's not just some terrible nightmare when the news blindsides you like that.  But one thing that helped me (after I switched surgeons, had more testing, and still got the same recommendation, but with proof of additional bc lurking in my breast) -- was when I learned about reconstruction options, and realized that I wasn't going to be without a breast.  I know mastectomy sounds so horrible, but reconstruction techniques (I had a Diep flap) have come such a long way.  As you try to absorb the recommendation and weigh what you want to do, maybe start to look at photos of reconstructed breasts.  That's what helped me a lot, and I hope it will also help you.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 10:19PM dlb823 wrote: Hello, mrs-mjt ~  There was recently a pretty good thread on just that topic.  I'll try to give you a link to it here: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/96/topic/726075?page=1 Like many procedures, our experiences seem to be varied -- from not thinking it was too bad, to extremely unpleasant.  I think some of it depends on the anxiety level you have going into it, and some depends on the skill of the doctors doing it.  The biggest PRO for it is that it allows doctors to find and biopsy tiny lesions very early.  So, although it wasn't the most pleasant test, I'm very grateful I had one, because the two tiny lesions I had were bc and could not be seen on ultrasound.  One question I might ask is if the lesion(s) they saw look spiculated (like tiny spiders), which is sometimes an indication that the lesion is bc -- or, at least that's what I was told.  Depending on where you're being treated, I might also ask about the experience level of the person performing the biopsy.  I had mine at a large teaching hospital, and later wondered if it was the first one the doctor performing it had ever done. If I ever need one in the future, I might be a bit reluctant to be a new doctor's first patient for this particular procedure.   Good luck, and please keep us posted on your experience and outcome. Thinking of you ~ Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 08:04PM dlb823 wrote: A1B1 ~ I haven't used a breast surgeon in AZ, but my husband recently had a surgical consultation at the Mayo Clinic in North Phoenix, and we were overwhelmingly impressed with everything about the experience.  They are extremely responsive, totally patient-centered, and lead you through every little step.  And they will have everything under one roof for you and be able to coordinate all aspects of her care.  I would be surprised if you don't get some specific recommendations for surgeons there as others see your question.   Thank goodness you've spotted potential problems with her current medical options!  I think finding the right breast surgeon and medical team will go a long way to easing your mind, her mind, and probably greatly improving her outcome -- especially if her local surgeon is inexperienced with bc!  Good for you for getting involved!     (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 03:30PM dlb823 wrote: Kris ~ I was in a similar situation and went back and forth many times trying to decide what to do.  I had a left mastectomy (with Diep reconstruction), but my primary bs docs @ a major breast center and the local rad onc I'm using both recommended rads, which, after weeks of indecision, I finally decided to do.  In my case, their specific concerns were that my 1 positive node had extracapsular extension, and there was also a 1mm unspecified margin on a tiny piece of trimmed tissue that to everyone's surprise (including my BS) contained a 1mm bit of lobular.  One thing a rad onc pointed out to me as I was researching what to do, is that 99% of the statistics out there don't apply to us, because all the research is based on women who have had lumpectomies.  But, since I've started rads, a friend who is trying to make the same decision found this: http://www.dslrf.org/breastcancer/content.asp?CATID=0&L2=3&L3=5&L4=0&PID=&sid=130&cid=389 Another tidbit of information that also tipped my decision in favor of doing rads is something someone on another thread here shared with me that her BS had explained to her.  He said that chemo works in the blood (which we all know), but that due to our surgery, the blood supply to the breast and axilla have been compromised.  That concerned me.   I'm certainly not trying to persuade you one way or the other, but just wanted to share a couple of thoughts that helped me in reach a decision.  For what it's worth, I just had tx #21 of 28 today, and so far, it's been very easy.
Posts.Title: RADS VS. NO RADS mom_of_2 Alyad

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 01:53AM dlb823 wrote: makingway ~  I, too, was very hesitant to have level 1 & 2 nodes removed after my sentinel node, which had been called clear in the OR, turned out to be positive with not only bc, but with two kinds of bc cells and extracapsular tumor extension.  (Don't know how they missed all that in the OR!)  Anyway, prior to my mast & ALND, I had my sister, who is in bc research and a bc survivor, ask umpteen doctors if there was any way I could safely forego the ALND, and not one of them thought it was prudent or wise to do so.  I know there's been an ongoing discussion about this on the "Natural Girls" thread, but I just don't believe the research offered is in support of no ALND IF your sentinel node tests positive.  I believe, after reading it, that the research is referring to too many ALNDs when there is no justification for it -- as in the sentinel node is clear.  And, even then, according to my sister, who has been in cancer research for 25 years, that is no assurance the bc can't bypass the sentinel node and turn up in another one.  Evidently it's rare, but it can happen.  Of course, we all need to follow our instincts and our hearts, but I just wanted to share my  experience with you, because I had gotten opinions from multiple top surgeons.  I ended up having 17 nodes removed and also had rads and, thank God, have no lymphedema.  But I think that is totally due to a superb surgeon and rad onc.      Deanna
Posts.Title: Refuse To Do Surgery makingway nelia48

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 12:28PM dlb823 wrote: makingway ~ Rose brings up an excellent point.  Do you know yet if you'll need chemo?  If you will, has anyone suggested doing it first?  There were several women on my August 08 chemo board who had neoadjuvant chemo, and went from having multiple positive nodes to no trace of bc in them. And, as far as researching and not going along with "the program," many of us have researched ad naseum every aspect of our pathologies, and if we really needed a mast, and what is the best reconstruction, and if we really needed an ALND, and chemo, and rads.  But as much as I read and talked to people, this rather obscure research questioning the benefit of ALND never surfaced.  So, I'm just trying to look at it with an open mind, and ask if perhaps this is a school of thought to which there is enough credence for you to be safe with the (albeit unorthodox) decision not to do an ALND, assuming you can convince your surgeon.  And like every other decision we make in this journey, I think what it comes down to is the question of how you would feel if you follow this "unapproved" (at least by your BS) path, and ever had a recurrence?   Would you still feel that you did the right thing?  And, from what you've said, it seems like you are pretty convinced there are benefits to leaving your lymph nodes intact.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2010 10:30PM dlb823 wrote: flagstage, many BSs & oncs do not do any type of scan unless we have a pain or other symptom that needs to be ruled out.  But thorough exams including MRIs are often part of routine followup, as is bloodwork that will often (but not always) indicate a possible problem.  Most of us have checkups every 6 months for at least 5 years, so if you're not happy with the followup suggested by your current medical team, it's never too late to find a new onc to do your followup.  And what you've observed about support groups is all too true.  The main place I've been treated (UCLA) actually has 3 support groups -- one for newly diagnosed women, one for Stage 4 women, and one for everyone else.  That way, each group's special concerns are better addressed.  Of course this can only work at a facility that treats a lot of women, but you might want to check around and see if anyone in your area does it that way.   When I was going through chemo I joined an art therapy class for bc patients at our local hospital and had a similar experience.  Eventually, I stopped going because at that stage in my treatment, it was too depressing to keep losing people out of the class. I'm glad you've found us tonight, and I hope BCO will turn out to be as helpful a support group for you as it is for many of us.  I finished my active treatment almost 2 years ago, and I have to tell you -- while it doesn't happen overnight, it definitely gets easier as you move forward.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 11:26AM dlb823 wrote: Have you tried Melatonin?  I'm finally taking it with great results, although when I first tried it during chemo, it didn't seem to work for me.  But now that chemo and rads are well behind me, it seems to work great.  I've also recently added just a tiny bit of Progesterone creme to my regimen.  Yes, I know it's controversial, but there is a thread about it here if you want to read up on it and see if it's something you would want to consider.  All I can tell you is that I am, for the first time in almost 2 years, sleeping soundly through the night again now that I'm using it + Melatonin. Oh, and I also walk for an hour to an hour and a half almost every day, which I know has been a huge stress-reliever, as well as helping me to recover physically from tx.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 05:46PM dlb823 wrote: I had a mast, chemo & rads.  The reason for the rads was quite specific.  I had a positive node with extracapsular extension (bc growing out of the node), and I also had a 1mm, unspecified margin because of a tiny "surprise" bc lesion my BS didn't know about.  It was only found during the final pathology, so the margins on that little bit of tissue had not been inked, and there was no way to tell at that point what it had been 1mm from.  So, from my experience, I would be concerned if you have specific things like this in your pathology.  Nikola, in your situation, if you have lingering concerns about what you've been told, maybe get a second opinion, just to ease your mind.  Jackie, I think your situation sounds like you would benefit from RT, but I'm not a doctor, and am just basing my opinion on my own experience and because of it, would be concerned enough about a .5mm margin against a chest wall to want RT.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2014 12:53PM - edited Dec 31, 2014 01:22PM by dlb823 I realize this thread is three weeks old now, but I'm kind of with She on this one. As someone who has always been very alternative minded (never used meds prior to bc dx) and followed my ND's advice on hormone balancing post-tx, up to but not including using an estrogen supplement (I used Testosterone and DHEA)... I think the time to balance your hormones is PRIOR to a bc dx, which sadly few of us even know about at that point. After those bc cells exist and know how to reproduce, I think it's really a crap shoot, and very easy to trigger their proliferation in spite of the thoughtful advice of the best holistic practioners in the world -- just b'cuz they are so mutant and adaptive. I would not give them any known "fuel." Just the opinion of someone who did not do an A/I due to a serious adverse reaction to one of them, and ended up with bone mets, which might have happened anyway, or might have been destined because of the delay in finding and treating some of my bc (detailed on my bio page), or any number of reasons. But there's absolutely no way I would tell a woman who has had bc to take estrogen now. I realize suicidal thoughts are a very serious issue, but you also have no assurance that estrogen will fix that. I'd seek out as many docs (conventional, alternative, everything...) as you possibly can until you find answers other than estrogen. And I have a friend who takes 3x the recommended amount of Melatonin (12 mg) and swears by it. Deanna (edited to fix a typo)

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 03:18PM - edited Jul 7, 2011 03:19PM by dlb823 SusansGarden, as far as "saving" chemo -- I think the answer is both yes & no.  Yes, if the Oncotype-DX says the risk of chemo might outweigh its benefit; then it's probably better to save it.  But no if the Oncotype shows a high risk of future metastasis, because I think you'd be better off trying to prevent that from happening in the first place, rather than waiting to treat it after it happens.  As my BS at UCLA pointed out, in terms of cancer, bc is a relatively easy one to treat successfully as long as it's confined to breast tissue.  Once it gets into your organs, it's an entirely different ballgame.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 02:36PM dlb823 wrote: halfcan, I took a much simpler approach than the above.  I brought along 1 bag of frozen peas or corn in a little lunch type cooler.  (The smaller veggies like these make the package more pliable than larger cut ones.)  During my taxotere infusion, I rotated the bag from one hand to another, then one foot to another, to keep my nailbeds cold.   If you're using store-sealed bags, I don't personally see a problem with using them for dinner.  During one of my infusions, when I'd missed lunch and was starving, I actually opened the bag when I was done icing with it and snacked on the contents. The idea of using frozen veggies came from the very common practice of using a bag of frozen veggies as a coldpack, like for common kid's injuries. We're all different, but I didn't have any problems (after my initial infusion when I didn't know about icing) with my very simplistic method.  I guess my point is, do what's comfortable for you, but as long as your fingertips and toes stay cold (too cold for the Taxotere to circulate much there), you shouldn't have a problem, and don't need to worry about doing it correctly or perfectly.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 03:09PM - edited Sep 3, 2011 03:10PM by dlb823 Hi, Kelly ~ I can throw out a couple of thoughts re. what seems at first glance to be conflicting information.  With the exception of a newly revised edition, many copies of Dr. Love's book in circulatation are 10+ years old, possibly predating the use of diagnostic MRI for bc, which now finds lesions that are quite small (I think as small as 2mm), which mammos do not see.  So as far as size goes, there's been a bit of a change in finding much smaller lesions, and if your copy of The Breast Book has a 1990's publication date, that might be one explanation. Beyond that, most bc lesions are not typically round like a BB.  They are more often irregular and/or spiculated (shaped a bit like a spider).  So I think both statements are pretty true.  The tiny round things we sometimes feel in our breasts are often cysts, clogged sweat glands, or other benign things.  OTOH, with MRI, we are also finding much smaller malignant lesions. The bottom line is, no lump, thickening or other irregularity should ever be ignored.  It's always best to get the opinion of a breast surgeon/expert.    Hope this helps ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2016 11:30PM dlb823 wrote: Scared, I just took a quick peek at some of your other posts, and one of them mentions that you have multicentric disease, which, combined with a positive node, might be at least part of the reason MSK seems to be leaning towards chemo for you, even without the benefit of an Oncotype. I also just pulled up recent research that, just perusing the headline, seem to say that pre-adjuvant chemo might be a wiser choice with fewer risks than axillary node dissection (ALND). In other words... if I am understanding the limited information on this link, as I didn't try to get access to read the entire article, this is very forward thinking to save your level 1 & 2 nodes. But that said, it doesn't mean it's necessarily the only approach, as you've already learned. http://www.uptodate.com/contents/neoadjuvant-thera... As you've probably know by now, neoadjuvant chemo is most often done in two situations -- to shrink an extremely large tumor (as Gracie pointed out above), or with TNBC, which is especially aggressive. And what it sounds like is that perhaps observationally they've figured out that doing this saves women from needing ALND, which can lead to a lifetime risk of lymphedma. If I was in your situation, I would probably do a couple of things. First, I would ask MSK to explain their rationale for recommending neoadjuvant chemo. They should be able to point to research (i.e. the article linked here or others) that is influencing their current thinking. Secondly, because even top docs always agree on what's best, I might get a third opinion from another NCI-designated cancer center. I think (not entirely sure) Johns Hopkins does long distance consults. Otherwise, NYU is known to be very good, and Mt. Sinai is another option if you're in the city. Hope this helps some. I'm so sorry you're in the position you are. It's surreal enough to get a bc dx, but then to get conflicting opinions must be incredibly confusing. But my guess is that MSK most likely is on the leading edge of what's being done, and that you are fortunate to have access to them for tx. Hugs, Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 12:24AM dlb823 wrote: Lynn, some women actually do report developing breast cancer in the same breast and same area several years after sustaining a blow to a breast.  It's highly unlikely that breast cancer would appear as suddenly as soon as 4 or 5 few months after an injury, so this most likely is something else going on, like an internal bruise that hasn't healed.  However, depending on your age and what this upcoming appointment reveals, since you had such a hard blow, it's probably good to at least be aware of that theory so that you will keep an extra-close eye on that area and be sure to keep up with regular future screenings.    Please keep us posted on what you find out.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2011 01:37PM - edited Oct 18, 2011 02:21PM by dlb823 Grace, I definitely think things get better as you get further away from your dx and tx.  However, I also think we all need to do things that help us "detach" (as time moves on -- and it may still be a bit early for you) from our bc identity -- although I doubt if it ever entirely goes away. One thing that's helped me a lot is getting out each morning for a long walk. Somehow the combination of enjoying nature, getting exercise (I walk about 4 or 5 miles, weather and time permitting), and just having that hour or so to process my thoughts about what I've been through is extremely anxiety-relieving, as well as helping with the aches & pains of low estrogen.  And exercise has been shown to decrease our recurrence risk by something like 35%.  So, as someone else here told me, when I walk I feel like every step is a step away from breast cancer. The other thing I've noticed being a huge help in moving me forward and out of the the breast cancer patient mentality is getting away and out of my normal routine.  I started noticing that each time I went away for a weekend, I felt a lot better (more like my old self) when I returned.  I honestly think that experiencing new things and meeting new people who don't know about our bc goes a huge way to resetting our thought process. But I know it's a process and never entirely goes away.  I was recently on a flight from Palm Springs to Dallas, and as the captain announced the connecting gates, he said "B9" -- and I have to tell, for the moment, I had such a strong emotional reaction that I felt like crying, which seems silly, but was very real when it happened.   The subconscious programming we've experienced is very powerful and may take some effort on our part to recognize and overcome, maybe starting with turning off the TV, for example, or only watching home & food channels, if you want to watch something that won't remind you of bc.     (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 11:58AM dlb823 wrote: pil ~  In many cases, the radiologist at the facility where you have your biopsy will actually call you with the results, which then go to your primary doctor or family doc who will talk to you about a referral to a breast surgeon -- unless you've had an excisional biopsy done by a breast surgeon, in which case details could come directly from that office/surgeon.  I would ask whomever gives you the news over the phone to also fax you a copy of the biopsy report right away.  If they can't for any reason, then call the place where you had it done and ask if you can pick up a copy for your records. Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2015 12:39AM dlb823 wrote: Meganrenee, your doctor is using some phrases that don't seem consistent with normal biopsies for breast cancer. Perhaps this is because the lump was aspirated, rather than having a true needle biopsy performed. I'm not sure. But "necrotic cancer" and "not tested for cells" and other wording sounds a bit unusual to me. And while it's true that breast cancer, which often takes many years to become large enough to be imaged or felt, normally doesn't change a lot in 3 months, I don't understand his comment about it being contained, especially if the lump was aspirated. If the lump doesn't go away now that it's been aspirated, I think I would ask for a referral to a breast surgeon/specialist, where you can be sure of getting an appropriate evaluation. Not saying that your doctor isn't doing that, but the technique and wording he's using just doesn't ring true for me -- unless he was 100% sure from the get-go that it wasn't possibly malignant, and was looking for something entirely different than bc, like infection. Just my take on what you've written, although I haven't read your previous posts, which may shed more light on your situation. Hugs, Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2016 01:54PM dlb823 wrote: Absolutely... living w/mbc. I was dx'd a little over 2 years ago (after almost 6 years) with diffuse and extensive bone mets. Like you, and like just about everyone else, the often old stats on Dr. Google made me feel like my life was over, or at least headed downhill very fast. But what a turnaround getting on a good med (as well as getting a surgery I needed) was! I'm now on my second regimen (2 meds this time, including one that's only been on the market a short time), and in spite of some ups and downs, living a fairly "normal" life -- even with extensive (but stable or improving) bone mets in many places. The fact that your mother did not recur for 19 years -- as devastating as it is, especially after all that time -- is probably a very favorable thing, as is the fact that she only has one bone met, which hopefully will respond beautifully to a hormonal tx or perhaps a bit of radiation. (((Hugs))) and hang in there! I'm glad you've found us! If I can offer one piece of advice, be sure the oncologist she sees is as positive as we are here! If not, run to another one! The last thing your mother needs is any doom & gloom or even a shred of doubt from one who isn't on the "living w/mbc" and "managing it similar to a chronic condition" page! Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2009 11:07PM - edited Mar 1, 2009 11:10PM by dlb823 strongasmymom ~  I'm sorry to hear about your Mom's bc dx and pending surgery, but think it's wonderful that you are available to help her and searching here for suggestions to make that easier. If your Mom is in good health (other than the bc) and good physical shape, and if her home doesn't pose navigating challenges (such as a lot of stairs), I think she will probably be able to take care of herself after a week at home, especially if her drains are out by then (have you been told about those?), and especially if her pantry and frig are well stocked, and if she has friends or neighbors that she can call if she needs anything.  Or, if you can arrange for some of them to check in with her daily -- like neighbors seeing if they can pick up anything she needs -- that would be even better, because she may not be comfortable asking for help. You may also need to plan out some practical aids for her, to be sure she doesn't have to move or lift anything heavy.  Even a 1/2 gal. of milk will be too much at first.  She won't be able to drive for several weeks, if she normally does.  And do her dogs need to be walked?  I think that would be difficult with a bilat & 4 dogs, as she probably won't be allowed to push or pull with either arm initially.  So, although she may be able to take care of herself with some arrangements made for these things, if you can spend more than a week with her, especially if she lives alone, I'm sure she would appreciate the company as much as the care.  When you're confined to home, the days can be awfully long and boring. Good luck to you both, and let us know us know what else we can share with you to ease your mind.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2016 04:17PM dlb823 wrote: Truper, if I was in your situation, I would absolutely seek a second opinion with a breast surgeon at a major university hospital like the ones listed in the link I'll give you. Once you do, I think the difference will be clear. If you absolutely cannot get to one due to distance, I would suggest calling the closest one to see if they can recommend a local surgeon. Often there will be someone in your area who has trained at one of these facilities so possesses the thoroughness you find at the bigger institutions. And read my bio page for an example of what can go wrong that you and a general surgeon may not even realize at the time. https://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-role/cancer-ce... The other benefit of places like those on the list is that you have all the specialties under one roof or on the same campus and used to working with a multidisciplinary/team approach. So, for example, if the team thinks you'll need radiation, for example, you won't start down a path with a recon that isn't compatible with RT. Hope this helps. Good luck! Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2016 01:50PM - edited Oct 10, 2016 01:53PM by dlb823 scared, it might help to think of it this way... The bc in your breast is not nearly as concerning as bc in lymph nodes, which indicates your bc clearly knows how to travel. Having chemo first is a systemic vs. local tx. If you have surgery first, you will have to wait several weeks to heal from it before you can start chemo. (You cannot start chemo with an open wound.) So, in essence, having chemo first gets after the bc cells that have already left the breast and have the most logical potential to get beyond the lymph nodes and metastasize. As far as hating the decision... I think one of the keys is to find a medical team you absolutely trust and let them guide you. Without that trust, you will always be second guessing their decisions, which really makes things miserable. This is another reason -- beyond simply a tie-breaker, so to speak -- why a 3rd opinion might be helpful -- to have one more team to evaluate and compare for comfort level and trust going forward.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2017 08:13PM dlb823 wrote: Grannax, the fatigue is very much related to lowered blood counts. Oncs watch granulocytes or neutrophils or ANC most closely (the part of the white blood cells that fight infection), but Ibrance can also lower red blood counts, for which fatigue (not enough oxygen) is a major symptom, along with shortness of breath, racing heartbeat, dizziness, anemia, and other common Ibrance SEs. VonHilda, welcome to BCO. Yes, Ibrance and other meds can mess with our internal thermostats, as can a lack of estrogen. I'm no longer on Ibrance, but when I was (for 19 months), I found the SEs got much better over time. Hope the bruise turned out to be nothing serious.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2017 06:16AM dlb823 wrote: Living, while your TMs are trending upward, they are still relatively low. My TMs have proven to be very accurate, but still my UCLA onc has always said she isn't concerned about an increase unless they double in one month's time. After I had been on Faslodex + Ibrance for 1.5 years, my TMs did start to rise kind of dramatically (took about 6 mos. to double, but were also 10x higher than yours are now and making 100 pt. jumps), at which point my bone scan was still stable, but chest CT revealed something new possibly going on in my liver-- too small to distinguish or biopsy, but not there previously -- so we did change my regimen to Xeloda. And my liver numbers were also on the rise, but came down very quickly after 1 month on Xeloda, as did my TMs. If I was in your situation, I might try to wait until it's been at least 3 mos. to get scanned, just because if something new is brewing, it may be too soon to be picked up. I might also want to speak to your new onc and not rely on the judgment call of a PA. She might be entirely right, but I would still want to know what an onc thinks, and if you can reasonably wait a bit longer to get scanned. Other things that can make the CA27-29 go up are inflammation and some meds, so a rise doesn't necessarily mean something is going on. But based on my experience, I think your situation merits watching and scans within a reasonable time -- hopefully just to rule out any progression. Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2009 06:22AM dlb823 wrote: Definitely see if there is a large enough hospital (like a university teaching hospital) in your area.  They often offer "High Risk" programs for women with a family history of bc and/or other significant risk factors.  They will evaluate a woman's risk, and if it is higher than the normal population, will offer more frequent screenings to ensure peace of mind, and that anything out of the ordinary is caught as early as possible.  Here is a list of some of the hospitals (by state) that are most likely to have this sort of program:  http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html If there isn't one near you, then a Comprehensive Breast Center or breast surgeon/specialist is what you want to look for.   Good luck ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2016 12:46AM dlb823 wrote: Barb, there are threads here specifically related to Ibrance that might interest you: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topics/... https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topics/... https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topics/... If you're on Facebook, there is also a private group there for Ibrance users. Message me for details and a link. It may sound counterintuitive, but the best thing for the fatigue caused by Ibrance is getting more exercise, if that's possible for you. Walking or swimming, for example, can really counteract the fatigue. For the nausea, first see if you can tie it to any specific foods that you can eliminate. Also, be sure to take Ibrance after a sizeable meal and with a full glass of water. Maybe try taking it at a different time of day. Ginger is helpful for nausea -- ginger tea, crystallized ginger. If none of these works sufficiently, ask your onc for a nausea med or a different nausea med. Emend is usually very good. Damon-RV'er, welcome to BCO. I'm glad you've found us. You might be interested in joining the Bone Met thread, here: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topics/... Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 12:05PM dlb823 wrote: The problem as I see it is is that each of our bc's is very unique and individual -- both in terms of probable causation and genetic and hormonal makeup.  What concerns me about totally holistic approaches to healing bc is that, from what I saw when I explored them prior to deciding on tx, is that holistic practicioners aren't educated in and don't take any of these individual differences (Her2, hormone responsiveness, or even Grade, for example) into account before assuring you they have the cure -- or at least they never asked me those questions.  From my personal experience, the ones I spoke to were very naive about the complexity of bc, believing they could cure me without surgery or chemo based on having "cured" a handful of others of some types of cancer.   Another thing that's always concerned me about a 100% natural approach is that many bc survivors were extremely healthy -- including being vegans or vegetarians, and runners or similiar athletes -- when they were dx'd, which tells me the cure or prevention for everyone's bc probably doesn't lie in food and exercise alone, although I think those are both extremely important elements of preventing a recurrence. This is not to say that I don't believe in a holistic lifestyle (I do!) and Eastern medicine  for many things, including complementary tx for bc.  I've sought out and used both integrative docs and naturopathic docs at various stages in my tx.  I just worry about possibly losing the window of opportunity to treat early stage bc while it's still early stage, and, quite honestly, Blubelle, the website for the Optimum Institute looks like a wonderful place for complementary care, but not the place I would solely partner with if my life was at risk.  I really hate to poke holes in anyone's belief in their doctors or treatment plan, as I think belief is so important.  And I've actually known women with metastatic bc who did extremely well on holistic only txs for many years -- perhaps better than many who use conventional only, although, again, I haven't been privy to their individual stats, so my comment is observational and very general.  But, assuming what you are dealing with is early stage invasive bc, I think you might want to check back with Stanford (assuming you meant Stanford in Palo Alto) or a comparable institution (UCLA, UCSF, USC, etc.), at least for a second opinion on your progress to date.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 10:01PM dlb823 wrote: Mamita ~  If both of the 2 nodes they removed were positive, having additional nodes removed would be the advisable thing to do.  When your onc said he wants more nodes out to prevent a recurrence, he may have meant to be sure no positive nodes or stray cells (since you've already had chemo) in any nodes have been left, which would be cause for concern -- not that removing healthy nodes would help prevent a recurrence. Do you know what sort of margin they had on the chest wall side?  While you may have had clear margins, perhaps it was minimal enough to cause concern in that location?  I think if they had seen anything new or concerning on your mammo, they would have explained that too you, so I have a feeling the concern is re. a very minimal margin near your chest wall. So sorry you're dealing with this surprise turn of events, but that seems to happen all too often.  But it's good that your new surgeon had a prestigious tumor board weigh in, and it doesn't sound like a decision you have to make too quickly, so you probably have some time to let the recommendation sink in and weigh your choices.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 04:25PM dlb823 wrote: spacebmt ~ I'm very sorry to hear about your Mother.  From what you've told us, it sounds like she had very appropriate care, but, sadly, some types of breast cancer are just extremely aggressive and those frequently progress very quickly, no matter what the course of treatment.  My guess is, if she did not have a CT scan initially (which there was no indication she needed), the metastisis may have been there all along.   Some doctors are starting to recommend radiation after a mastectomy, but this is a very new trend, and not the standard of care as yet.  And radiation is actually done to prevent a recurrence in the breast.  I don't believe it would have prevented what happened to your Mother. Your Mother's progression after the metastisis was discovered sounds especially fast, which must have been devastating to your family.  But it also leads me to believe that she may have had one of the extremely aggressive types of breast cancer that occasionally seem unstoppable, no matter what is done.  I'm so sorry.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 04:38PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Joanne ~ Grades 1, 2 & 3 are determined visually, based on how much the cells in your lesions have mutated (changed) from normal cells.  The diagnosis is based on the pattern of the cells -- from just slightly changed, to growing in a much more erratic pattern. Her2 is determined with a laboratory test.  It can be done with a basic test from a biopsy sample, but unless it is strongly + or -, that result is not definitive, and needs to be sent out for a more sensitive test (FISH) that takes longer.  This is normally done with the surgical pathology.  Multiple tumors are not that uncommon.  It's called multifocal disease if they're all in the same quadrant and multicentric when in different quadrants.  Sometimes they're little satellite lesions, and sometimes they're entirely different types of bc.  (I had both IDC and ILC lesions.)  Your surgical pathology will detail each one, as well as your sentinel node, for a more complete picture.  Multifocal or multicentric disease does not necessarily mean a more aggressive bc, but it does mean more aggressive surgery (a mx) is necessary to be sure none is left behind and assure the best cosmetic outcome with reconstruction. Hope this helps!    Deanna
Posts.Title: 3 tumors in one breast--no Her2 test done yet Joanne58 dlb823

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 01:04PM dlb823 wrote: Totally normal, and it does get better over time.  One thing that I am almost OCD about now is hand washing.  I wash them immediately upon returning home from any shopping, errands, etc.  I also take immunity building supplements I didn't take pre-bc, such as Green Tea Extract, a mushroom extract, etc., curcumin, etc., and these all seem to help.    If you haven't already, you may want to ask your primary doc or onc to check your WBCs & RBCs.  Knowing where you are with those can help you know if you need to supplement, etc.  Obviously chemo, but also RT, can greatly impact them, and it may take a year or more for them to return to a strong normal range.       Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2017 04:00PM dlb823 wrote: Kandy, it's "packaged differently" because it's actually missing solvent ingredients that are in Taxol, and those are what cause allergic reactions to Taxol or Taxotere for most patients. http://www.breastcancer.org/research-news/abraxane... From that article: Taxol uses a solvent to dissolve its main ingredients so the medicine can enter the bloodstream. These solvents can make Taxol harder to tolerate while being given. Usually women take medicine before receiving Taxol to minimize any reactions to the solvents. Abraxane doesn't use a solvent, which can make it easier to tolerate and also means that women don't need to take medicine before receiving it. You should be good!

Are you thinking of looking for yet another onc? And, Artist, ohmygosh, from your explanation of events, I would think your onc would have had plenty of time for ascites to cross her mind if she'd been at all focused on you. I know choices may be limited in the mountains, but I find it very hard to excuse her lack of recognizing or even considering ascites in your situation. Thank goodness you went somewhere else! Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 11:23AM dlb823 wrote: I totally agree with the exercise recommendations.  It makes a huge difference, and even starting slowly will quickly build stamina.   I also wanted to say something about the migraines.  I had to get off caffeine prior to my mastectomy, have not gone back to it, and have not had a headache in those 5 months.  I was never a big coffee drinker -- just a couple of cups a day, and at one point, after an earlier lumpectomy, I'd even switched to chai, because coffee didn't appeal to me.  But, I had headaches probably 2 or 3 times a week that I never even connected to the caffeine.  Now that I'm totally off it, no headaches -- even during chemo.  Another thought for your sister... Is she using any nutritional supplements?  A quality natural multi-vitamin/mineral is essential, and there are other nutrients that are important, depending on her individual eating habits/needs.  I've always used a lot of stuff, but during chemo I added B6 for  neuropathy, and I've recently added Biotin, which a post-chemo acquaintance with noticeably thick hair regrowth said was helping her.  Just another area to look into if you haven't already...   Take care, and best to you both ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 06:18PM dlb823 wrote: Taxotere does a number on our joints, as well as causing a lot of foot neuropathy.  The supplement B6 can help some with the latter, and getting exercise, even if it's difficult at first, also helps.   When I finished chemo (TCx4), I could barely climb a flight of stairs, and I had a weird, extreme pain in my right shin.  Both took several months to resolve, but eventually I was walking 5+ miles a day, as were others in my chemo & rads groups here who went through similar things.  So hang in there!  It will get better, but it just takes more time than anyone ever tells us going into it for our bodies to heal and rebuild.   (((Hugs)))   Deanna

While bc certainly isn't common at your age, it's not unheard of, so dismissing you based on your age and stalling 2 mos. on ordering an u/s when you have an inverted nipple and suspiscious lump doesn't give me a lot of confidence in that doctor.  I am also of the firm opinion that many general surgeons do not see enough bc to recognize uncommon problems, nor can they possibly keep up on everything about breast-related problems the way a breast only surgeon does.    Another thing you might do is call the closest NCI-designated cancer center, like UCSF or Stanford, and ask them if they could recommend a surgeon in your area.  Perhaps they can recommend someone who has previous been @ UCSF, etc.  I've found great doctors from those kind of referrals.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 01:03PM dlb823 wrote: yasmin ~  Definitely get a second opinion.  Not all oncs recommend the same course of action or the same chemo regimen.  Also, you had a somewhat complex dx with more than one type of bc.  For that reason alone, I think a second opinion's a very good idea. Without studying up on your dx, if you were my daughter, I'm pretty sure I would want you to do the chemo.  On the other hand, unless you really need it, I'm not crazy about the recommendation for AC.  Adriamycin has potential for some serious SEs, including heart damage and also a very small (2%) but none-the-less significant chance of it causing leukemia.  Taxotere & Cytoxin (TC) is a newer regimen that you may want to ask about if a second opinion onc doesn't suggest it. Good luck with your decision, and please keep us posted, especially if you go for a second opinion ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 02:45PM - edited Dec 28, 2010 05:09PM by dlb823 Heather, I'm not sure what's going on, but my rule of thumb is that we should always have definitive explanations for something like swollen glands or a pain that doesn't go away.  And, from the above, it doesn't sound like you've had that.  And you are absolutely right to be concerned about a tech assuming what a lump is based on your age, especially when you have swollen nodes in multiple locations.  If I was in your position, I would get copies of your mammo & u/s films (the center where you had them will put them on a CD for you if you ask), and take them to another doctor, along with any other recent test results, such as the pathology reports from your thyroid biopsies.  Since breast cancer is uppermost in your mind, I would start with the breast cancer department at one of these NCI-designated cancer centers.  http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html   If it turns out that there is nothing concerning going on in your breast (which we'll certainly hope & pray), a facility like any of these will have enough other departments & experts to get to the root of your problem, which may not be from your breast at all.  But it definitely sounds like something is going on that needs to be identified and treated. Good luck, and please keep us posted!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2017 04:46AM dlb823 wrote: Just seeing this now, Kay, and haven't read through everyone's responses. But I can share with you that I also had pain that sort of shot up my right leg and had me hobbling around on a cane. It started around the time I was dx'd w/mets and progressively worsened over almost 3 mos., until I ended up in the ER in absolutely excruciating pain, only to find out that I actually had pathologic fractures in my femur and pelvis that required a titanium rod in my femur and a total hip replacement. Since that time, I have suggested to several mets sisters who were experiencing leg pain to have their femur & pelvis checked with an MRI, to see if that's possibly what was going on, and each time it was. So it's not uncommon. Obviously I can't say for sure that's what's going on with you, but there's enough of a risk that you absolutely should ask for an MRI. In my case, the pain was not where the fractures were until it got so severe I couldn't move and was literally screaming and crying at the same time -- probably when the fractures totally gave way. But prior to that, it was just worsening pain in my shin, shooting up my leg, so I had no reason to suspect something was going on where it was. Hopefully, that's not what's going on, but the way your pain is presenting definitely raises the suspicion of a fracture. Please keep us posted! Hugs, Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 02:07PM dlb823 wrote: Deannie, obviously it's impossible to guess what's going on from a brief description, even if we were doctors, which we're not.  But my first thought is that if you were carefully screened 2 years ago, it's questionable whether "a good sized lump" would appear in that time frame.  For most of us, breast cancer takes many years to grow to the point where it's detectable either with imaging or by self exam.  Also, the fact that you had 4 prior benign lesions may also point to this one being benign.  But definitely get it checked out ASAP.  And as far as your fiance goes, I understand your fear, but if he's the kind of man worth committing the rest of your life to, I would hope that he loves you enough not to run away from a health problem (hopefully just a scare).  Would you, if positions were reversed?      Deanna

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2013 05:08PM dlb823 wrote: Sunnyca, the only thing I would add to the above is to ask if you had an MRI prior to your surgery. And, yes, I went back 3 mos. later and had a mx, because the lesions were in different areas of my breast. In your situation, since you are Her2+, it's also important to start chemo & Herceptin ASAP, so additional surgery probably isn't in your best interest right now, as long as you're sure everything was found prior to your lumpectomy. Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2017 10:43PM dlb823 wrote: I had a similar experience with Letrozole in 2009. I suffered such severe nausea that led to a passing out episode that I not only refused to continue taking it, I was afraid to try another A/I. I'm very much into holistic health -- have been all my life -- and felt comfortable working with an ND and doing I3C and hormone balancing as an alternative, although I probably got complacent after a year or two, so can't say I kept it up for 5 years. Anyway, almost 6 years from my original Stage II dx, I had a recurrence -- diffuse and extensive bone mets. The interesting thing is, my first line of tx after my re-dx was Anastrozole (Arimidex), which significantly healed my bone mets and kept me stable for 18 mos. I had a Grade 3 multicentric bc, both IDC & ILC, and a positive node with extracapsular extension, so there's every possibility my bc might have recurred even if I'd stayed on Femara or another A/I. Sometimes I just think some of us are programmed to recur no matter what we do, but I also feel like I totally underestimated both the Grade 3 factor, as well as just how powerful these meds are. I've also learned since I refused Femara, that what we're normally RX'd is generic Letrozole, which is made by several different drug manufacturers, and that sometimes what gives us the worst SEs are the fillers those companies use, which vary from brand to brand. (It should say on your med bottle which company makes yours.) This is something you might want to look into as well, as sometimes just changing sources can improve your SEs, as can a short break and then returning to the med. I am not trying to scare you or tell you are foolish not to do an A/I. It's a very individual decision. However, knowing everything I know now (which I didn't know in 2009), I would not make the same decision today, especially after seeing the difference Anastrozole made in my mets, and, ironically, with almost no SEs. Just my two cents worth... Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2012 11:46AM dlb823 wrote: Kaara, as I understand it, the length of time is only one of many measurements.  It's always very similar (in the 32 to 36 dose range) because it's a cumulative amount they need to achieve, but a lot of other varying measurements are based on the size & location of the tumor, size of our bodies, etc.   Most sizeable facilities have a radiation physicist and a dosimetrist to plan each patient's individual RT.  It's definitely not a one size fits all tx.   Hormonals are a whole different story, and one reason I declined an A/I after 1/2 dose of Femara clearly didn't agree with me.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 07:11AM - edited Dec 23, 2008 07:20AM by dlb823 Hi, mamakaren ~  I've missed seeing you on the August 08 chemo board, and have wondered how you're doing.  I'm 10 weeks post my last chemo tx, and still having serious body aches, as are some others on the August board, as well as some gals on the TC board.  I forget which chemo  you were on, but Taxotere seems to be a bad one for lingering pain.  Were you on that?  My eyelashes and eyebrows thinned dramatically at 9 weeks, which made me realize that the damage chemo does will not repair itself within a week or a month, but will probably take several months to resolve.  And neither of my oncs has been very helpful.  It's frustrating that they don't seem to recognize or acknowledge these residual SE's. If you're sure none of the swelling is heart-related or the beginning of lymphedema, all I can suggest is what I've been doing, which is using lots of vitamins, including B6, which was recommended to prevent neuropathy.  I'm also doing a liver detox supplement and just started a Chinese herb detox tea.  I've also been elevating my leg that is giving me the most pain on a pillow when I sleep, and that seems to help me sleep through the night and not be awakened by the pain.  Maybe you could try that for your painful hand and wrist. So sorry you're having these problems, but I just keep telling myself how strong we are all for getting through chemo, and that it is just going to take longer than any of us knew for the residual SE's to go away, but they will.  Christmas blessings to you ~  Deanna P.S.  My local onc had done a rheumatoid factor blood test during my chemo tx, just to be sure my pain wasn't arthritis, which it wasn't.  But he still seemed to think the pain, which started during chemo, was coincidental to the chemo and not caused by it!  (Are you kidding me?!?!)

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 10:40PM dlb823 wrote: Keighty, some of the larger, NCI-designated teaching hospitals actually have high risk programs where they will evaluate your true risk based on family history.  Then, assuming you are at higher risk than the normal population, they will both teach you lifestyle changes, as suggested above, as well as monitor you more closely, which will give you a lot of peace of mind, in addition to catching any irregularity as early as possible. Here's a list of the NCI-designated cancer centers.  Start by calling the one closest to you and, if necessary, continue until you find one.  If by any chance you're in California, I know for sure UCLA has one.  http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html Genetics certainly is a risk factor.  But there are a lot of things you can do to hopefully minimize that additional risk.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 05:01PM - edited Apr 12, 2012 05:06PM by dlb823 Maybe call the surgeon's office and get the name of the oncologist and his hospital affiliation.  Tell the surgeon's office that your Mom needs to fully understand the pros & cons of neoadjuvant chemo from the oncologist before she can decide what to do.  See how long it will be until he's in your town again, or if he's from a top notch facility, see if you can see him in his office, or would he do a phone consult if you or the surgeon sends him your Mom's biopsy and imaging reports.   I would try to get things rolling now -- just in case the onc's local day in your area is Monday or Tuesday. I would want to know the first day you can see him.  Since your Mom already has a bc dx, knowing this, any doctors should get her in very quickly.  If they don't, those are not the kinds of doctors you want.   Shopping for a doctor is very much like shopping for any other service, except we're stressed when we learn we have to do it, and often not thinking clearly.  Just take a deep breath and know that it will all work out okay.  It's just going to take a few phone calls and letting her surgeon know that she wants to be an informed patient before making such a big decision.  You might also ask your local surgeon or someone in his office exactly how many breast surgeries he does each year.  That might give you some peace of mind, or more conviction to look elsewhere.     Deanna  PS ~ MRIs are normally the next step after you get a bc dx -- before any tx decisions are made because the results may influence those decisions.

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2011 01:46PM dlb823 wrote: I don't think oncs normally RX anything for the bone pain from Neulasta.  Most of us learned here that Claritin (regular formula; generic brands work fine) helps a lot if taken a couple of hours prior to a Neulasta injection, and, if necessary, every few hours in the 24 hrs. following it.  Some women also add some Tylenol to boost its effacacy. Another thing that's probably worth trying is asking them to give you the Neulasta in your tummy, rather than your hip.  I didn't do that, but some women have reported that helped a lot too.   But I don't think what you've experienced (unhelpful docs) is out of the ordinary.  Docs just don't seem to recognize how bad that Neulasta pain can be -- probably b'cuz drug co's & reps seriously minimize that SE.     Deanna
