Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2015 11:03PM dlb823 wrote: Joy, I'm so sorry about your diagnosis. No matter how we get the news, it's almost too much to wrap our heads around at first. But getting it as you did with your staging changing rapidly from I to IV, is especially brutal. I'm not totally familiar with the medical system in Canada, but here in the US, not all oncologists think alike, and while most will start us on an aromatese inhibitor, there are situations where a more aggressive approach might be appropriate. It all depends on the extent of your disease. But aromatese inhibitors are extremely powerful drugs, and some women even achieve NED (no evidence of disease) with them. So either way, I'm sure you will get excellent care. You just may want to get more than one opinion to be sure you have an oncologist who will explain things to you a bit better and whom you totally trust. artistatheart, I'm not only sorry about your diagnosis, I am not happy that you feel written off. Without knowing where you're located, you may want to also get a second opinion. If you are in the US, I strongly recommend an NCI-designated cancer center, where you will find oncs who specialize in breast cancer, so may view liver mets a bit differently than a general oncologist. Our oncs should be hopeful and encouraging. The last thing you need is one who makes you feel written off from the get-go. That doesn't say a lot for their belief in their ability to get your disease under control. Here's a list of the top places where you may find more help and hope. http://www.cancer.gov/research/nci-role/cancer-cen... Hugs to you both, and hang in there! I know it sounds weird, but it truly does get easier, especially if you have an onc you trust and like, and once the meds kick in. Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 01:06AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Rovergirl  ~  I can relate to your situation, and just wanted to share my story in the hope that it might help you.  A few days after my 2/25 lumpectomy, my BS told me I needed a mastectomy.  Needless to say, I was in total shock, and I decided to seek a 2nd opinion.  That process evolved into getting approval from my insurance company for a 2nd MRI, then an MRI guided biopsy, then meeting with a plastic surgeon, then he and my new BS coordinating their schedules, and finally getting my mastectomy scheduled for 5/20, which was still a long month away by that time.  Waiting for each step was horrible. And yet, in retrospect, the wait, as hard as it was at the time, was probably the best thing for me because it gave me plenty of time to research every little question on my mind, talk to several women who had gone through it, decide which type of reconstruction I wanted, and all in all approach May 20 with much more confidence and peace of mind about it than I ever would have had back in March.  A similar thing happened with chemo, which I couldn't start until August 6.  In the beginning, I was absolutely terrified about it.  But, by the time it came around, I was so ready to get on with it. In your situation, if you are overdosing on info' to the point of meltdowns (which I also did), I'd suggest taking a break from the research for awhile, and just letting your mind and emotions catch up.  I used to get angry when my husband would suggest that, but I did it, and it helped. Another thing that helped me with my fear of surgery was a positive imagery CD called Successful Surgery.  It's available at http://www.healthjourneys.com/.  I was so impressed with how it calmed my fears, I later purchased one they have for chemo, which I think also contributed a lot to my change of attitude about that. And lastly, while waiting for both surgery and chemo, I decided I might as well use the extra time to get my body stronger by increasing my morning walks to 3 miles and eating extremely nutritiously, both of which I think helped me sail through surgery.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 01:37PM dlb823 wrote: CoolBreeze ~  Sorry for what you're going through, but I had a similar, dragged-out dx, and, in the long run, it all worked out for the best.  In my case, I had a lumpectomy in Feb of last year, but the pathology showed additional concerns and my BS wanted to do a mast.  I went to UCLA for a second opinion and had to wait for insurance approval for a 2nd MRI (a long delay, but my first one had been blurry), then an attempt at an u/s guided bx that couldn't find what they clearly saw on MRI, then finally the MRI-guided bx.  By the time my BS and PS had a compatible surgery date, it was May.  But the MRI bx found 2 more small ILC lesions that my first MRI & BS had missed, and by that time I was really trusting my UCLA docs and becoming more open to the need for a mast, which they never rushed me into.  I know how frustratingly slow everything seems to be moving for you now, but it sounds like you have very thorough docs, and that's great.  As far as what to expect, they put you in an MRI machine, face down, and there are grids on each side of the breast area.  You're numbed, and they get the bx samples while they have your breast pictured on the MRI.  Mine took about an hour, and I was extremely woozy (sick) and had some bleeding afterwards.  Other women here have advised taking an anti-anxiety med (I didn't), and in retrospect, that's probably a good idea if you're comfortable with it.  And be sure someone drives you.  You will not be in any shape to drive after it because the procedure can be a pretty stressful experience and takes a lot out of you, especially when we're already on an emotional rollercoaster due to the whole reason we're there!  Do you have a date schedule yet?     Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 08:05PM dlb823 wrote: Stacey ~  Here is a link to the thread I thought might be helpful to you: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/478386?page=10#idx_273 I've posted this information elsewhere, but one of the things that I found amazingly helpful for facing chemo is a guided imagery CD by Belleruth Naparstek at www.healthjourneys.com.  It's a  combination of music, guided images and affirmations that reframe chemo in a much more positive light.  She talks about a "healing fountain of sparkling liquid," and uses wonderful phrases like, "... thanking our cancer for teaching us what we needed to know, but now telling it it's time to go..."  There's a little sample you can listen to on-line, and you can download directly to an MP3 player.  Just a last-minute suggestion if you feel it might be helpful. And, if you haven't already found it, there's a thread here for women starting chemo in January.  It's really helpful to have support from others going through the same thing you are at the same time. Stacey, believe me, you are stronger than you think.  You can do this.  I'll be praying for you.  What time is your app't.?   Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2010 08:30PM dlb823 wrote: Just lost a lengthy post  (darn!), but will try to reconstruct the key points... There seem to be TWO disability benefits. SSDI (Social Security Disability Insurance) is for people who have paid into the social security system for a certain number of years.  SSI (Supplemental Security Income) is for anyone who needs assistance due to disability and/or limited income: http://ssa-custhelp.ssa.gov/app/answers/detail/a_id/245/~/differences-between-social-security-disability-and-ssi-disability You DO NOT have to be a citizen to get SSI:  http://www.ssa.gov/ssi/text-eligibility-ussi.htm I'm still not sure about getting SSDI if you're not a citizen (these sites are ridiculously confusing!), but I found this: http://www.disabilitysecrets.com/get-disability-if-not-citizen.html Irina ~ Have you inquired about BOTH of these programs?  It sounds like your Stage IV dx  qualifies you for SSI.  It may also qualify you for SSDI even though you are not yet a citizen IF you have paid social security for a number of years. Are you already possibly getting SSI?  If not, it sounds like that's the one you need to ask your case worker about immediately.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 04:47PM dlb823 wrote: (((PatriceRose)))  I also had lesions in more than one quadrant (discovered after I'd had a lumpectomy), and had a very difficult time accepting the fact that I needed a mast.  It's a hard thing to come to grips with.  What helped me the most was learning about Diep reconstruction.  It's a procedure where they basically replace diseased breast tissue with tummy tissue, and you end up with a really natural looking breast.  Very few plastic/vasular surgeons do it, but it's worth looking into.  I had mine @ UCLA, and many women on BCO have gone to a place referred to as NOLA.  When you're up to it, search the 'net for images of Diep breast reconstruction.  I think you'll be amazed at the results. Again, I know how hard it is to accept it when we hear we need a mast.  But needing aggressive treatment doesn't mean you're going to die.  You're just in the worst place right now, but there honestly is light at the end of the tunnel and you WILL get through it!    Deanna
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy of 2 different quadrants PatriceRose dlb823

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 06:25PM dlb823 wrote: tobo, which would you feel most comfortable doing?  If you wait 6 mos. and they recommend a biopsy at that point, would you have worried all that time, only to end up doing a biopsy anyway?  Chances are your situation isn't going to change significantly, and at some point, a biopsy will be recommended.  It sounds like the chances of your having bc are very slim (e.g. probably Bi-Rads 3), or they would have recommended a biopsy already.  But if it would ease your mind to have the biopsy done, and if they've already said they would do it, then that's not an unreasonable choice.  If you ask for a biopsy now and it's totally B9, would that lessen your anxiety? I'm also wondering, since you have very dense breasts, if your insurance would possibly cover an MRI (in lieu of a biopsy).   In the past, MRI's were only approved as diagnostic tools, after someone is already dx'd with bc.  But with dense breasts now recognized as a risk factor, I'm wondering your doctor could get an MRI approved for screening purposes.  Just a thought, and maybe someone else knows...    Deanna
Posts.Title: To biopsy or not? tobo april485

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 10:49PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, bean ~ What kind of doctor are you seeing?  The very fact that she doesn't consider you high risk when you have a sister dx'd with bc at age 41 makes me not comfortable with her degree of expertise about bc.  Did she give your suspiscious lesions a Bi-Rads rating, such as Bi-Rads 3 or 4?   If I was in your situation, I would look for a breast surgeon/specialist to review your imaging and advise if a biopsy is necessary.  That's also the kind of specialist who can let you know if you are truly at high risk, in which case he or she will set up more frequent monitoring, as well as discuss lifestyle changes that might be helpful in reducing your risk and increasing your peace of mind about it. You can find a breast surgeon at facilities such as these:  http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html If there isn't one within a reasonable distance of where you live, maybe call the closest one and see if they can recommend someone in your area. Hopefully, your lesions are all B9, but the recommendations you've had to date leave me just a bit uncomfortable, and I would hate to see you either have an unnecessary biopsy or wait 6 mos. when a more specialized and experienced doctor might be able to give you better guidance.  JMO.  Sorry you're going through this, but I'm glad you've found BCO!     Deanna
Posts.Title: Why am I not high-risk? bean bean

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2013 01:12PM dlb823 wrote: bean, there are many women on BCO who had children very young, and/or have quite a few children -- both supposedly risk reduction factors.  I'm not entirely sure what "high risk" means in terms of increased risk percentages (vs. normal risk), but as others have pointed out elsewhere on BCO, we are all at risk simply because we have breasts. I was on HRT (Prempro) for many years, which my PCP constantly reassured me was not only okay for me but beneficial -- in spite of the fact that I have a sister who is a 2x bc survivor.   In retrospect, common sense should have told me that I was most likely at increased risk and that prolonged use of HRT probably wasn't wise advice to follow.  But I think deep down those of us with sisters with bc have a hard time believing it can also happen to us.  Hopefully, it won't happen to you, and everything will turn out to be B9.  But don't let any doctor's advice override your common sense.  Consult with the best ones you can find, and be sure whatever you're told rings true for you.  If it doesn't and leaves you uncomfortable, get a second opinion.       I had multifocal bc that was both IDC & ILC.  The ILC only showed up on MRI.  The problem is, many health insurance companies will not approve MRIs as screening tools -- only for diagnostic purposes (e.g. after you've already been dx'd).   This is one more reason why it's often better to be seen by a breast surgeon because they will know how to get a screening MRI approved if they believe you need it.          Deanna

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 11:53AM dlb823 wrote: MHP70 ~ I think your list idea is great!  Communicating upfront where you could use help with rides, meals. childcare (if you have kids), etc., is perfect and should go a long way to ease your stress. You have also got to start putting yourself first, something that does not come natural to most of us women!   You need to switch from "spending most of my time fearing for my life" to "spending most of my time fighting for my life," which is your #1 priority right now.  Everything else is #2 or further down the list.  YOU come first.  Top of the list, before any meetings, etc.  It's one of the odd benefits that comes with a bc dx.  Please give yourself that permission right now and stop trying to do more than you can or need to until you have taken care of your own treatment and emotional needs.  Tell your family, "I will need more help from you for awhile, and I will also need you to help me remember that my regaining my health is the most important thing I have to do right now."  And tell your friends, "I'd love to, but my #1 priority is getting well and then getting my strength back."  Fighting breast cancer is not something we work into everyone's else's schedules and needs.  (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 06:34PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Viktoria ~  I had the same thing happen to my left thumb while on Taxotere -- first that audible popping for a couple of weeks, and then it became frozen.  I've done quite a bit of research about it, and I believe the taxane drugs (is Tamoxifen a taxane?) can damge the tendons for some of us.  Related to this (I think), I also had horrible pain in my right leg after chemo, which I think is also a tendon issue.  The good news is, 15 weeks post my last chemo tx, both problems are starting to resolve.  What I've been doing for my thumb is forcing it to bend (stretching it) as much as it will each day.  That seems to be helping now, but did not help when I was on the Taxotere.  I've also added a daily whey protein shake, to be sure my body has enough protein to rebuild.  Short of that, from what I've read, the next step is a cortizone shot.   I'll be interested to see what others have to say.  By the way, my onc seemed to be in the dark (or in denial) about Taxotere causing this kind of damage, but the rheumatoid factor test he did was totally negative, so I am 100% positive that Taxotere caused my frozen thumb or "trigger finger" (the term to use when you research it).

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 09:21AM dlb823 wrote: WinterStorm, are you asking about not having any surgery at all -- just chemo and/or rads?  If that's your question, the answer is, they really need to remove the primary tumor load.  Both chemo and rads are delivered to clean up rogue cells -- not ensure the complete eradication of an actual tumor.  As far as I know (and I'm not a doctor), that needs to be removed for the best outcome.  But as the others have said, depending on size and location, a lumpectomy is just as effective as a mastectomy, as long as you follow it with rads to clean up any missed bc cells.      Deanna
Posts.Title: Why not just keep the breast? Halah dlb823

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 10:27PM dlb823 wrote: Mindy ~ Just to clarify -- surgery, chemo & rads each do very different things, and chemo and rads are not interchangeable.  Chemo works primarily in our blood.  Rads basically sterlizes the area where the tumor was removed, so that any stray cells can't regrow there.  Have you been told you will need chemo?  Generally speaking (and not taking into account Her2+, etc.), if there is no reason to suspect your bc has moved beyond your breast (such as a positive lymph node, which indicates aggressive cells that want to travel), it's unlikely chemo will benefit you. If you have a small lesion in a large breast (think I read your comment about that on another thread), then it sounds like a lumpectomy with radiation will be what's recommended to you.  And depending on where your tumor is located, perhaps one of the newer, shorter courses of radiation might be appropriate for you.  I know the co-pays seem monumental, but treating your bc now, while it's still early -- whatever that takes -- whether it's asking for help from the organizations and programs that are out there, and/or asking for discounts and arranging minimum payment plans with hospitals -- seems like it's by far the better choice.  You probably have some options, and it's good that you're asking questions and exploring some creative solutions.  But I personally don't believe that foregoing surgery would be wise.  Please let us know what else we can do to help you continue to think this through.  You can PM me any time, and I'd be happy to talk to you on the phone, as well.  There must be some better solutions to your dilemna.     Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2013 02:44PM dlb823 wrote: You're absolutely not crazy! We are the best experts at what is going on with our bodies, and if a breast surgeon agreed that your concerns merited considering a biopsy, if only to ease your mind, then it sounds like it's worth doing. And it's good that she's ruled out IBC. I had a lump that I could feel for more than a year. My PCP couldn't feel it and it didn't image on mammo or u/s, so I decided that it must be a reaction to caffeine, especially b'cuz it bothered me more if I drank a lot of coffee. Well, I wasn't imagining it. It was an ILC lesion that, thankfully, had some IDC in it, which eventually imaged -- about a year later, when it was Stage II. But that experience taught me to trust my gut over what any doctor tells me, especially if I know something about my body has changed. Hopefully whatever you feel is totally B9, as the vast majority of lesions are. But as I said above, you need the peace of mind to be sure. (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 02:34PM dlb823 wrote: Absolutely!  I had TCx4, and other than the 3rd & 4th day of each infusion cycle, when I felt like a cross between the flu and getting hit by a truck, I was out and about doing whatever I had to do. Towards the end of my chemo, I grew increasingly fatigued and didn't have the energy to do as much.  But then I'd caught some sort of bronchial infection, which didn't help, and which took weeks to shake. My best advice (from hindsight) is try to get some exercise each day (to keep up muscle tone), and be extremely careful about not picking up a bug or illness -- like wash your hands a lot, especially if you're out shopping, etc.  If I had to do chemo again, I would also consider wearing a mask if I had to be out in a big crowd of strangers -- anything not to get sick.      Good luck!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 06:43PM dlb823 wrote: Sorry, but that's still a bit too confusing to be sure of what was meant.  The term metastatic usually indicates that the breast cancer has gone beyond the breast or lymph nodes.  That's why I can't figure out what is meant the way it's being said.  If she had an original tumor and two smaller tumors, those are sometimes referred to as "satellite tumors," but not metastasis.  And even though breast cancer often shows up in lymph nodes, where it's been stopped from going any further, that in itself is not usually called a metastasis -- just positive lymph node(s).   Deanna

Posts.Content: May 6, 2015 09:51AM dlb823 wrote: My thoughts... I don't believe there is any one cause, partly b'cuz it's been shown in recent years that not all of our bc's are the same (not just our hormonal or Her2 stats, but much more complex cellular level differences). I do strongly believe that in most cases (other than those w/a genetic link such as BRCA1 or 2) bc happens due to a compilation of things that stress our bodies and immune systems, which could be a different combination for each of us -- hormones, exposure to environmental chemicals (including in utero), prolonged emotional stress, etc. -- and that eventually something tips the scales and cells start to mutant. And if our immune systems don't catch them -- sometimes b'cuz they're too busy dealing with (even minor) autoimmune issues -- those cells get a foothold and are off and running. I also believe that there are a lot of yet unknown genetic mutations that increase our predisposition, like a new one just discovered in those of Polish or French Canadian decent. http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/293147.ph... Things I believe can make a difference for most of us include... Exercise (a host of research supports this); keeping a normal weight (extra fat = extra estrogen, among other things); eating for your health (which to me means making choices that are the most nutrient dense and feel right for your individual body, although I personally eat mostly plant based these days to restrict the amino acid methionine); supplementing what's missing in your diet, such as D3; eating organic (especially dairy -- that BST & rBGH is bad stuff -- but also avoiding GMOs, which have herbicides and pesticides built in); using toxin-free household and personal care products (because the cumulative affects of prolonged exposure to so many of them has never been tested); and perhaps most importantly (IMO), making a conscious effort to live as stress-free as possible.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2012 03:31PM - edited Nov 20, 2012 03:31PM by dlb823 Hi, Lully ~ I'm not sure why no one's responded yet to your question, so I thought I'd share a few thoughts.  Perhaps many are just too busy with holiday prep to be on bc.org much today. What jumps out at me about the information you provided is that your Oncotype score (26) is a bit high -- probably high enough that chemo needs to be seriously considered.  There's very little in the stats you've provided to give us a clue as to why your score is 26, but obviously there's a somewhat aggressive factor in the 20+ genetic factors the Oncotype uses that is influencing your score. Whether or not you do chemo is entirely your choice.  Personally, I had a really hard time wrapping my head around doing it, but -- in retrospect -- I'm glad I did it, although my stats were also quite different from yours.  One thing that might help you think it through is a website called cancermath.net.  I'll try to give you a link to the breast cancer page, which will give you some suggested stats w/ & w/out chemo:  http://www.lifemath.net/cancer/breastcancer/outcome/index.php Another thing that might help are threads here called "Oncotype Rollcall," where many women have reported their Oncotype scores and decision about chemo.  (Use the search box to the left to look for them.)   A third thing you might consider doing is getting a second opinion.  Not all oncs think alike -- especially about micromets (assuming you're referring to a lymph node), which some oncs consider a negative node, depending on the # of cells.  Whenever you have doubts about what you're being told by a doc, a second opinion can be really helpful.   Hope this helps, and let us know if we can answer any other questions for you.   (((Hugs))), and glad you've found bc.org.     Deanna

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 10:26AM dlb823 wrote: Hi, KT ~ So sorry about your Grandma's diagnosis.  If I was in her situation, I would definitely get a second opinion.  Not that anything is wrong or suspicious about what she's already been told, but it's just that all surgeons and/or oncologists do not always agree on the best course of treatment, and sometimes it's extremely helpful to get a second opinion.  It may confirm the first, or it may give her another option, but either way, it should yield additional information. And, due to some of the things you've told us, if at all possible, I would also want her seen by one of the larger medical centers for that second opinion.  They see the most breast cancer, and as a result will probably have experience with cases similar to your Grandma's in terms of her age, size of tumor, possible high KI-67 and other stats, which would be comforting if I was in her situation.  Here's a list of some of the best cancer centers: http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html As far as cutting away the skin, 12cm is a large tumor. If it's also close to the surface, there would be little or no necessary margin between it and the skin.  But all the more reason to get a second opinion -- just to be sure she's on the best track with doctors you all like and trust. Good luck to you both, and to your Mom ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 12:36PM dlb823 wrote: Stacey ~ Many of us have been exactly were you are, and we all made it through chemo just fine.  Anticipation is by far the worst part of it.  You've gotten some great advice already, especially about drinking water. Have you checked out the thread that's anchored the top of the chemo section here about what you need to get through chemo?  There are many little comfort things you can pick up and have on hand to help prevent or quickly treat any SE's -- things like Biotene mouthwash, a gentle toothpaste & toothbrush, antibacterial soap, and a laxative that works for you.  And remember, not everyone gets every SE you may have heard about.  Will someone be going with you tomorrow?  Probably a good idea to have someone drive you and be with you the first time.  I'll be thinking about you, and hope you'll let us know how it goes and how you're doing.    Take care ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2011 03:06PM - edited Jul 5, 2011 03:07PM by dlb823 Mags, I've been treated @ UCLA, so can offer a couple of observations.  One thing they have that I don't believe City of Hope does is a top-notch integrative medicine department that works with bc patients to maximize treatment benefits while alleviating its SEs.  Another interesting thing is that they have enough bc patients to have separate support groups for newly-dx'd, early stage, and metastatic bc, which means a support group geared to a woman's specific needs and concerns. I've heard wonderful things about City of Hope in general, but when I was choosing between the two for my situation, although City of Hope would have been a bit closer, I found UCLA much easier to get started with because of the multidisciplinary clinic they offer.  They're also very highly rated (#1 in the West) by entities that rate comprehensive cancer treatment centers, and their new (like 2 yrs. old) I.M. Pei designed hospital is about as fabulous as a hospital gets. Sara Hurvitz, my onc there, specializes in bc.  Let me know if you or your friend need contact information, links, or anything else I can help you with.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2012 10:33AM dlb823 wrote: Junekat, 3-1/2 weeks seems like a long time to wait for an excisional biopsy -- especially for a lump you described in a previous post as "golf ball size."  I'm not really sure what to advise you, especially because there is at least one very fast growing type of bc that is better off getting chemo prior to any surgery, and I'm wondering if that would include an excisional biopsy.  (Sorry, I don't know, and I'm not suggesting you absolutely have bc -- just trying to think through all the possibilities to help you make a wise choice.)  Also, if your lump now possibly has some sort of appendage or new growth, I would think your surgeon would need to know that prior to doing that biopsy.  So I would absolutely call his office and advise what you've told us.  If I was in your situation, I might also ask whoever set up this app't. for you (since I think you also mentioned not having health insurance in a previous post), and see if you can possibly get a 2nd opinion somewhere -- just to be sure the excisional biopsy is the best path to pursue.  Do you know if there's a large, university medical center nearby?  That would be my first choice for getting a 2nd opinion for you.   But do let us know what your surgeon's office tells you after you call them!   (((Hugs)))  Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 06:02PM - edited Apr 12, 2012 06:03PM by dlb823 If the surgeon expects you to return to his office on Tuesday with a decision about chemo vs. surgery after "thinking about it" for a week, then I think your Mom needs to insist on meeting with an oncologist first, to get her questions about those options answered.   You could certainly keep the appointment with him on Tuesday to ask some of the questions you now have, like "How many lumpectomies or mastectomies have you done?"  But in the mean time, I would work on getting a second opinion from another surgeon too.  As Melrose said, it never hurts to compare and get more information. And Melrose made another great point -- that at a larger comprehensive cancer center all the specialists are under one roof with shared on-line records.  No running around to figure out what's next or if a surgeon and plastic surgeon work together or even have priviledges at the same hospital.  Care under one roof or on one campus is much more coordinated with a much stronger team approach.      Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2009 04:56PM dlb823 wrote: Sorry to tell you, but thinking a lump is just a cyst mainly because you're just 34 is not particularly good medical care.  Not that it isn't a cyst; it may well be.  But if you spend any time at all on these boards, you will find that we have plenty of members in their 30's and even their 20's.  So I'm not at all comfortable with that kind of thinking.  Also, insurance companies are not quick to cover MRI's (they're expensive) unless you already have a diagnosis and it's being used to see if there are additional lesions.  So if you opt for an MRI, be sure your doctor gets it pre-approved with your insurance company. What kind of doctor are you seeing?  The best doctor to evaluate anything going on with our breasts is a breast surgeon/specialist.   Do you know if there's a breast cancer center in your area?  You really need to be evaluated by a breast surgeon who will know that you are not too young, as well as the fact that not having a family history doesn't preclude you either. Here's a list of facilities that will have the type of doctor best qualified to evaluate your lump: http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/map-cancer-centers.html If there isn't one within a couple of hours of you, call the closest one and ask them to recommend someone in your area.  Or, as an alternative, you could also start a new thread here, asking for breast surgeon recommendations in your area.   Good luck, and please let us know what you find out.  And by the way, 80% of breast biopsies turn out to be benign, so the odds are entirely in your favor that this is not breast cancer.  But you do need it ruled out.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 12:35AM dlb823 wrote: Yes, a simple mastectomy no longer requires more than one night in a hospital, if that.  I've actually heard of it being done at UCLA, one of the best facilities in the US, on an outpatient basis.  I don't think it's so much a lack of compassion, but that surgery for the procedure has become so skilled that it doesn't require longer hospitalization.  They are basically removing diseased tissue that is not within the body cavity, so if all goes as planned, recovery (without reconstruction) doesn't require a long hospitalization.  When a woman has immediate reconstruction, this makes the process a bit more complex, so sometimes a few more nights in hospital are required to ensure a good outcome.  I'm sorry about your boyfriend's Mom, but hopefully her surgery was done with such precision and care that she'll actually recover from it much quicker than you're expecting.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2011 01:39AM - edited Oct 29, 2011 02:01AM by dlb823 Deanna, if you let your Mom's surgeon know that she and you have questions and a concern about the ALND, hopefully she will slow down and answer your questions. Your Mom may have prepaid for the surgery, but that doesn't mean she has to unwillingly submit to or be bullied into a procedure she doesn't fully understand the need for, and/or may not want.  It's her body, and we are talking about surgery that can have a lifelong impact.  If she's not comfortable with this surgeon's attitude or demeanor, she may need to make time to get a second opinion, and the surgeon will just have to reschedule her.   OTOH, with extracapsular extension, I can see why a breast surgeon may want to remove a few more nodes.  But if I was in your Mom's situation, I would still need to be convinced that it's prudent (which it may be), and I would absolutely insist that they not take any more than they have to -- which I don't believe is all of them.       Deanna

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 09:01AM - edited May 7, 2012 09:02AM by dlb823 I had an MRI that I found out much later was blurry.  Unfortunately, my first breast surgeon didn't bother to repeat it, which would have changed the course of my experience.  So blurry or poor quality is my first thought.  Also, did they give you a contrast dye?  Forgetting to do that would be a second guess.  But why don't you phone the office back and just ask them why the need to repeat it?  Also you need to be absolutely sure that they've pre-authorized a re-do with your insurance company.  Those aren't inexpensive tests, and I very much doubt any insurance company will simply pay for a 2nd one unless there's a justifiable reason.   Good luck, and please let us know what you find out and what happens.    Deanna  PS ~ I just re-read your OP.  Did you already have the 2nd one???  If so, did they not explain what was going on???

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 12:29PM dlb823 wrote: Molly, here's another on-line calculator that might add to your thinking on what to do... http://www.lifemath.net/cancer/ Also, just a heads up that when you first join BCO, you're limited to 5 posts per 24-hour period.  This is done to prevent spamming, but at the same time, can be very frustrating when you're trying to figure out something as important as you are.  If you need to, you can continue a conversation with anyone here with the Private Message feature (PM).  Click on their screen name and it will take you to a page with that feature.       No one ever wants to do chemo, but one school of thought on breast cancer that many of us share is that it's important to hit it with everything we can initially, to hopefully prevent a recurrence, especially a metastatic recurrence. Have you thought about maybe getting a second opinion?  I know with my treatment decisions, it was always helpful to talk to a second and sometimes a third oncologist (or surgeon or radiation oncologist, depending on the step).  Sometimes you just need that one kernel of information that will help to crystalize your thinking on what's right for you.   Personally, although my dx may not have been the same as yours, I was extremely anti-medicine.  But I finally decided that I never wanted to wake up with a recurrence and always wonder if doing chemo would have prevented it.  But it took me weeks to get to that decision.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 09:57AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:50AM by dlb823 jeanette ~ I just want to pop back in here to comment on your post, which concerned me.  First, I'm also surprised at how vague your pathology appears to be, and how much information isn't there -- such as your ER,  PR status, or even the size of the lesion.  While I am all for a mast when necessary, and I know how stressful it is to be diagnosed, I would just hope that you know what size lesion you're dealing with before making the important decision you are.  Also, please do not let them take all of your nodes.  Unless there are circumstances re. your dx that are not included in your post, taking the sentinel node will tell you if they have to go further.  And even if they do, many breast surgeons these days will take only level 1 or level 1 & 2 nodes, leaving you level 3 nodes to do the job they're there to do.  Without any nodes, you are at high risk for lymphedema, which is no picnic if it happens to you.   Here's a link to some very recent research about lymph node removal.  Please read up a bit before you make decisions that can be life-altering and irreversible. http://www.usatoday.com/yourlife/health/medical/breastcancer/2010-09-21-surgery_N.htm JMHO, because I would not want you to do something under stress or in haste that you might later regret, and it sounds like you have very little information in hand upon which to base the decisions you're making.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 05:23PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Stillshell ~ I'm sorry to hear about your Mom's situation.  Was she in poor health prior to chemo?  Many of us had a rough time with chemo, but few women actually end up in the hospital these days, and then being on oxygen -- it sounds as if she may have had pre-existing health issues or a severe allergic reaction or something quite out of the ordinary.  What have her doctors said about her need to be on oxygen?  Again, this is something that would almost never happen to an otherwise healthy woman your Mother's age unless there were extenuating circumstances, or unless her breast cancer has possibly spread to her lungs, which we'll pray isn't the case.  But hopefully the oxygen is making her a lot more comfortable while she recuperates. As far as staging, remember, a lot of what you may read on the internet is based on data from treatment that was done 5 or 10 or more years ago.  In most cases, those of us dealing with breast cancer now are getting much more targeted treatment (like your mother getting chemo pre-surgery, which is something rather new), and even women who are diagnosed at Stage IV (the highest stage) can often do well for a very long time with today's treatment options.  No matter what your Mother's stage, one of the most important things is finding doctors who will work hard to help her.  That's why so many of us here are so keen on 2nd and 3rd opinions (even after you've had some treatment), because not all doctors think alike, and not all doctors (especially those who don't keep up on the latest research) approach especially later stage breast cancer with the same positive attitude and determination. The stages are explained in the informational part of this website (black bar at top of the page... symptoms & diagnosis... search staging).  I will pray that your Mother recovers from the chemo and surgery, and that you have some better news when you talk to her doctor.  Oh, and it's probably good that they didn't take more lymph nodes, to avoid causing lymphedema.  Hopefully, radiation will take care of anything that may have been left.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 12:50PM - edited Mar 12, 2009 12:52PM by dlb823 sueelizabeth ~ Wow!  You have really been through a lot.  First, I want to say that I agree with the other women here who thought your bruising wasn't abnormal, and I also want to compliment you on the way you handled yourself in your follow-up with your surgeon.  I'm proud of you for not losing your cool or breaking down.  But, I have to tell you, I wish I had been with you today.  That doctor's condescending attitude is unbelievable and so uncalled for that I can't figure out if he's just incredibly arrogant, or if his arrogance is also hiding incompetence.  At this point, if I was in your situation, I would absolutely go somewhere for a complete second opinion on both the cosmetic aspects of your surgery, as well as the pathology.  The one thing that is lacking and you will want to get a copy of is the Surgical Report.  I would suggest calling his office and asking that they make you a copy and leave it at the front desk where you will pick it up.  (If you wait for them to send it, you might be waiting forever.)  When you have that and any other records (like mammograms, ultrasounds, etc.), make an appointment at a comprehensive breast center for a second opinion.  They will be able to review your case and make recommendations as to what, if anything, needs to be done now.  I am really sorry that you've had this experience. Unfortunately, you're not alone, and it isn't until it happens that we learn that doctors can be very different in their approach to the same situation -- not to mention their personalities and demeanor with us.  I hope that your sharing your story here will help other women in the situation you were in slow down and get a second opinion, especially when it comes to surgical procedures.   Take care, and keep us posted on what you decide to do ~ Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2008 12:07PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, Charlotte  ~  I'm glad that you are happy with your surgeon.  That's extremely important.  As far as the lumpectomy, they make an incision and remove the lesion and a margin of tissue around it.  You'll have a scar from the incision, but it's normally an out-patient procedure, and you are home the same day. You'll probably have some bruising that takes a week or so to go away, but for most women there's no significant pain.  They will give you a pain med, but I never even needed mine because Tylenol was sufficient.  They will probably also do another small incision in your underarm area and remove 1 or more lymph nodes to check them.  I'm curious to know if you've had an MRI, just to be sure there's nothing going on besides the one lesion they've found.  If you haven't, I would ask about it.   I hope this information helps.  Don't be afraid to ask anything else, and you know you can also send me or anyone else here a private message if there is anything you want to ask off these boards.  Just click on someone's screen i.d., and the page it takes you to has a tab to send a private message (PM).      Take care  ~  Deanna

Posts.Content: May 30, 2010 05:56PM - edited May 30, 2010 05:57PM by dlb823 KMP ~ I'm so sorry you're having such a rough time with chemo.  Were your first 2 rounds 3 weeks apart?  And did they give you Decadron prior to your infusions?  Are you using anything to prevent mouth sores?  There's a mouthwash called BIOTENE that's very good while you're on chemo.  It's available at Target and most drug stores; maybe Wal-Mart, too (not sure).  Also, check out the top of the CHEMOTHERAPY section (Forum Index above).  There should be a list of OTC things to help with constipation, etc.  I can't recall them all now, but I remember buying about 5 or 6 things before I started chemo -- things like that mouthwash and a gentle laxative, etc., to prevent some of the problems you've been having before they happen. You didn't mention your family situation.  Do you have people there to help you, or friends you can reach out to?  It's hard to care about cooking when you feel so awful, but I found comfort foods like macaroni & cheese and grilled cheese sandwiches were the easiest to tolerate.  But you may need some help to be sure you eat when you can.  And are you drinking LOTS of water?  That's extremely important!      Hang in there!  Hopefully, your oncologist can switch you to Emend.  Just be sure that she is aware of all the problems you're having, so that she can make any adjustments.  Chemo isn't fun, but it shouldn't be as bad as what you're going through.      Deanna P.S.  When you first join BCO, you are limited to 5 posts per 24 hr. period.  So you may want to be careful about responding to every post.  If you do get shut out, you can continue to chat with anyone here by using the Private Message (PM) feature (like email).  Just click on any screen name or avatar, and it will take you to a page with that feature.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 08:35PM dlb823 wrote: Hi, chrissy ~ Like you, I believe that stress plays a role in developing breast cancer.  Dr. David Servan-Schreiber's book, Anti-Cancer, A New Way Of Life, has an excellent chapter on stress.  One of the interesting points he makes is that the worst stress is the kind over which we have no control, and I can't imagine a more helpless feeling than losing custody of your children.  If you haven't read his book, I highly recommend it.  Not only will it give you some additional insight into how stress contributes to illness, but it has many strategies and scientifically-based ideas for lowering our risk factor going forward.   I'm so sorry all of those things happened to you.  I pray the future will hold much happier times for you.  You certainly are overdue for them!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 01:01PM - edited Apr 12, 2012 01:03PM by dlb823 Strongme, I'm so sorry about your Mom's dx.  And it is all very confusing in the beginning, but it will get easier for you both as you learn the terminology and settle on docs you really trust and like. From what you've told us, it sounds like she has a competent surgeon, but I am always in favor of second opinions which can validate and give you peace of mind about surgeon #1's game plan, give you additional helpful information that wasn't communicated to you by surgeon #1, or sometimes come up with a doctor or facility you just like better than the first one. Is your Mom's surgeon a breast (only) surgeon?  These are normally found at the larger, comprehensive cancer centers, where they treat the most bc.  If her surgeon isn't a breast surgeon, that might be an excellent choice for a 2nd opinion.  And has she had an MRI?    As far as staging, yes, that always comes after surgery to remove the lesion and possibly more lymph nodes.  If you click on Symptoms & Diagnosis at the very top of this page, it will take you to the informational part of BCO where you can search "Staging" for a detailed description of the stages of bc.  This will help you understand what your Mom's surgeon believes at this point she is dealing with based on the estimated size of her lesion and node involvement. When your Mom starts chemo, she'll find a group here for those starting it that month, whether it's April or May.  That kind of support from others also going through it makes it so much easier than facing it alone.  I strongly recommend getting your Mom on BCO, especially for the support aspect. Best to you both!  Let us know how else we can help, and please keep us posted on her situation and how you're doing ~ (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2010 01:00AM dlb823 wrote: willingtowonder ~  One thing you might consider doing is getting a second opinion, and maybe even a third.  Another piece of the puzzle might be to ask for the Tamoxifen metabolizer test.  It would be a shame to count on Tamoxifen as your primary weapon if by some chance you aren't a good metabolizer, and there is a test for that now. An oncotype score of 3 is exceedingly low.  I don't know what factors about your tumor played into that low score, but prior to Oncotype-DX recently becoming available to women with some positive nodes, with 1 positive node and Grade 3 bc, chemo most likely would have been recommended for you.  I did chemo with 1 positive node after getting 3 very different opinions from 3 different oncologists.  And while it was "do-able," it certainly wasn't a walk in the park for me, and recovering from it -- getting strong again -- took several months longer than I'd anticipated.  So I think it's a decision that bears input from additional doctors, to help you decide what's really best for you.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 04:22PM dlb823 wrote: StrongMe, I know that seeing an oncologist who is only available one day a week complicates things a bit, but it seems to me that you and your Mom would need information from him before being able to decide if she wants to do chemo first (neoadjuvant chemo) or surgery first. How can her surgeon expect her to make that kind of decision without a lot more information, including the questions you've asked here?  As you've already figured out, there can be pros & cons to doing neoadjuvant chemo, although for some particular types and stages of bc, it can be the better choice.  However, I'm a bit bothered by a surgeon who expects a newly-dx'd patient to make that decision without a lot more input. I don't know where you're located, but I strongly second Windlass's suggestion that you get an opinion at an NCI-designated cancer center (the list she gave you), even if you have to travel a few hours.  That's what I did (after a lumpectomy that didn't get all the bc), and I met with all the appropriate specialists in one afternoon -- surgeon, oncologist, rad onc, and psychologist -- for a much more complete picture of where I was and what I needed to do going forward.  If there isn't one within a reasonable distance from you, maybe call the closest one and speak to someone in their breast center and see if they can recommend a surgeon and an oncologist closer to you -- perhaps a graduate of their medical school or former resident there. At the risk of sounding overly concerned -- just because your Mom's gyn has sent bc patients to this local surgeon for breast surgery for 10 years doesn't mean he's done a lot of them.  If you're in a rural area, that could be one a month or fewer, vs. an NCI-designated cancer center where they do several breast surgeries a day, 5 days a week.   It adds up to a huge difference in experience, not to mention keeping up on the latest research when it's all you do.  I think this is especially important if your Mom's bc is Stage III, in which case getting the right tx ASAP (whether that's chemo or surgery) from a highly experienced breast surgeon and oncologist can have a real bearing on outcome.  I'm also concerned that he hasn't done an MRI yet. JMHO, and you can read my bio page to see why I feel so passionately about this.     Deanna
Posts.Title: So confused. StrongMe23 Kicks

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 12:33PM - edited Oct 28, 2011 12:37PM by dlb823 Hi, Deanna... another Deanna here...  The info' Omaz gave you is extremely important.  When lymph nodes are removed, there is a serious risk of a condition called Lymphedema, which is basically miserably uncomfortable and painful swelling in the arm and/or truncal area.  Newest research shows that removing lymph nodes, which until recently was done automatically if the sentinel node was found to be positive, rarely impacts staging or treatment, so just isn't necessary in the majority of situations.   The fact that you said "all of her lymph nodes" also raises a bit of a red flag for me.  Even prior to this new study, removing level 1 & 2 nodes at most was plenty.  We need as many of our lymph nodes as possible left intact -- not only to prevent lymphedema, but also to do the job they're supposed to do, which is to catch the bad stuff (like the 4mm of bc) before it goes any further! Please encourage your Mom to speak up and question her surgeon on this, including showing him the research Omaz gave you!    (((Hugs))) Deanna  PS ~ About your question on chemo...  Do you know if your Mom had the Oncotype-DX test done?  That's what is used to determine the need for chemo.

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 09:01PM dlb823 wrote: tallydiver, just a few random thoughts on your Mother's situation...  (1)  Second opinions can be an excellent way to decide if any breast surgeon is the right one for you.  Comparing what two or more docs tell you, as well as their communication styles, will not only get you more information that you'll have if you see only one, it will give you a chance to see which one feels like the best match.  That said, based on my own experience (detailed on my bio page), I am highly biased for NCI-designatied facilities, such as Moffit, where they do the most bc tx, and are totally up on the latest research because they're the docs doing it.  And with the PNI, which appears to be rare, you want docs who have seen it before and have experience treating it.   http://www.cancer.gov/researchandfunding/extramural/cancercenters (2)  As far as a surgeon being young, I wouldn't worry so much about that if they're at a really top institution where they are working in the same department with top leaders in the field.  I'd actually be more concerned about an older surgeon in a more remote setting who doesn't specialize in bc.   (3)  Don't worry too much about what you read on the internet about things like PNI.  It can be outdated info', especially when it's a more rare subset.   So sorry about your Mom's dx, but most women treated for early stage breast cancer do very well!     Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2015 01:05PM dlb823 wrote: Beachbum, I have been thinking a lot about this post since I first saw it last night, and I guess what I most want to say is... Don't buy into the most negative information you see or hear, and if your oncologist isn't offering you a much more positive spin, find one who will. Of course it's true that some bc's can be very aggressive and difficult to treat. But it can also make a huge difference where you're being treated, and my personal opinion is that you need to at least get some input from a true TNBC expert -- someone who deals with it 24/7, as some do at the more prominent institutions that specialize in breast cancer. I say this because I know for a fact that UCLA and other top tier places (i.e. MDAnderson, etc.) have 15 and 20 year TNBC survivors, and A LOT of advancements in tx can and will happen within the next 5 or 10 or 15 years. I also believe, as wonderful as many of them are, there is no way a local oncologist who treats everything from lung cancer to prostate cancer to melanoma, can be half the expert on TNBC that someone who is actually doing the research is. Plus I believe that being pro-active in itself is very empowering and can lift your spirits. Also keep in mind that any survival stats out there now are based on patients who were treated 5 or 10 more years ago -- many before preadjuvant chemo, for example, was discovered to improve outcomes for women with TNBC. Hopefully, these stats will change dramatically as researchers continue to unravel the mysteries of the various types of bc's, and hopefully we will continue to have more more targeted tx's and even a cure within our lifetimes. (((Hugs))) Deanna

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 04:51PM dlb823 wrote: lemonjello ~  I'm so sorry that you've been blindsided with news of needing additional treatment, but, unfortunately, it's not uncommon for that to happen.  For the most part, chemo is done after surgery and before RT, and an Oncotype-DX test will ensure that you don't have chemo if you don't need it, or ease your mind that it's the prudent thing to do.  I know how frustrating these delays and situations can be, but it would be far worse if they didn't recommend chemo and you truly needed it.  So, try to roll with the changes and delays -- as hard as that seems now.  Have the Oncotype test, and know your likelihood of a recurrene with and w/out chemo.  You can always reschedule chemo for as soon as the Oncotype results are back, assuming you'll be able to move ahead then, without having left anything to chance.   Good luck, and please let us know what you decide to do ~    Deanna

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2012 02:57PM - edited Jan 7, 2012 02:57PM by dlb823 I think you're okay for a biopsy.  For more involved breast surgery, OTOH, I would strongly favor a breast surgeon, based on the logic that they see far more cases and variations of breast cancer, so just have the added finesse when things aren't straight forward or cut & dried.  General surgeons, even general oncological surgeons, have to keep up on the latest information for a variety of conditions -- from colon cancer to melanoma.  Are they competent to do a simple breast biopsy or surgery?  In most cases, yes. But there's absolutely no way they can be as experienced with breast cancer as a breast surgeon who looks at and performs surgery only on breasts, 365 days a year.    Hopefully, your biopsy will be B9!  But if anything about what you find out concerns you, keep a 2nd opinion with a breast surgeon in mind as a next step.   (((Hugs)))    Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2010 12:04PM dlb823 wrote: Kate, I don't have fibro but have dealt with two other auto-immune issues and am much the way you describe re. hightened stimuli -- especially the need to flee reaction I get in crowds.  I had read in the past was that oversensitivity to pain and discomfort plays a role in Irritable Bowel Syndrome (one of the things I had for years pre-bc).  In other words, those with IBC are more sensitive to pain than others.  At first read, I took it as an "it's in your head" rationale, but from what you're saying, there may be more to it. I've also found that since chemo my reaction to multiple sound stimuli is noticeably hightened, to the point of being overly frustrated when 2 people are trying to talk to me at the same time, or when someone tries to talk to me when I'm concentrating on something else.   So your and Barbe's comments have made me wonder if that reaction is even beyond chemobrain -- maybe tied into the auto-immune predisposition.    By the way, not sure if I posted this earlier and don't want to take the time to look back now, but I had recently met someone in cancer research (who is also a bc-survivor) who made a comment about having a theory that bc is actually an auto-immune disease, at least for some of us.  And the more I read threads like this one, the more I wonder if there is more of a connection than currently understood or acknowledged -- at least for some of us.   Deanna

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2008 09:23PM dlb823 wrote: Hello, Charlotte ~ So sorry to hear about what your situation, but it sounds like your doctors are being aggressive, which is good.  Is the surgery you're having on December 12 a biopsy or a lumpectomy?  I wasn't sure from your explanation.  And, yes, the waiting and worrying is hard on our families, too.  But it sounds like you have a wonderfully large family, and I know they will be there to support you.  It may sound crazy, but no matter how much you know you are loved now, you will find out how even more amazing and wonderful your family is when it's you who needs their support.  So, don't be afraid to lean on them a bit. You mentioned your mother-in-law. You know, a lot has changed in the almost 40 years since she had her surgery, so try not to worry about whatever she experienced.  Things have come a long way since then, with both treatments and outcomes being significantly better. You have come to a wonderful place to share your fears and get your questions answered.  Keep us posted on how you're doing. I will be thinking about you and praying for strength for you and your family.    Deanna
Posts.Title: CONFUSE WITH ALL OF THIS CHAR7 dlb823

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 01:29AM dlb823 wrote: Susskins ~ It seems like more testing might yield additional information to help you make your decision.  For one, I've never heard of determining if a lump is malignant or benign based on feel alone.  Has anyone suggested another biopsy or an MRI to you?  At the moment, I don't think there's any reason for you to rush into a decision as important and irreversible as a mastectomy or a bi-lateral mastectomy.  Your friend had a very aggressive form of breast cancer; so far, that isn't your situation at all.  If you must lose your breast(s), DIEP flap reconstruction, which I had, is wonderful. But it's a long surgery and a long recovery, and you will lose all nipple sensation and a lot of skin sensation.  You will also have a long tummy scar.  It's certainly nothing to rush into (even with a large area of ADH) because a nurse thinks a new lump feels malignant. Since you're in MN, have you thought about going to the Mayo Clinic for another opinion?  They're certainly amongst the best institutions and doctors in the US, and should be able to help you figure out what to do.    Deanna

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 11:01AM - edited Mar 2, 2010 11:03AM by dlb823 Wecome, Molly ~ So sorry you're joining this club that none of us ever wanted to be in, but you've found a great place for information and support. There's a thread here that might help you with your decision.  It's called New Oncotype Roll Call.  I'll try to give you a link to it:  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/730468?page=11#post_1598080 If that link doesn't work, go to the Forum Index above and scroll down to the Chemotherapy section.  You'll find it there.  There was also an older one that got very long,  If I can find it, I'll bump it for you as well. The only other bit of advice I can give you is be sure you know which chemo is being recommended for you.  Not all oncologists recommend the same ones, and this is something you should read up on and ask questions about if you decide you are going to do it.      Deanna

Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 12:42PM dlb823 wrote: beausoliel ~ I know it's hard, but I wouldn't read too much into a doctor's facial expression.  You have no idea what was going on in his head at the moment you saw a more serious look -- it could have been any number of things, including thoughts unrelated to what he was doing at the moment.  And, while the contents of a biopsy might be suspicious, I don't believe a doctor can visually tell if they're malignant or benign.  It's totally normal for our minds to go to the worst case scenario, but the fact is, 80% of breast biopsies turn out to be B9, and hopefully yours will be in that 80%.    (((Hugs)))   Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2011 09:38PM dlb823 wrote: LeesaAnn, most of us have only one shot at ridding ourselves of bc.  If it comes back anywhere other than in the breast, it's a whole different ballgame.  For that reason, and because your Oncotype score really isn't that low, and because of the LVI, I think chemo might be a prudent choice.  (Of course, I don't know you and I'm not a doctor.  I'm simply going by your stats and what I've learned over the past 3.5 years.) A question a bc survivor friend asked me when I was trying to decide, was...  "If you didn't do chemo and it ever came back, would you regret not doing it?"  That's a question only you can answer for you. In my case, I knew I would never, ever forgive myself.  Chemo was no walk in the park, but it's behind me now, and if you saw me today you'd never know I went through it.   One other thing to keep in mind... What if for some reason you have a problem with Tamoxifen or an Aromatese Inhibitor (the one that follows Tamox)?  I did, which now makes me extra happy I made the decision to do chemo. Just some random thoughts I hope will be helpful ~    (((Hugs)))   Deanna
Posts.Title: Onco 22 and must decide on Chemo LeesaAnn mdg

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 04:32PM dlb823 wrote: If any doctor makes you feel uncomfortable asking questions about your health and their recommendations for you, RUN the other way.  IMO, 2 things can cause that -- a knowledge gap, or ego -- and neither of those is a good thing. Competent doctors welcome your questions, and they should be able to quote research studies and reference their personal experience to back up their recommendations.  They should also be totally fine with it if you express a desire to get a second opinion.   Remember, you will be seeing your MO for a minimum of 5 years when you count followup post-tx.  Best to get it right from the start.  You might also want to ask to see their infusion area.  Evidently, there's a wide range of decor (upbeat to drab), as well as patients.  Some centers only cater to bc patients, while others handle a more general population. So you might as well check that out while you're at it. Good luck!    Deanna

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 11:39AM dlb823 wrote: LeesaAnn, I wonder if talking to another onc or two might be helpful?  You may not get any additional information, but sometimes what we need is just that one little tidbit of information -- that one insight that no one else mentioned in exactly the same way -- to help us solidify our thoughts on what's right for us.   Also, look into the Penguin Cold Caps.  I didn't use them because I didn't know about them at the time.  But quite a few women on BCO have.  (Use the search box to upper right to find at least one ongoing thread about them.)    I don't think oncs ever "dial down" chemo regimens to appease patients.  TCx4 was the original regimen for TC.  Some oncs felt better using 6, especially for women with multiple positive nodes, possibly because it was a newer regimen. Now I believe there's a trial comparing 4 to 6.  CMF (mentioned above) is known to be a regimen with perhaps the lightest SEs.  My onc @ UCLA has an on-line video comparing the various chemo regimens for bc, their SEs and stats.  PM me if you'd like a link to it.   If you do decide to do chemo, join the support group that forms each month here on BCO for getting through chemo.  (Click on Forum Index above and scroll down to the Chemotherapy Forum.)  Going through it with other women truly eases the journey immensely!   (((Hugs)))   Deanna
